attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648245addc', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-SFUND-2015-0781-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': '03/01/2017

Dear Administrator Pruitt,

I have some awareness of the issues at hand with hardrock mining. I live in Minnesota where we have our own 'hardrock' mining issue in the proposed Polymet mine. The proposed mine is located in a water rich area near the BWCA. Last I heard the State is requiring the mining company to put up money for potential cleanup costs while the mining is in operation and into the future as the toxic waste sits in piles and ponds. Last I heard the mine will be in operation for some 30 years and will provide good paying jobs to hundreds of workers. In other words, the mine will provide jobs for two generations of workers, three at best. But the waste will sit there in a toxic state for two or three hundred years. In a time span of that nature no one can know how invulnerable the containment of the waste will be to environmental conditions. And the benefit of the jobs and taxes and fees paid by the mining company, and the mining company itself, will be long gone. So the state needs a guarantee that there will be sufficient funds to pay for maintenance and cleanup cost going forward after the mine is closed.

It seems to me a common sense proposal to require mining companies to put up money for future costs associated with the toxic waste generated by the mining operation. This money should cover both ongoing containment as well as pollution cleanup caused by the waste leakage going into the future until the waste becomes benign. I suspect that engineers know that there designs for containing toxic waste generated by mining operations are not invulnerable to environmental affects on the the designs Mechanical Integrity. MI is defined as the management of critical process equipment to ensure it is designed and installed correctly, and that it operates and is maintained properly (i.e. no leaks and all elements are fit for service).

It is great that the mining operations will bring jobs to the local communities. It is great that the company will pay taxes and fees to government entities. But let mining not be a race to the bottom. Let us not compete with other countries, notably China, where mining operations are not well regulated and pollution is a guaranteed result of operations. We must insure that our own back yard is not turned into a waste land even if this puts mining operations at a competitive disadvantage with other countries.

Sincerely Yours,

Will Perry
13415 Europa Ct N
Unit 8
Hugo, MN 55038
6512460084

comment:
03/01/2017

Dear Administrator Pruitt,

I have some awareness of the issues at hand with hardrock mining. I live in Minnesota where we have our own 'hardrock' mining issue in the proposed Polymet mine. The proposed mine is located in a water rich area near the BWCA. Last I heard the State is requiring the mining company to put up money for potential cleanup costs while the mining is in operation and into the future as the toxic waste sits in piles and ponds. Last I heard the mine will be in operation for some 30 years and will provide good paying jobs to hundreds of workers. In other words, the mine will provide jobs for two generations of workers, three at best. But the waste will sit there in a toxic state for two or three hundred years. In a time span of that nature no one can know how invulnerable the containment of the waste will be to environmental conditions. And the benefit of the jobs and taxes and fees paid by the mining company, and the mining company itself, will be long gone. So the state needs a guarantee that there will be sufficient funds to pay for maintenance and cleanup cost going forward after the mine is closed.

It seems to me a common sense proposal to require mining companies to put up money for future costs associated with the toxic waste generated by the mining operation. This money should cover both ongoing containment as well as pollution cleanup caused by the waste leakage going into the future until the waste becomes benign. I suspect that engineers know that there designs for containing toxic waste generated by mining operations are not invulnerable to environmental affects on the the designs Mechanical Integrity. MI is defined as the management of critical process equipment to ensure it is designed and installed correctly, and that it operates and is maintained properly (i.e. no leaks and all elements are fit for service).

It is great that the mining operations will bring jobs to the local communities. It is great that the company will pay taxes and fees to government entities. But let mining not be a race to the bottom. Let us not compete with other countries, notably China, where mining operations are not well regulated and pollution is a guaranteed result of operations. We must insure that our own back yard is not turned into a waste land even if this puts mining operations at a competitive disadvantage with other countries.

Sincerely Yours,

Will Perry
13415 Europa Ct N
Unit 8
Hugo, MN 55038
6512460084

comment: I would love to get away from or cut down on the need of oil. However, at this point, oil is greatly needed in everyday use. Not just for driving, but paint, plastics, etc. Because we need oil, the best way to transport it is pipelines. It way look like it harms the environment during construction, but in the big picture it is better than the constant train and semi traffic.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648244c81e', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2016-D-4414-0002', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Private Industry - C0003', 'comment': "I join with the Honey and Pollination Center, Robert Mondavi Institute, UC Davis, the Pollinator Stewardship Council, and the American Honey Producers Association, to express concern of the FDA requirement for packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars."
This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars."
Not only is this confusing for consumers, it is also incorrect. There are no added sugars in pure honey. Honey is a totally natural product.
As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."
If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.", 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2016-D-4414', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064824e50c6', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-03-02T17:15:55Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-03-02T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2017-03-01T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'Comment from Elena Mudrak', 'trackingNbr': '1k1-8v0j-jmxy', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I join with the Honey and Pollination Center, Robert Mondavi Institute, UC Davis, the Pollinator Stewardship Council, and the American Honey Producers Association, to express concern of the FDA requirement for packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars."
This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars."
Not only is this confusing for consumers, it is also incorrect. There are no added sugars in pure honey. Honey is a totally natural product.
As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."
If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648244c81e', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2016-D-4414-0002', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual Consumer', 'comment': 'My comment is related to the wording being purposed for labeling which effects labeling of honey.
This FDA rule will lead consumers to believe that honey is adulterated when in fact pure, natural honey contains no added sugars whatsoever.

Consumers will be confused by this proposed label language. The implication that honey may be adulterated (as clearly suggested by this proposed labeling which states honey contains "added sugars") is of great concern as it will likely create an unnecessary negative perception of our product.

While it is recognized that honey may be a source of sugar added to foods, there is nothing added to pure honey that is packaged as such.

It would be much more logical and prudent if the FDA would consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey as "Total Sugars" and not "Added Sugars."', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2016-D-4414', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064824e5213', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-03-02T17:15:57Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-03-02T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2017-03-01T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'IA', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'Comment from Rebecca Marshall', 'trackingNbr': '1k1-8v0k-k2zf', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
My comment is related to the wording being purposed for labeling which effects labeling of honey.
This FDA rule will lead consumers to believe that honey is adulterated when in fact pure, natural honey contains no added sugars whatsoever.

Consumers will be confused by this proposed label language. The implication that honey may be adulterated (as clearly suggested by this proposed labeling which states honey contains "added sugars") is of great concern as it will likely create an unnecessary negative perception of our product.

While it is recognized that honey may be a source of sugar added to foods, there is nothing added to pure honey that is packaged as such.

It would be much more logical and prudent if the FDA would consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey as "Total Sugars" and not "Added Sugars."

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648235e037', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'DOT-OST-2016-0204-0002', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'DOT', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'DOT-OST-2016-0204', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Brenda', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064824e543b', 'lastName': 'Johnson', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-03-02T14:19:31Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-03-02T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2017-03-01T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment from Brenda Johnson', 'trackingNbr': '1k1-8v0n-wpla', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.

attributes: {'commentOn': '090000648244c81e', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2016-D-4414-0002', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual Consumer', 'comment': 'It amazes me that you, the FDA would require added sugars on a honey label. Honey is a natural sweetener made from the nectar of various flowers. With this addition to already overwhelming restrictions it makes it hard for a small time beekeeper to be able to bottle and sell honey. comment: It amazes me that you, the FDA would require added sugars on a honey label. Honey is a natural sweetener made from the nectar of various flowers. With this addition to already overwhelming restrictions it makes it hard for a small time beekeeper to be able to bottle and sell honey. The addition of added sugars on a honey label will only add to more confusion on the part of the consumer. Please rethink this and exempt honey from this requirement. Thank you.

comment:
When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.

comment: Please consider excluding honey from your added sugar regulations. It comes as the bees and God make it. We do not add anything to it!  That's like saying a grape farmer has to label them "sugar added" because grapes have naturally occurring sugars!!  Ridiculous, and it would be false advertising to boot.  Thanks for reading this

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648244c81e', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2016-D-4414-0002', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Food Industry - C0027', 'comment': 'Dear FDA:

Just want to be sure it's clear that pure honey does not contain any added sugar. It contains nothing but pure honey. It is a mistake to show sugar as an ingredient on a pure honey label. Please help educate the consumer by not confusing them. As a local beekeeper it important that people know exactly what they are getting and honey is perfect as is!

I join with the Pollinator Stewardship Council, and the American Honey Producers Association, to express my concern of the FDA requirement of packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars." This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars." This will confuse food consumers.

If this label is implemented at the commercial beekeeping level it will begin the misinformation to food consumers that sugar is added to honey. Eventually, it will create confusion across the honey industry and mislead the consumer about a natural product.

As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is." ', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2016-D-4414', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064824e5826', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-03-02T21:09:28Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-03-02T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2017-03-01T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'CA', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'Comment from Anonymous', 'trackingNbr': '1k1-8v0o-w6td', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Dear FDA:

Just want to be sure it's clear that pure honey does not contain any added sugar. It contains nothing but pure honey. It is a mistake to show sugar as an ingredient on a pure honey label. Please help educate the consumer by not confusing them. As a local beekeeper it important that people know exactly what they are getting and honey is perfect as is!

I join with the Pollinator Stewardship Council, and the American Honey Producers Association, to express my concern of the FDA requirement of packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars." This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars." This will confuse food consumers.

If this label is implemented at the commercial beekeeping level it will begin the misinformation to food consumers that sugar is added to honey. Eventually, it will create confusion across the honey industry and mislead the consumer about a natural product.

As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648244c81e', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2016-D-4414-0002', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual Consumer', 'comment': 'My name is Laura Day. I am a member of the Alamo Area Beekeeper's Association living in San Antonio, Texas.
My husband, Keith Day and I have been keeping bees for 2 years now. We plan to continue working with these very special Creatures for years to come. We have some serious concerns with the new rule directing the labeling of nutritional information of honey.
The honey industry supports and applauds the FDA for its continued commitment to informing consumer food choices through the nutrition facts label.
Honey is completely made by bees from the nectar of flowers. While honey is a source of sugar added to foods, there is nothing added to pure honey.
Listing the sugar content in honey as "Added Sugars" on the nutrition facts label implies adulteration of honey in its natural form - something beekeepers do not do or advocate.
As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."
If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.
Consumers will be misled to believe that honey is sweetened by adding an external sugar source rather than the naturally occurring sugars inherent in honey.
There is a risk of consumer confusion if the nutrition facts label notes "Added Sugars" but a separate area on the label notes "naturally occurring sugar." By definition, something added cannot also be naturally occurring. Our research shows that this will cause consumer confusion that hinders their ability to make informed food choices.
We realize that honey is added to foods in preparation or manufacturing and in that case it is clearly an added sugar in those foods and could therefore be labeled as "Added Sugars" on the Nutrition Facts label.
However, pure honey, itself, does not contain added sugars.
We share the desire for clear, understandable nutrition information to aid consumer choice.
Our desire, as is the FDA's, is to inform consumer food choices to promote public health without confusion or misbranding around pure honey.
To that end, we are asking that the FDA consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey as a "Total Sugar" and not "Added Sugars."', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2016-D-4414', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064824e5947', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-03-02T21:09:31Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-03-02T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2017-03-01T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'Comment from Laura Day', 'trackingNbr': '1k1-8v0q-e1lw', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
My name is Laura Day. I am a member of the Alamo Area Beekeeper's Association living in San Antonio, Texas.
My husband, Keith Day and I have been keeping bees for 2 years now. We plan to continue working with these very special Creatures for years to come. We have some serious concerns with the new rule directing the labeling of nutritional information of honey.
The honey industry supports and applauds the FDA for its continued commitment to informing consumer food choices through the nutrition facts label.
Honey is completely made by bees from the nectar of flowers. While honey is a source of sugar added to foods, there is nothing added to pure honey.
Listing the sugar content in honey as "Added Sugars" on the nutrition facts label implies adulteration of honey in its natural form - something beekeepers do not do or advocate.
As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."
If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.
Consumers will be misled to believe that honey is sweetened by adding an external sugar source rather than the naturally occurring sugars inherent in honey.
There is a risk of consumer confusion if the nutrition facts label notes "Added Sugars" but a separate area on the label notes "naturally occurring sugar." By definition, something added cannot also be naturally occurring. Our research shows that this will cause consumer confusion that hinders their ability to make informed food choices.
We realize that honey is added to foods in preparation or manufacturing and in that case it is clearly an added sugar in those foods and could therefore be labeled as "Added Sugars" on the Nutrition Facts label.
However, pure honey, itself, does not contain added sugars.
We share the desire for clear, understandable nutrition information to aid consumer choice.
Our desire, as is the FDA's, is to inform consumer food choices to promote public health without confusion or misbranding around pure honey.
To that end, we are asking that the FDA consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey as a "Total Sugar" and not "Added Sugars."

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481dc1394', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2015-N-1765-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual Consumer', 'comment': 'Docket No. FDA-2015-N-1765



As an employee in the indoor tanning industry, I strongly oppose the FDAs proposal to ban tanning by minors and to require customers to sign a risk acknowledgement form every six months. Our customers enjoy tanning for a variety of reasons, and for the reasons outlined below, no further government regulation is needed.



First, the decision of whether a minor should tan, be that outdoors in the sun or indoors at a tanning salon (that enforces limited tan times and other safety precautions), is best left to parents, not the federal government. Most states already require parental consent for minors to tan indoors, ensuring the parent has input and approval.



In addition, we have many teenage clients who are referred to indoor tanning by their doctor or dermatologist to treat skin conditions. Why should these clients be required to obtain these services at a dermatology office which is much more expensive than at an indoor tanning salon?



If minors are prohibited from using indoor tanning salons, they will instead use sunbeds at home, in an unregulated and unsupervised environment, and likely tan more aggressively outdoors. These alternatives would lead to an increase in sunburn and injury, compared to tanning at our salons which enforce tan time limits and other safety precautions.



Next, requiring adults to sign a risk acknowledgement certification every six months in order to use a sunbed is absurd. Our customers are already required to acknowledge risk before their first session; requiring this to be done every six months would be an administrative nightmare and tremendous burden to our salon employees, without serving any valid public purpose. There is no other product or service in the country, including the purchase of alcohol, tobacco and red meat, that requires consumers to sign such a form. It would be unfair to require such a form in our business and not for the hundreds of products and services which present many more dangers than UV exposure.



For all of these reasons, I am strongly opposed to these proposed additional regulations.

comment:
Docket No. FDA-2015-N-1765



As an employee in the indoor tanning industry, I strongly oppose the FDAs proposal to ban tanning by minors and to require customers to sign a risk acknowledgement form every six months. Our customers enjoy tanning for a variety of reasons, and for the reasons outlined below, no further government regulation is needed.



First, the decision of whether a minor should tan, be that outdoors in the sun or indoors at a tanning salon (that enforces limited tan times and other safety precautions), is best left to parents, not the federal government. Most states already require parental consent for minors to tan indoors, ensuring the parent has input and approval.



In addition, we have many teenage clients who are referred to indoor tanning by their doctor or dermatologist to treat skin conditions. Why should these clients be required to obtain these services at a dermatology office which is much more expensive than at an indoor tanning salon?



If minors are prohibited from using indoor tanning salons, they will instead use sunbeds at home, in an unregulated and unsupervised environment, and likely tan more aggressively outdoors. These alternatives would lead to an increase in sunburn and injury, compared to tanning at our salons which enforce tan time limits and other safety precautions.



Next, requiring adults to sign a risk acknowledgement certification every six months in order to use a sunbed is absurd. Our customers are already required to acknowledge risk before their first session; requiring this to be done every six months would be an administrative nightmare and tremendous burden to our salon employees, without serving any valid public purpose. There is no other product or service in the country, including the purchase of alcohol, tobacco and red meat, that requires consumers to sign such a form. It would be unfair to require such a form in our business and not for the hundreds of products and services which present many more dangers than UV exposure.



For all of these reasons, I am strongly opposed to these proposed additional regulations.

My concern is that you are removing my rights to make decisions on my own. I am a grown adult and you are trying to control how often I want to tan or if I want to allow my child to tan when I FEEL SHE IS OLD ENOUGH. This is my life to make my decisions in. You wouldn't dare dream of limiting how many cigarettes a person smoke a week/month/year. There is no difference here. As a parent---it is my responsibility to decide what is best for my children. You do not know personal issues and cases and one blanket "no one under 18 can tan" is not smart. This will only lead to individuals purchasing a tanning unit and using it as often as they want, for how long they want, while also allowing anyone else in the neighborhood that wants to use it the same. This doesn't allow people to be educated in the correct way. The salon I use has done a fabulous job of teaching me to start off with lower time increments and building a base tan slowly and keep from burning.

This is not the right thing to do.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2015-N-1765', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481ec87c0', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-03-02T16:56:09Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-03-02T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-03-16T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'Comment from Brie Smith', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8oj4-yesb', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I wanted to take a moment to send my concern regarding these proposals. My concern is that you are removing my rights to make decisions on my own. I am a grown adult and you are trying to control how often I want to tan or if I want to allow my child to tan when I FEEL SHE IS OLD ENOUGH. This is my life to make my decisions in. You wouldn't dare dream of limiting how many cigarettes a person smoke a week/month/year. There is no difference here. As a parent---it is my responsibility to decide what is best for my children. You do not know personal issues and cases and one blanket "no one under 18 can tan" is not smart. This will only lead to individuals purchasing a tanning unit and using it as often as they want, for how long they want, while also allowing anyone else in the neighborhood that wants to use it the same. This doesn't allow people to be educated in the correct way. The salon I use has done a fabulous job of teaching me to start off with lower time increments and building a base tan slowly and keep from burning.

I could continue but again---you are making proposals that take away my freedoms and rights to make my own decisions. This is not the right thing to do.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481dc1394', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2015-N-1765-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Health Professional - A0007', 'comment': 'As a physician, I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2015-N-1765', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481eca148', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-03-02T20:20:21Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-03-02T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-03-16T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'Comment from George Glassman', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8oj9-tm5i', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
As a physician, I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.

{'commentOn': '090000648062870f', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'HUD-2007-0065-7135', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'HUD', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Hello!

My name is Michael Brock and I am a Home Loan Consultant in Knoxville,
Tennessee. I work for Countrywide Home Loans and have been originating great
loans for great clients by utilizing downpayment assistance programs such as
Nehemiah, Genesis, and Ameri-Dream for over a year.

Since the fall of 100% loans, I have helped numerous families start their first home
buying experience of their lives with the FHA government 30 year fixed loans by
utilizing these downpayment assistance programs. They have truly been a dream
for millions of American's looking to own their own homes.

By discarding these programs, there are a number of negative things that will
result.

First, home prices will continue to decline at an astronomical rate as there will be
at least 20% less home sales going on without the ability to use these
downpayment assistance programs. The backbone of the American people has
been chopped off enough. Do not allow for tens of millions of more people to have
upside down mortgages on their home values.

Second, the job loss throughout the US will be astronomical as loan originators,
processors, underwriters, HUD officials themselves, downpayment assistance
program employee's, appraisers, title workers, and even realtors will all lose their
income levels which are currently down a huge amount from the previous levels in
2006 and 2007. Job loss only means more bad economical news, higher rates to
new buyers, and stocks dropping like flies.

Third, think of the credit worthy people whom will make great payments on time
throughout their mortgage who need help with downpayment assistance. Why
should they be penalized for the corrupt laws of our politicians and our economic
heads of state? Why should they be unable to buy a home because our
Republican controlled presidency, senate, and house failed to put the necessary
oversight needed back in 2003, 2004, 2005, and 2006? All politics aside, this is
ridiculous that there was never regulation enough to begin with!

You can not allow for these great programs to go away and endanger the lives of
MILLIONS of hard working Americans. The job loss, value decline, economic
stress, and inablility to purchase homes with no money down for credit worthy
borrowers can not resume.

Please help us all to continue closing good clean loans for good clean borrowers!

Thank you so much!', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'HUD-2007-0065', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064806b5227', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2008-08-08T11:11:27Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2008-08-08T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2008-08-07T11:11:24Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment Submitted by Michael Brock, Countrywide Home Loans', 'trackingNbr': '806b5227', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Hello!

My name is Michael Brock and I am a Home Loan Consultant in Knoxville,
Tennessee. I work for Countrywide Home Loans and have been originating great
loans for great clients by utilizing downpayment assistance programs such as
Nehemiah, Genesis, and Ameri-Dream for over a year.

Since the fall of 100% loans, I have helped numerous families start their first home
buying experience of their lives with the FHA government 30 year fixed loans by
utilizing these downpayment assistance programs. They have truly been a dream
for millions of American's looking to own their own homes.

By discarding these programs, there are a number of negative things that will
result.

First, home prices will continue to decline at an astronomical rate as there will be
at least 20% less home sales going on without the ability to use these
downpayment assistance programs. The backbone of the American people has
been chopped off enough. Do not allow for tens of millions of more people to have
upside down mortgages on their home values.

Second, the job loss throughout the US will be astronomical as loan originators,
processors, underwriters, HUD officials themselves, downpayment assistance
program employee's, appraisers, title workers, and even realtors will all lose their
income levels which are currently down a huge amount from the previous levels in
2006 and 2007. Job loss only means more bad economical news, higher rates to
new buyers, and stocks dropping like flies.

Third, think of the credit worthy people whom will make great payments on time
throughout their mortgage who need help with downpayment assistance. Why
should they be penalized for the corrupt laws of our politicians and our economic
heads of state? Why should they be unable to buy a home because our
Republican controlled presidency, senate, and house failed to put the necessary
oversight needed back in 2003, 2004, 2005, and 2006? All politics aside, this is
ridiculous that there was never regulation enough to begin with!

You can not allow for these great programs to go away and endanger the lives of
MILLIONS of hard working Americans. The job loss, value decline, economic
stress, and inablility to purchase homes with no money down for credit worthy
borrowers can not resume.

Please help us all to continue closing good clean loans for good clean borrowers!

Thank you so much!

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006480620ee8', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAR-FAR-2008-0001-0003', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '538 Broadhollow Road', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAR', 'city': 'Melville', 'category': None, 'comment': 'As a human resource (HR) professional and one of the nearly 245,000 members of
the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM), I appreciate the opportunity
to share my views on this important workplace issue. Ensuring that employees
are authorized to work is a vital part of the human resource function.

I support the establishment of a federal electronic employment verification
system; one that is administratively easy to use, provides accurate results, and
does not create new employer liabilities. However, I am concerned that
mandating the use of E-Verify without first fixing its underlying problems
(which have been well-documented in testimony before the U.S. Congress) will
only exacerbate the problems certain employers and employees have encountered
with using the system.

I have included the shortfall of the e-verify system which I urge you to review
before mandating it's use.', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FAR-FAR-2008-0001', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Janise', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064806a6b63', 'lastName': 'Verdi-Soskil', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-01-15T00:41:17Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2008-08-08T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2008-08-01T15:34:04Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'NY', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comments', 'title': 'FAR Case 2007-013, Employment Eligibility Verification (Comment 127)', 'trackingNbr': '806a6b63', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '11747', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
As a human resource (HR) professional and one of the nearly 245,000 members of
the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM), I appreciate the opportunity
to share my views on this important workplace issue. Ensuring that employees
are authorized to work is a vital part of the human resource function.

I support the establishment of a federal electronic employment verification
system; one that is administratively easy to use, provides accurate results, and
does not create new employer liabilities. However, I am concerned that
mandating the use of E-Verify without first fixing its underlying problems
(which have been well-documented in testimony before the U.S. Congress) will
only exacerbate the problems certain employers and employees have encountered
with using the system.

I have included the shortfall of the e-verify system which I urge you to review
before mandating it's use.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006480620ee8', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAR-FAR-2008-0001-0003', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '5203 Leesburg Pike', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAR', 'city': 'Falls Church', 'category': None, 'comment': 'FAR Case 2007-013

The proposed changes to the FAR mandating use of the E-Verify system by
Federal Contractors and Subcontractors under contracts over $3,000 pose
logistical concerns for employers and employees.

The contemplated time frame of eight days will not be a sufficient period of time for
an individual to resolve a records discrepancy in the SSA or USCIS databases,
particularly if the individual must secure birth or citizenship records to resolve a
discrepancy. Workers should have the ability to access and correct their records
prior to the generation of a nonconfirmation notice.

The summary of costs and benefits outlined in the Supplementary Information of
the proposed rules underestimates the adverse impact on employers, particularly
small businesses, of terminating employees who cannot resolve records
discrepancies within eight days.

Although the E-Verify system is reportedly accurate, the influx of the estimated
more than 160,000 additional employers using the system by FAR requirement
could diminish the performance and accuracy of the system and support
services. The Government should consider a staged transition to the use of the
system at a contract threshold higher than $3,000.
', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FAR-FAR-2008-0001', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Fern', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006480691189', 'lastName': 'Ward', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-01-15T00:41:53Z', 'organization': 'IntelliDyne, LLC', 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2008-08-08T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2008-07-23T20:20:12Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'VA', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comments', 'title': 'FAR Case 2007-013, Employment Eligibility Verification (Comment #34)', 'trackingNbr': '80691189', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '22041', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
FAR Case 2007-013

The proposed changes to the FAR mandating use of the E-Verify system by
Federal Contractors and Subcontractors under contracts over $3,000 pose
logistical concerns for employers and employees.

The contemplated time frame of eight days will not be a sufficient period of time for
an individual to resolve a records discrepancy in the SSA or USCIS databases,
particularly if the individual must secure birth or citizenship records to resolve a
discrepancy. Workers should have the ability to access and correct their records
prior to the generation of a nonconfirmation notice.

The summary of costs and benefits outlined in the Supplementary Information of
the proposed rules underestimates the adverse impact on employers, particularly
small businesses, of terminating employees who cannot resolve records
discrepancies within eight days.

Although the E-Verify system is reportedly accurate, the influx of the estimated
more than 160,000 additional employers using the system by FAR requirement
could diminish the performance and accuracy of the system and support
services. The Government should consider a staged transition to the use of the
system at a contract threshold higher than $3,000.

{'commentOn': '090000648053d497', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FWS-R9-NSR-2008-0062-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FWS', 'city': 'Saco', 'category': None, 'comment': 'I think that law-abiding citizens should be allowed to carry, transport firearms for
personal protection in lands run by NPS & FWS. Why should I have to go around
these lands just because I carry a gun? I'm not a bad person, or looking for
trouble I just want to be sure that my family & I are protected. Thank you for
listening to my thoughts. ', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FWS-R9-NSR-2008-0062', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Eugene', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064806b6c59', 'lastName': 'Salveson', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2014-01-18T17:42:49Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2008-08-08T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2008-08-08T03:53:03Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'MT', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # E8-09606', 'trackingNbr': '806b6c59', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '59261', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I think that law-abiding citizens should be allowed to carry, transport firearms for
personal protection in lands run by NPS & FWS. Why should I have to go around
these lands just because I carry a gun? I'm not a bad person, or looking for
trouble I just want to be sure that my family & I are protected. Thank you for
listening to my thoughts.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648053d497', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FWS-R9-NSR-2008-0062-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FWS', 'city': 'Vail', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Protecting State and Federal lands, national parks, reserves are important to all of
us across America. The protection rights of law-bidding citizens to carry firearms
in self-defense is part of our Constitutional rights. We as law-bidding citizens with
State laws and regulations to carry concealed weapons should not be divided by a
line in the sand (due to crossing into a State Park, Federal or State Game
Reserve or National Park). We as law-bidding citizens have been trained, certified,
fingerprinted and documented to carry a firearm concealed to preserve the safety
of another human life (whether it is our own or a family member or another person
in our presence). The current laws prohibiting law-bidding citizens from protecting
our selves should be revised to allow law-bidding citizens to carry firearms onto
National Parks, Game Reserves. Criminals do not follow the laws of the land and
thus we are exposed to self-protected by other means.

Thanks you for your time and consideration in this very important matter.

Patrick G. Heater', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FWS-R9-NSR-2008-0062', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Patrick', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064806b6b45', 'lastName': 'Heater', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2014-01-18T18:23:30Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2008-08-08T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2008-08-08T03:19:25Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'AZ', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # E8-09606', 'trackingNbr': '806b6b45', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '85641', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Protecting State and Federal lands, national parks, reserves are important to all of
us across America. The protection rights of law-bidding citizens to carry firearms
in self-defense is part of our Constitutional rights. We as law-bidding citizens with
State laws and regulations to carry concealed weapons should not be divided by a
line in the sand (due to crossing into a State Park, Federal or State Game
Reserve or National Park). We as law-bidding citizens have been trained, certified,
fingerprinted and documented to carry a firearm concealed to preserve the safety
of another human life (whether it is our own or a family member or another person
in our presence). The current laws prohibiting law-bidding citizens from protecting
our selves should be revised to allow law-bidding citizens to carry firearms onto
National Parks, Game Reserves. Criminals do not follow the laws of the land and
thus we are exposed to self-protected by other means.

Thanks you for your time and consideration in this very important matter.

Patrick G. Heater

comment:
Please allow concealed carry in parks, there is no way rangers can be everywhere all

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648053d497', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FWS-R9-NSR-2008-0062-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FWS', 'city': 'Olive Branch', 'category': None, 'comment': 'I support the amendments to regulation specified in Docket ID: FWS-R9-NSR-
2008-0062 Document ID: FWS-R9-NSR-2008-0062-32426.1. As a matter of
practicality, this will enhance the general safety of the public on federal lands and
reduce the, sometimes severe, inconveniences for those otherwise authorized to
legally carry concealed weapons. Current regulations present good citizens with a
hazard resulting from the fact that criminals on our federal lands are unlikely to
abide by them. Thus the regulation as currently written only prevents honest
citizens from self-protection against the dangerous criminals that sometimes use
our parks to ply their trade. This revision will also reduce the exposure of law
abiding persons to unnecessary and pointless potential penalties for inadvertent
carry mistakes when moving between contiguous state and federal regulated
lands.
', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FWS-R9-NSR-2008-0062', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'John', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064806b6dec', 'lastName': 'McInnis', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2014-01-17T21:08:12Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2008-08-08T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2008-08-08T04:59:33Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'MS', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # N/A', 'trackingNbr': '806b6dec', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '38654', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I support the amendments to regulation specified in Docket ID: FWS-R9-NSR-
2008-0062 Document ID: FWS-R9-NSR-2008-0062-32426.1. As a matter of
practicality, this will enhance the general safety of the public on federal lands and
reduce the, sometimes severe, inconveniences for those otherwise authorized to
legally carry concealed weapons. Current regulations present good citizens with a
hazard resulting from the fact that criminals on our federal lands are unlikely to
abide by them. Thus the regulation as currently written only prevents honest
citizens from self-protection against the dangerous criminals that sometimes use
our parks to ply their trade. This revision will also reduce the exposure of law
abiding persons to unnecessary and pointless potential penalties for inadvertent
carry mistakes when moving between contiguous state and federal regulated
lands.

attributes:

comment:
Ref: Firearm carry in National Parks and Refuges: As a law man it is crucial to be
prepared to defend either myself or another against serious bodily harm or death.
As a citizen of these United States this right is truely among our most treasured
amendments. Please accept these comments as my intent to support updating
such laws as to allow the lawful carry of a firearm by our law enforcement and law
abiding citizens within our National Parks and Refuges.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648053d497', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FWS-R9-NSR-2008-0062-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FWS', 'city': 'Spring Hill', 'category': None, 'comment': 'I am a law abiding citizen, a physician, with a concealed weapon permit. There is
no rational justification for not allowing me to protect myself and family, or for me
to unknowingly commit a crime, by continuing to disallow carrying my weapon
into a national park. These borders into the park are frequently suddenly come
upon, and easily confused with state parks. When a national park is noticed, it is
often impossible to avoid becoming a criminal, if only for a moment. The rule
keeping me from self protection in an area with multiple acute risks should be
abandoned.', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FWS-R9-NSR-2008-0062', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Karl', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064806b77cf', 'lastName': 'Leibensperger', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2014-01-18T18:13:36Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2008-08-08T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2008-08-08T12:05:11Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'FL', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # E8-09606', 'trackingNbr': '806b77cf', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '34608-7486', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I am a law abiding citizen, a physician, with a concealed weapon permit. There is
no rational justification for not allowing me to protect myself and family, or for me
to unknowingly commit a crime, by continuing to disallow carrying my weapon
into a national park. These borders into the park are frequently suddenly come
upon, and easily confused with state parks. When a national park is noticed, it is
often impossible to avoid becoming a criminal, if only for a moment. The rule
keeping me from self protection in an area with multiple acute risks should be
abandoned.

attributes: {'commentOn': '0900006480f8987b', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'WHD-2011-0003-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'WHD', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'I support the expansion of labor protections for home-care workers. And their work should be valued as such, with the same labor protections afforded to all workers in our country.  ', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'WHD-2011-0003', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Susan', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006480fd0c9a', 'lastName': 'Levy', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2012-03-08T11:59:54Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2012-03-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-03-07T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Levy, Susan', 'trackingNbr': '80fd0c9a', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: I support the expansion of labor protections for home-care workers.  My family relied for years on the work and support of care givers, and their work was essential to my families ability to function.  They made all other work possible.  And their work should be valued as such, with the same labor protections afforded to all workers in our country.

attributes: {'commentOn': '0900006480f8987b', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'WHD-2011-0003-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'WHD', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'I am writing in support of the Department of Labor’s proposed rule that would narrow the current exemption of home care workers from the minimum wage and overtime protections under the Fair Labor Standards Act. The proposed regulations will help to stabilize the home care workforce that is experiencing high turnover because of low pay and long hours. These workers help elders and people with disabilities stay in their homes and out of institutions and these protections will result in less attrition and better quality care.  I also support the proposed rule to require employers of live-in domestic workers to keep records of their workers’ hours worked. But it is important for the employers to keep other records like the rate of pay, total wages paid, or deductions for meals and housing. Deductions for meals and housing are common for live-in workers, and without keeping these records, it is easy to make errors in calculating the worker’s wages. Employers can easily keep track of these records using computers or smartphones. I hope you will move this proposal forward!', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'WHD-2011-0003', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Nancy', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006480fd119b', 'lastName': 'Nelson', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2012-03-08T12:55:49Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2012-03-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-03-07T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Nelson, Nancy', 'trackingNbr': '80fd119b', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: I am writing in support of the Department of Labor’s proposed rule that would narrow the current exemption of home care workers from the minimum wage and overtime protections under the Fair Labor Standards Act. The proposed regulations will help to stabilize the home care workforce that is experiencing high turnover because of low pay and long hours. These workers help elders and people with disabilities stay in their homes and out of institutions and these protections will result in less attrition and better quality care.  I also support the proposed rule to require employers of live-in domestic workers to keep records of their workers’ hours worked. But it is important for the employers to keep other records like the rate of pay, total wages paid, or deductions for meals and housing. Deductions for meals and housing are common for live-in workers, and without keeping these records, it is easy to make errors in calculating the worker’s wages. Employers can easily keep track of these records using computers or smartphones. I hope you will move this proposal forward!

comment:
Par (h) of NPRM indicates the hose is to be modified, in accordance with the Accomplishment Instructions of Bombardier Service Bulletin 601R-35-017, Revision A, dated June 9, 2011. The Service Bulletin states in various places to discard the hose.
Please change the NPRM accordingly.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006480f8987b', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'WHD-2011-0003-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'WHD', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Dear President Obama and the Department of Labor,

I am a worker writing to urge the Department of Labor to implement new rules (RIN 1235-AA05) to protect live-in domestic workers and narrow the “companionship exemption,” which currently excludes nearly two million home care workers from federal minimum wage and overtime protections. Live-in domestic workers and home care workers are unfairly denied the same baseline wage and hour protections that most other workers in our society can depend on.

The revised rule should: (1) ensure that workers employed by home care agencies or other intermediaries are not exempt; and (2) narrow the definition of “companionship” to cover only fellowship and protection, thereby excluding workers who assist clients with activities of daily living (ADLs) or instrumental activities of daily living (IADLs)


The revised rule should also require employers of live-in workers to keep records of hours worked, rate of pay, and deductions from wages for meals and housing.


Home care workers and live-in domestic workers deserve full labor protections; our families, our clients, and the industry as a whole will also benefit from this much-need reform.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'WHD-2011-0003', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Fernando', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006480fd1252', 'lastName': 'Castillp', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2012-03-08T12:14:36Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2012-03-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-03-07T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Castillp, Fernando', 'trackingNbr': '80fd1252', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Dear President Obama and the Department of Labor,

I am a worker writing to urge the Department of Labor to implement new rules (RIN 1235-AA05) to protect live-in domestic workers and narrow the “companionship exemption,” which currently excludes nearly two million home care workers from federal minimum wage and overtime protections. Live-in domestic workers and home care workers are unfairly denied the same baseline wage and hour protections that most other workers in our society can depend on.

The revised rule should: (1) ensure that workers employed by home care agencies or other intermediaries are not exempt; and (2) narrow the definition of “companionship” to cover only fellowship and protection, thereby excluding workers who assist clients with activities of daily living (ADLs) or instrumental activities of daily living (IADLs)


The revised rule should also require employers of live-in workers to keep records of hours worked, rate of pay, and deductions from wages for meals and housing.


Home care workers and live-in domestic workers deserve full labor protections; our families, our clients, and the industry as a whole will also benefit from this much-need reform.

I also support the proposed rule to require employers of live-in domestic workers to keep records of their workers’ hours worked. Deductions for meals and housing are common for live-in workers, and without keeping these records, it is easy to make errors in calculating the worker’s wages. Employers can easily keep track of these records using computers or smartphones. I hope you will move this proposal forward!

comment: I am writing in support of the Department of Labor’s proposed rule that would narrow the current exemption of home care workers from the minimum wage and overtime protections under the Fair Labor Standards Act. The proposed regulations will help to stabilize the home care workforce that is experiencing high turnover because of low pay and long hours. These workers help elders and people with disabilities stay in their homes and out of institutions and these protections will result in less attrition and better quality care. I also support the proposed rule to require employers of live-in domestic workers to keep records of their workers’ hours worked. But it is important for the employers to keep other records like the rate of pay, total wages paid, or deductions for meals and housing. Deductions for meals and housing are common for live-in workers, and without keeping these records, it is easy to make errors in calculating the worker’s wages. Employers can easily keep track of these records using computers or smartphones. I hope you will move this proposal forward!

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006480fb2898', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'APHIS-2011-0130-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'APHIS', 'city': 'Albuquerque', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Eucalyptus trees are not native to the U.S. and their introduction has damaged native ecosystems, to the point that California and Florida deem them "invasive pests".

So how crazy is it to engineer such a tree with a cold tolerance trait, so it can take over even more of America?.

ArborGen's petition should be rejected and all of their GE eucalyptus field trials should removed before it's too late.

Court decisions on genetically engineered perennial organisms including GE bentgrass and GE alfalfa, demonstrate a growing legal foundation around the potential escape of perennial GE organisms, even in field trials.

In addition, the U.S. Forest Service has stated that plantings of eucalyptus lower water tables, and affect groundwater recharge and local stream flows, in some cases eliminating seasonal streams. This is of particular concern in light of drought conditions in parts of the South. They state, "[eucalyptus] water use is at least 2-fold greater than most other native forests in the southeastern US."

In dry regions or areas where droughts occur, eucalyptus are at high risk of catching fire. Wildfires in Oakland California in 1991 and in Australia in 2009, both fueled by eucalyptus trees, killed scores of people and caused billions in losses.

The fatal fungal pathogen, Crytococcus Gattii has been found in the U.S. It can cause fatal fungal meningitis among people and animals that inhale its spores. One of the eucalyptus species used in the GE eucalyptus hybrids (E. Grandis) is a known host for Cryptococcus Gattii. Creating extensive habitat for this fatal fungal pathogen is shocking and foolhardy.

Please consider all these points and do the right thing by protecting America and Americans from these destructive trees.



', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'APHIS-2011-0130', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Erin', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006480fd1e56', 'lastName': 'Harris', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2012-03-08T20:10:22Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2012-03-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-03-08T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'NM', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Comment from Erin Harris', 'trackingNbr': '80fd1e56', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Eucalyptus trees are not native to the U.S. and their introduction has damaged native ecosystems, to the point that California and Florida deem them "invasive pests".

So how crazy is it to engineer such a tree with a cold tolerance trait, so it can take over even more of America?.

ArborGen's petition should be rejected and all of their GE eucalyptus field trials should removed before it's too late.

Court decisions on genetically engineered perennial organisms including GE bentgrass and GE alfalfa, demonstrate a growing legal foundation around the potential escape of perennial GE organisms, even in field trials.

In addition, the U.S. Forest Service has stated that plantings of eucalyptus lower water tables, and affect groundwater recharge and local stream flows, in some cases eliminating seasonal streams. This is of particular concern in light of drought conditions in parts of the South. They state, "[eucalyptus] water use is at least 2-fold greater than most other native forests in the southeastern US."

In dry regions or areas where droughts occur, eucalyptus are at high risk of catching fire. Wildfires in Oakland California in 1991 and in Australia in 2009, both fueled by eucalyptus trees, killed scores of people and caused billions in losses.

The fatal fungal pathogen, Crytococcus Gattii has been found in the U.S. It can cause fatal fungal meningitis among people and animals that inhale its spores. One of the eucalyptus species used in the GE eucalyptus hybrids (E. Grandis) is a known host for Cryptococcus Gattii. Creating extensive habitat for this fatal fungal pathogen is shocking and foolhardy.

Please consider all these points and do the right thing by protecting America and Americans from these destructive trees.

', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'APHIS-2011-0130', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Hollis', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006480fd1e37', 'lastName': 'Watkins', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2012-03-08T20:07:29Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2012-03-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-03-08T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'MS', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Comment from Hollis Watkins', 'trackingNbr': '80fd1e37', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Eucalyptus trees are introduced organisms in the U.S. and are documented as invasive pests in California and Florida. The cold tolerance trait could vastly expand the range of this GE eucalyptus tree–and hence enhance its ability to invade native ecosystems. Experience in California and other parts of the world has clearly demonstrated that when eucalyptus escape, it is next to impossible to eradicate them.

Court decisions on genetically engineered perennial organisms including GE bentgrass and GE alfalfa, demonstrate a growing legal foundation around the potential escape of perennial GE organisms, even in field trials.

In addition, the U.S. Forest Service has stated that plantings of eucalyptus lower water tables, and affect groundwater recharge and local stream flows, in some cases eliminating seasonal streams. This is of particular concern in light of existing drought conditions in parts of the South. They state, “[eucalyptus] water use is at least 2-fold greater than most other native forests in the southeastern US.”

In dry regions or areas where droughts occur, eucalyptus are at high risk of catching fire. Wildfires in Oakland California in 1991 and in Australia in 2009, both fueled by eucalyptus trees, killed scores of people and caused billions in losses.

The fatal fungal pathogen, Crytococcus Gattii has been found in the U.S. It can cause fatal fungal meningitis among people and animals that inhale its spores. One of the eucalyptus species used in the GE eucalyptus hybrids (E. Grandis) is a known host for Cryptococcus Gattii. Creating extensive habitat for this fatal fungal pathogen is dangerous and foolhardy.

ArborGen’s petition must be rejected and all of their GE eucalyptus field trials removed before it is too late.
