THAT IS NOT RIGHT, and I therefore strongly OPPOSE the rolling back of TitleIX protections. Trying to enforce a nondiscriminatory policy makes NO SENSE when sexual assaults are clearly done more by men than women.

Potential attackers will, of course, realize the standards of proof would be lower, and it would therefore make schools LESS SAFE.

Rolling back protections makes no sense. NO to this! It's beyond absurd.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'ED-2018-OCR-0064', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Anonymous', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006483a807cd', 'lastName': 'Anonymous', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2019-02-23T17:38:31Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2019-02-23T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2019-02-15T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2018-25314', 'trackingNbr': '1k3-98a3-qxay', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Betsy DeVos proposed changes to Title IX enforcement would make it harder for sexual assault survivors to come forward, strip them of Title IX protection, & raise the standard of proof required.

THAT IS NOT RIGHT, and I therefore strongly OPPOSE the rolling back of TitleIX protections. Trying to enforce a nondiscriminatory policy makes NO SENSE when sexual assaults are clearly done more by men than women.

Potential attackers will, of course, realize the standards of proof would be lower, and it would therefore make schools LESS SAFE.

Rolling back protections makes no sense. NO to this! It's beyond absurd.

attributes: {'commentOn': '090000648390c193', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'ED-2018-OCR-0064-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'ED', 'city': None, 'category': 'Civil Rights', 'comment': 'Truly, I am disappointed in the words of this proposal. As a woman, I feel that this is a giant leap backwards towards feeling safer in today's society. A giant leap backwards from survivors finally being heard and acknowledged. A giant leap backwards from moving towards a system that doesn't women feel guilty for the horrible things that happen to them. A leap backwards from believing women. This is sickening, and there is absolutely no reason that these changes need to be done to Title IX. This is the exact opposite of what is needed to help women succeed in society. I don't know what to say to change anyone's minds, as my voice feel powerless in a society where the president has openly been sexist, racist and homophobic. I shouldn't have worry about the future that my potential daughter(s) will face, when there are so many ways that the government can help protect and believe women in society. I urge you, women of Congress, and at this point in society men of Congress, to take a step back and think about what kind of a society you would want to live in and would want your daughters, mothers, sisters, and friends to live in. I'm tired of feeling unheard, and I'm tired of fighting for rights that I as a women should inherently have. I am equal to men in all things other than the law.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'ED-2018-OCR-0064', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Anonymous', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006483a807fc', 'lastName': 'Anonymous', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2019-02-23T17:35:32Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2019-02-23T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2019-02-15T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2018-25314', 'trackingNbr': '1k3-98a3-yp00', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: Truly, I am disappointed in the words of this proposal. As a woman, I feel that this is a giant leap backwards towards feeling safer in today's society. A giant leap backwards from survivors finally being heard and acknowledged. A giant leap backwards from moving towards a system that doesn't women feel guilty for the horrible things that happen to them. A leap backwards from believing women. This is sickening, and there is absolutely no reason that these changes need to be done to Title IX. This is the exact opposite of what is needed to help women succeed in society. I don't know what to say to change anyone's minds, as my voice feel powerless in a society where the president has openly been sexist, racist and homophobic. I shouldn't have worry about the future that my potential daughter(s) will face, when there are so many ways that the government can help protect and believe women in society. I urge you, women of Congress, and at this point in society men of Congress, to take a step back and think about what kind of a society you would want to live in and would want your daughters, mothers, sisters, and friends to live in. I'm tired of feeling unheard, and I'm tired of fighting for rights that I as a women should inherently have. I am equal to men in all things other than the law.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064846bf686', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EEOC-2020-0005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EEOC', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Chair Dhillon,

I am writing to request that you with withdraw this proposed discriminatory and anti-union regulation.

The proposed regulation undermines EEOCs mission to enforce laws that prevent discrimination in the workplace by deterring federal workers from coming forward and impeding their rights to representation. Reopening the comment period when the vast majority of the thousands of comments already received oppose this arbitrary and illegal rule also raises grave doubts about the EEOCs motive for reopening the comment period.

It is also exactly the wrong time for EEOC to diminish the ability to pursue discrimination complaints when our nation is facing the stark reality of racial injustice. Likewise, it is bad policy in the #MeToo era to hinder workers from exposing harassment. EEOC should focus on robust enforcement that strengthens civil rights rather than weakening rules to make it harder for victims of discrimination to get help.

The harmful impact of the proposed rule still includes:

Deterring federal employees from reporting discrimination.

Unfairly limiting the choice of representative, because federal workers need representation on duty time, which is when the complaint process takes place.

Singling out union representatives as the only federal employees who cannot use official time to assist in an EEO complaint.

Creating an enormous cost obstacle for federal workers, who without union representation in the EEO process, may face paying an attorney or abandoning their claim.

Attacking official time to unjustly prohibit unions from representing their bargaining units.

EEOC should hold a public meeting for transparency and to allow stakeholders to have a voice.

Sincerely,

Marsha Smith
adk.marsha@gmail.com
15 Bridle Lane
Dryden, New York 13053', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'EEOC-2020-0005', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Anonymous', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '090000648476263b', 'lastName': 'Anonymous', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2020-07-19T16:33:50Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 1, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2020-07-19T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2020-07-15T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'EEOC-2020-0005-0001 ', 'trackingNbr': '1k4-9htg-q1s8', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}

Chair Dhillon,

I am writing to request that you with withdraw this proposed discriminatory and anti-union regulation.

The proposed regulation undermines EEOCs mission to enforce laws that prevent discrimination in the workplace by deterring federal workers from coming forward and impeding their rights to representation. Reopening the comment period when the vast majority of the thousands of comments already received oppose this arbitrary and illegal rule also raises grave doubts about the EEOCs motive for reopening the comment period.

It is also exactly the wrong time for EEOC to diminish the ability to pursue discrimination complaints when our nation is facing the stark reality of racial injustice. Likewise, it is bad policy in the #MeToo era to hinder workers from exposing harassment. EEOC should focus on robust enforcement that strengthens civil rights rather than weakening rules to make it harder for victims of discrimination to get help.

The harmful impact of the proposed rule still includes:

Deterring federal employees from reporting discrimination.

Unfairly limiting the choice of representative, because federal workers need representation on duty time, which is when the complaint process takes place.

Singling out union representatives as the only federal employees who cannot use official time to assist in an EEO complaint.

Creating an enormous cost obstacle for federal workers, who without union representation in the EEO process, may face paying an attorney or abandoning their claim.

Attacking official time to unjustly prohibit unions from representing their bargaining units.

EEOC should hold a public meeting for transparency and to allow stakeholders to have a voice.

Sincerely,

Marsha Smith
adk.marsha@gmail.com
15 Bridle Lane
Dryden, New York 13053

comment:
Chair Dhillon,

I am writing to request that you with withdraw this proposed discriminatory and anti-union regulation.

The proposed regulation undermines EEOCs mission to enforce laws that prevent discrimination in the workplace by deterring federal workers from coming forward and impeding their rights to representation. Reopening the comment period when the vast majority of the thousands of comments already received oppose this arbitrary and illegal rule also raises grave doubts about the EEOCs motive for reopening the comment period.

It is also exactly the wrong time for EEOC to diminish the ability to pursue discrimination complaints when our nation is facing the stark reality of racial injustice. Likewise, it is bad policy in the #MeToo era to hinder workers from exposing harassment. EEOC should focus on robust enforcement that strengthens civil rights rather than weakening rules to make it harder for victims of discrimination to get help.

The harmful impact of the proposed rule still includes:

Deterring federal employees from reporting discrimination.

Unfairly limiting the choice of representative, because federal workers need representation on duty time, which is when the complaint process takes place.

Singling out union representatives as the only federal employees who cannot use official time to assist in an EEO complaint.

Creating an enormous cost obstacle for federal workers, who without union representation in the EEO process, may face paying an attorney or abandoning their claim.

Attacking official time to unjustly prohibit unions from representing their bargaining units.

EEOC should hold a public meeting for transparency and to allow stakeholders to have a voice.

Sincerely,

Robert Brown
rob1965@embarqmail.com

Angier, North Carolina 27501

Likewise, it is bad policy in the #MeToo era to hinder workers from exposing harassment. EEOC should focus on robust enforcement that strengthens civil rights rather than weakening rules to make it harder for victims of discrimination to get help.

The harmful impact of the proposed rule still includes:

Deterring federal employees from reporting discrimination.

Unfairly limiting the choice of representative, because federal workers need representation on duty time, which is when the complaint process takes place.

Singling out union representatives as the only federal employees who cannot use official time to assist in an EEO complaint.

Creating an enormous cost obstacle for federal workers, who without union representation in the EEO process, may face paying an attorney or abandoning their claim.

Attacking official time to unjustly prohibit unions from representing their bargaining units.

EEOC should hold a public meeting for transparency and to allow stakeholders to have a voice.

Sincerely,

Doug Landau
popcomics@gmail.com
150 73rd St S
Saint Petersburg, Florida 33707

EEOC should focus on robust enforcement that strengthens civil rights rather than weakening rules to make it harder for victims of discrimination to get help.

The harmful impact of the proposed rule still includes:

Deterring federal employees from reporting discrimination.

Unfairly limiting the choice of representative, because federal workers need representation on duty time, which is when the complaint process takes place.

Singling out union representatives as the only federal employees who cannot use official time to assist in an EEO complaint.

Creating an enormous cost obstacle for federal workers, who without union representation in the EEO process, may face paying an attorney or abandoning their claim.

Attacking official time to unjustly prohibit unions from representing their bargaining units.

EEOC should hold a public meeting for transparency and to allow stakeholders to have a voice.

Sincerely,

Jennifer Porter
jennifernicholeporter@gmail.com
PO box 661
Bar Mills, Maine 04004

Chair Dhillon,

I am writing to request that you with withdraw this proposed discriminatory and anti-union regulation.

The proposed regulation undermines EEOCs mission to enforce laws that prevent discrimination in the workplace by deterring federal workers from coming forward and impeding their rights to representation. Reopening the comment period when the vast majority of the thousands of comments already received oppose this arbitrary and illegal rule also raises grave doubts about the EEOCs motive for reopening the comment period.

It is also exactly the wrong time for EEOC to diminish the ability to pursue discrimination complaints when our nation is facing the stark reality of racial injustice. Likewise, it is bad policy in the #MeToo era to hinder workers from exposing harassment. EEOC should focus on robust enforcement that strengthens civil rights rather than weakening rules to make it harder for victims of discrimination to get help.

The harmful impact of the proposed rule still includes:

Deterring federal employees from reporting discrimination.

Unfairly limiting the choice of representative, because federal workers need representation on duty time, which is when the complaint process takes place.

Singling out union representatives as the only federal employees who cannot use official time to assist in an EEO complaint.

Creating an enormous cost obstacle for federal workers, who without union representation in the EEO process, may face paying an attorney or abandoning their claim.

EEOC should hold a public meeting for transparency and to allow stakeholders to have a voice.

Sincerely,

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802c9e88', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCG-2007-27656-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCG', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': '(1)I am the owner-operator of a 44' sailing vessel. I have lived aboard the vessel continuously since 1989
(2)My primary sources for obtaining marine weather forecasts are USCG HF radio broadcasts and, when I am in an area where it is available shoreside, NOAA internet site information.
(3) I use Coast Guard HF radio voice broadcasts to receive marine weather forecasts daily, year round. During hurricane season I listen twice daily or more often if a storm is active or forming in my area. These broadcasts are critical to our safety and operation as they provide information on expected storm conditions not readily available from other sources listed in my response to Question 2.
(4) I use Coast Guard HF radiofax broadcasts to receive marine weather forecasts daily year round and twice daily when under way or during hurricane season. The information is critical to my ability to plan operations, and thus our safety. Like the voice broadcasts in (3) above, it is available no matter where my vessel may be located.
(5) Due to its limited range, I rarely use Coast Guard HF radio Simplex Teletype over Radio (SITOR) (also known as Narrow Band Direct printing (NBDP)) to receive marine weather forecasts. It is very convenient, and I would use it more often if it were reliably available.
(6) Other than unreliable and time consuming amatuer sources on HF radio, I know of no other cost effective alternative sources for obtaining marine weather forecasts. Onboard internet service is available via satellite phone hookups, but the costs are prohibitive. It is my understanding that the Navy is even discontinuing this service on certain contract ships due to cost considerations. The Coast Guard HF broadcasts are vastly superior.
(7) The loss of Coast Guard HF marine weather broadcasts would have a devastating effect on my ability to safely operate my vessel in the Caribbean during hurricane season. The information provided in these broadcasts is critical and generally unavailable from any other source in the remote areas where we operate.
(8) We primarily operate offshore in the Caribbean, but we spend most of our time anchored in remote areas far from internet connections.

Thompson', 'trackingNbr': '802c9f60', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
(1)I am the owner-operator of a 44' sailing vessel. I have lived aboard the vessel continuously since 1989
(2)My primary sources for obtaining marine weather forecasts are USCG HF radio broadcasts and, when I am in an area where it is available shoreside, NOAA internet site information.
(3) I use Coast Guard HF radio voice broadcasts to receive marine weather forecasts daily, year round. During hurricane season I listen twice daily or more often if a storm is active or forming in my area. These broadcasts are critical to our safety and operation as they provide information on expected storm conditions not readily available from other sources listed in my response to Question 2.
(4) I use Coast Guard HF radiofax broadcasts to receive marine weather forecasts daily year round and twice daily when under way or during hurricane season. The information is critical to my ability to plan operations, and thus our safety. Like the voice broadcasts in (3) above, it is available no matter where my vessel may be located.
(5) Due to its limited range, I rarely use Coast Guard HF radio Simplex Teletype over Radio (SITOR) (also known as Narrow Band Direct printing (NBDP)) to receive marine weather forecasts. It is very convenient, and I would use it more often if it were reliably available.
(6) Other than unreliable and time consuming amatuer sources on HF radio, I know of no other cost effective alternative sources for obtaining marine weather forecasts. Onboard internet service is available via satellite phone hookups, but the costs are prohibitive. It is my understanding that the Navy is even discontinuing this service on certain contract ships due to cost considerations. The Coast Guard HF broadcasts are vastly superior.
(7) The loss of Coast Guard HF marine weather broadcasts would have a devastating effect on my ability to safely operate my vessel in the Caribbean during hurricane season. The information provided in these broadcasts is critical and generally unavailable from any other source in the remote areas where we operate.
(8) We primarily operate offshore in the Caribbean, but we spend most of our time anchored in remote areas far from internet connections.

{'commentOn': '09000064802139f6', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OPP-2006-0955-0323', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'I commend the EPA for their initiative in controlling hazardous materials
and urge you to consider and implement more specific measures:

- Please restrict second generation rat poisons to indoor use only.
- Restrict baiting of burrows to pellet or meal baits.
- Labels should direct exterminators to avoid blocking or caving-in burrow
entrances after poison deployment.
- Use only block baits in bait stations.
- Bait stations should be required to display clear POISON warning labels.
- Labeling should require that sites be carefully monitored for several days
to make sure that poison has not been exposed.
- Please incorporate bittering agents that will deter squirrels, birds, and
other forms of wildlife.
- Please advocate IPM methods on labels.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
Melissa Varjian
28 Pine Drive
Cedar Grove, NJ 07009

Varjian', 'trackingNbr': '8023f0f8', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I commend the EPA for their initiative in controlling hazardous materials
and urge you to consider and implement more specific measures:

- Please restrict second generation rat poisons to indoor use only.
- Restrict baiting of burrows to pellet or meal baits.
- Labels should direct exterminators to avoid blocking or caving-in burrow
entrances after poison deployment.
- Use only block baits in bait stations.
- Bait stations should be required to display clear POISON warning labels.
- Labeling should require that sites be carefully monitored for several days
to make sure that poison has not been exposed.
- Please incorporate bittering agents that will deter squirrels, birds, and
other forms of wildlife.
- Please advocate IPM methods on labels.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
Melissa Varjian
28 Pine Drive
Cedar Grove, NJ 07009

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802139f6', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OPP-2006-0955-0323', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': '
Jo-Anne Romanowski
1424 Carol Court
Palatine, IL 60074

Re: Proposed Risk Mitigation Decision for Nine Rodenticides
Docket Number EPA-HQ-OPP-2006-0955

Dear Environmental Protection Agency,

I am opposed about the direction being considered by the EPA for the risk
associated with use of rodenticide products. One of the reasons we have effective
Rodent control is because we do in fact have control for making a choice on how
to treat. Take that away from the public and we will see a significant change in
the current public health. Keeping in mind housing with landlords not complying
to the needs of their tenants due to excessive costs to control a large unchecked
infestation which will ultimately occur.

I have on occasion purchased one of these products in the past and have seen my
problem disappear. Thankfully I was able to keep a small problem in check. They
are a safe and convenient way to prevent serious conditions down the road for
your home and other homes in your area.

My request is that you not to adopt this proposal for our safety in the future.

Sincerely,
Jo-Anne Romanowski

{'commentOn': '09000064802c9e88', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCG-2007-27656-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCG', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'I am the Captain of a 145' Safety Standby Vessel supporting offshore oil platforms in waters of Trinidad and Tobago West Indies. There is only one other vessel in the fleet equipped with the equipment to recieve MF/HF broadcasts and we pass this information onto the other vessels in the surrounding area upon request and also to the platforms which we provide SAFETY STANDBY coverage for. The weather information is vital in planning day to day activities and for planning future works.
With the hurricane season approaching it is even more important to have this information available and would be a severe hindrance to the SAFETY of our operations if it was discontinued.

comment:
I am the Captain of a 145' Safety Standby Vessel supporting offshore oil platforms in waters of Trinidad and Tobago West Indies. There is only one other vessel in the fleet equipped with the equipment to recieve MF/HF broadcasts and we pass this information onto the other vessels in the surrounding area upon request and also to the platforms which we provide SAFETY STANDBY coverage for. The weather information is vital in planning day to day activities and for planning future works.
With the hurricane season approaching it is even more important to have this information available and would be a severe hindrance to the SAFETY of our operations if it was discontinued.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802bf9ba', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2005-21829-0009', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': 'Mateyko Aviation Group', 'address2': '18148 East Weaver Drive', 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Centennial', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Re: parachute inspection intervals (6 month):
Dear Sir(s);
As the owner and operator of a warbird, I religiously hvae my Butler seat parachutes inspected every 120 days. It has been my experince that the chutes, containers and accompanying assemblies are consistently found in servicable condition. Given modern material (nylon, synthetic fabrics, etc) the integrity of the equipment remains in tact longer that previous materials. With that said, I firmly believe inspection of the parachutes on a six (6) month interval would provide adequate and safe time periods whereby a qualified parachute rigger could detect unairworthy components. Thank you for your consideration.

Respectfully,

Greg Mateyko
', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FAA-2005-21829', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Gregory', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802bf900', 'lastName': 'Mateyko', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-05T02:37:18Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-05-23T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2007-05-23T04:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-05-23T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'CO', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Gregory A. Mateyko', 'trackingNbr': '802bf900', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '80016', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Re: parachute inspection intervals (6 month):
Dear Sir(s);
As the owner and operator of a warbird, I religiously hvae my Butler seat parachutes inspected every 120 days. It has been my experince that the chutes, containers and accompanying assemblies are consistently found in servicable condition. Given modern material (nylon, synthetic fabrics, etc) the integrity of the equipment remains in tact longer that previous materials. With that said, I firmly believe inspection of the parachutes on a six (6) month interval would provide adequate and safe time periods whereby a qualified parachute rigger could detect unairworthy components. Thank you for your consideration.

Respectfully,

Greg Mateyko

you to consider and implement more specific measures:

- Restrict baiting of burrows to pellet or meal baits.

entrances after poison deployment.
- Use only block baits in bait stations.
- Bait stations should be required to display clear POISON warning labels.
- Labeling should require that sites be carefully monitored for several days to
make sure that poison has not been exposed.

forms of wildlife.

{'commentOn': '09000064802139f6', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OPP-2006-0955-0323', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': "RE: Rodenticides; Proposed Risk Mitigation Decision on Nine Rodenticides
EPA-HQ-OPP-2006-0955

I.
The purpose of this Comment is to bring to the attention of the Environmental
Protection Agency (EPA) an incident involving the use of second generation
anticoagulant rodenticide in the Japanese Tea Garden, Golden Gate Park, San
Francisco, California. The presence of a bait box in the Tea Garden during
August of 2006 was officially verified through e-mail communication with Chris
Geiger, Ph.D., Integrated Pest Management, San Francisco Department of the
Environment. The type of poison used was identified as being difethialone in
the form of Generation Blox. E-mail from Chris Geiger, Integrated Pest
Management, San Francisco Department of the Environment, to Lydia
Peirce-Dougherty, SFEnvironment Website Email(Mar. 16, 2007). The incident
described below illustrates the need for second generation anticoagulant risk
mitigation, in particular, the importance of tamper-resistant bait stations.

II.
The Japanese Tea Garden is a popular tourist attraction in Golden Gate Park and
usually filled with visitors. On August 13th, 2006, a rat was discovered
sitting on a small lawn area near the front of the Tea Garden. A group of young
children quickly gathered to watch the rat walk about on the lawn, and several
children expressed a desire to touch or play with the animal. Due to the calm
nature of the rat, coat colouration, and body type, I concluded the rat was a
juvenile domestic Rattus norvegicus. Domestic Norway rats are occasionally
dumped in Golden Gate Park by negligent owners and require rescue.

When I made my first capture attempt, the rat ran behind a stand of bushes and
huddled next to a black box on the ground. I immediately asked various Tea
Garden employees for help with the rat, and specifically asked if bait boxes
were being used in the Garden. I was told there were no bait boxes in the Tea
Garden, and so assumed the black box was part of the garden infrastructure.

I followed the rat behind the stand of bushes, and discovered the black box
askew and the surrounding area covered with small yellow pellets. The word
'poison' was embossed into the plastic cover of the box, yet the writing was
impossible to read without coming into contact with the scattered pellets. The
top of the box could easily be opened without force.

I proceeded to pick up the docile rat and was promptly bitten. The rat died
from massive internal hemorrhage before medical treatment could be obtained.

The deceased rat was later determined by experts to be a female Rattus rattus,
not a juvenile domestic Rattus norvegicus. The two animals are very difficult
to distinguish, and the extreme illness of the rat made identification more
problematic due to changes in her coat texture and behavior.

III.

The EPA proposed risk mitigation for second generation anticoagulant
rodenticides includes a requirement that all above ground applications be in
tamper-resistant bait stations. Eight are criteria used to define a
tamper-resistant bait station; three of those criteria are directly relevant to
the above incident:

3. . . . capable of being locked or sealed so that children and nontarget
animals cannot gain access through the opening or procedures used to fill the
bait compartment(s);. . .

5. capable of being anchored securely to resist efforts to move the station or
to displace its contents, or equipped with a mechanism which virtually prevents
bait from being shaken out of the station after it has been moved;. . .

6. equipped with internal structures for containing baits and minimizing
spillage and tracking of bait outside of the station or into readily accessible
parts of the station;. . . Label Improvement Program for the Revision of Use
Directions for Commensal Rodenticides and Statement of the Agency's Policies on
the Use of Rodenticide Bait Stations, Pesticide Regulation (PR) Notice 94-7 (EPA
Sept. 16, 1994) [hereinafter PR Notice 94-7].

IV.

Criterion three states a bait station must be, ?capable of being locked or
sealed,? to prevent children and nontarget animals from having access to the
bait compartment. Id. The Tea Garden bait station was unlocked, with no obvious
locking or sealing mechanism to prevent the top of the bait box from being
flipped open to reveal the main bait compartment.

Criterion five states a bait station must be capable of being anchored securely
to the ground to prevent children and nontarget animals from obtaining bait by
lifting and shaking the box. Or, the bait station must be designed to prevent
bait from being shaken out if the box is moved. The Tea Garden bait box was not
anchored to the ground, and no anchoring device was visible. In addition,
pelleted bait was running freely out of the openings and onto the ground, which
indicated the lack of a safety mechanism to prevent bait from being shaken free.

Criterion six states the bait station must be designed with internal structures
to minimize, ?spillage and tracking of the bait outside of the station or into
readily accessible parts of the station.? Id. As previously stated, the Tea
Garden bait box was surrounded by yellow bait pellets spilling from each opening.

Golden Gate Park holds thirty-six of the City's one hundred bait stations that
utilize second generation anticoagulant rodenticide. Jane Kay, Groups Debate
Poison After Three Hawks Die, One Survives, San Francisco Chron. B3 (Mar. 16,
2007). When bait is permitted to cover the ground around a bait station
non-target animals, such as domestic dogs and corvids, are directly exposed to
the rodenticide. ?Most baits are grain-based and are therefore attractive to
many birds and non-target mammals; those baits with flavor enhancers (e.g. fish
flavors) might also attract carnivores.? Proposed Risk Mitigation Decision for
Nine Rodenticides 5 (EPA Jan. 17, 2007). Requiring tamper-resistant bait
stations is expected to reduce the number of non-target animals poisoned with
difethialone, including the endangered San Joaquin kit fox. Id.

In addition, nothing prevented children who were intrigued by the Tea Garden
rat from coming into contact with the difethialone pellets spilling from the
bait station.

V.

In conclusion, the application of PR Notice 94-7 criteria for tamper-resistant
bait stations would mitigate the serious hazards illustrated by the Japanese Tea
Garden bait box. Children and nontarget animals will not have access to the
bait compartment through an open flip top. An anchored bait box cannot be
transported by a child or nontarget animal, and will prevent pelleted bait from
being easily shaken out. Or, the internal structure of the bait station will
prevent spillage of the bait if the box is moved. And last, effectively
designed internal structures will also minimize spillage of pelleted bait and
the tracking of pelleted bait outside the bait station.

Photographs of the bait station and the rat, both alive and dead, are available
on request.
", 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'EPA-HQ-OPP-2006-0955', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '090000648023eef3', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2010-11-01T18:39:26Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-05-23T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-05-18T15:26:41Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Anonymous public comment', 'trackingNbr': '8023eef3', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
RE: Rodenticides; Proposed Risk Mitigation Decision on Nine Rodenticides
EPA-HQ-OPP-2006-0955

I.
The purpose of this Comment is to bring to the attention of the Environmental
Protection Agency (EPA) an incident involving the use of second generation
anticoagulant rodenticide in the Japanese Tea Garden, Golden Gate Park, San
Francisco, California. The presence of a bait box in the Tea Garden during
August of 2006 was officially verified through e-mail communication with Chris
Geiger, Ph.D., Integrated Pest Management, San Francisco Department of the
Environment. The type of poison used was identified as being difethialone in
the form of Generation Blox. E-mail from Chris Geiger, Integrated Pest
Management, San Francisco Department of the Environment, to Lydia
Peirce-Dougherty, SFEnvironment Website Email(Mar. 16, 2007). The incident
described below illustrates the need for second generation anticoagulant risk
mitigation, in particular, the importance of tamper-resistant bait stations.

II.
The Japanese Tea Garden is a popular tourist attraction in Golden Gate Park and
usually filled with visitors. On August 13th, 2006, a rat was discovered
sitting on a small lawn area near the front of the Tea Garden. A group of young
children quickly gathered to watch the rat walk about on the lawn, and several
children expressed a desire to touch or play with the animal. Due to the calm
nature of the rat, coat colouration, and body type, I concluded the rat was a
juvenile domestic Rattus norvegicus. Domestic Norway rats are occasionally
dumped in Golden Gate Park by negligent owners and require rescue.

When I made my first capture attempt, the rat ran behind a stand of bushes and
huddled next to a black box on the ground. I immediately asked various Tea
Garden employees for help with the rat, and specifically asked if bait boxes
were being used in the Garden. I was told there were no bait boxes in the Tea
Garden, and so assumed the black box was part of the garden infrastructure.

I followed the rat behind the stand of bushes, and discovered the black box
askew and the surrounding area covered with small yellow pellets. The word
'poison' was embossed into the plastic cover of the box, yet the writing was
impossible to read without coming into contact with the scattered pellets. The
top of the box could easily be opened without force.

I proceeded to pick up the docile rat and was promptly bitten. The rat died
from massive internal hemorrhage before medical treatment could be obtained.

The deceased rat was later determined by experts to be a female Rattus rattus,
not a juvenile domestic Rattus norvegicus. The two animals are very difficult
to distinguish, and the extreme illness of the rat made identification more
problematic due to changes in her coat texture and behavior.

III.

The EPA proposed risk mitigation for second generation anticoagulant
rodenticides includes a requirement that all above ground applications be in
tamper-resistant bait stations. Eight are criteria used to define a
tamper-resistant bait station; three of those criteria are directly relevant to
the above incident:

3. . . . capable of being locked or sealed so that children and nontarget
animals cannot gain access through the opening or procedures used to fill the
bait compartment(s);. . .

5. capable of being anchored securely to resist efforts to move the station or
to displace its contents, or equipped with a mechanism which virtually prevents
bait from being shaken out of the station after it has been moved;. . .

6. equipped with internal structures for containing baits and minimizing
spillage and tracking of bait outside of the station or into readily accessible
parts of the station;. . . Label Improvement Program for the Revision of Use
Directions for Commensal Rodenticides and Statement of the Agency's Policies on
the Use of Rodenticide Bait Stations, Pesticide Regulation (PR) Notice 94-7 (EPA
Sept. 16, 1994) [hereinafter PR Notice 94-7].

IV.

Criterion three states a bait station must be, ?capable of being locked or
sealed,? to prevent children and nontarget animals from having access to the
bait compartment. Id. The Tea Garden bait station was unlocked, with no obvious
locking or sealing mechanism to prevent the top of the bait box from being
flipped open to reveal the main bait compartment.

Criterion five states a bait station must be capable of being anchored securely
to the ground to prevent children and nontarget animals from obtaining bait by
lifting and shaking the box. Or, the bait station must be designed to prevent
bait from being shaken out if the box is moved. The Tea Garden bait box was not
anchored to the ground, and no anchoring device was visible. In addition,
pelleted bait was running freely out of the openings and onto the ground, which
indicated the lack of a safety mechanism to prevent bait from being shaken free.

Criterion six states the bait station must be designed with internal structures
to minimize, ?spillage and tracking of the bait outside of the station or into
readily accessible parts of the station.? Id. As previously stated, the Tea
Garden bait box was surrounded by yellow bait pellets spilling from each opening.

Golden Gate Park holds thirty-six of the City's one hundred bait stations that
utilize second generation anticoagulant rodenticide. Jane Kay, Groups Debate
Poison After Three Hawks Die, One Survives, San Francisco Chron. B3 (Mar. 16,
2007). When bait is permitted to cover the ground around a bait station
non-target animals, such as domestic dogs and corvids, are directly exposed to
the rodenticide. ?Most baits are grain-based and are therefore attractive to
many birds and non-target mammals; those baits with flavor enhancers (e.g. fish
flavors) might also attract carnivores.? Proposed Risk Mitigation Decision for
Nine Rodenticides 5 (EPA Jan. 17, 2007). Requiring tamper-resistant bait
stations is expected to reduce the number of non-target animals poisoned with
difethialone, including the endangered San Joaquin kit fox. Id.

In addition, nothing prevented children who were intrigued by the Tea Garden
rat from coming into contact with the difethialone pellets spilling from the
bait station.

V.

In conclusion, the application of PR Notice 94-7 criteria for tamper-resistant
bait stations would mitigate the serious hazards illustrated by the Japanese Tea
Garden bait box. Children and nontarget animals will not have access to the
bait compartment through an open flip top. An anchored bait box cannot be
transported by a child or nontarget animal, and will prevent pelleted bait from
being easily shaken out. Or, the internal structure of the bait station will
prevent spillage of the bait if the box is moved. And last, effectively
designed internal structures will also minimize spillage of pelleted bait and
the tracking of pelleted bait outside the bait station.

Photographs of the bait station and the rat, both alive and dead, are available
on request.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802139f6', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OPP-2006-0955-0323', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'I am pleased to see that you are considering changes in the use of rodenticides.
The unwise use of these can be very detrimental to our children, pets, and wildlife;
if they have access to the bait, the results can be serious illness, or even fatal. In
poisioning rats, the bait is often easily accessable to squirrels, etc, who are much
desired visitors to our parks. Most rodents are at the bottom of the food chain, and
a poisioned rat that is caught by a hawk or fox or pet dog or other predator will, in
turn, cause their death also. While I realize that the rat problem must be
addressed, it must be done safely, with a broad overview of the possible problems
that could arise. I think that better labeling, and restrictions on who can use them
as well as the locations where they can be used would at least be a start for
solving the problem. I also think that public awareness should be addressed - the
fact that leaving food and water in accessable locations provides a 'club med' for
rats and mice. Throwing unwanted food in a streetside trash container, and the
leftover food from restaurants in a trash bin outside is an open invitation to pests. I
hope you can address the problem successfully.
', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'EPA-HQ-OPP-2006-0955', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '090000648023f090', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2010-11-01T18:39:27Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-05-23T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-05-18T17:09:40Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Anonymous public comment', 'trackingNbr': '8023f090', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I am pleased to see that you are considering changes in the use of rodenticides.
The unwise use of these can be very detrimental to our children, pets, and wildlife;
if they have access to the bait, the results can be serious illness, or even fatal. In
poisioning rats, the bait is often easily accessable to squirrels, etc, who are much
desired visitors to our parks. Most rodents are at the bottom of the food chain, and
a poisioned rat that is caught by a hawk or fox or pet dog or other predator will, in
turn, cause their death also. While I realize that the rat problem must be
addressed, it must be done safely, with a broad overview of the possible problems
that could arise. I think that better labeling, and restrictions on who can use them
as well as the locations where they can be used would at least be a start for
solving the problem. I also think that public awareness should be addressed - the
fact that leaving food and water in accessable locations provides a 'club med' for
rats and mice. Throwing unwanted food in a streetside trash container, and the
leftover food from restaurants in a trash bin outside is an open invitation to pests. I
hope you can address the problem successfully.

{'commentOn': '09000064802139f6', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OPP-2006-0955-0323', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'I am a "pocket pet" owner (domesticated "fancy rat").

I am also in the indoor environment business (clean air, purified water.)

Eliminating toxins in both our indoor and outdoor environments is key to health for
all of us, most importantly our children and small pets, including rodents.

"These poisons pose serious risks to wildlife, children, and companion animals."
Thank you for banning them.
Michele Jones, Tucson, Arizona
', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'EPA-HQ-OPP-2006-0955', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '090000648023f00a', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2010-11-01T18:39:27Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-05-23T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-05-18T16:29:11Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Comment submitted by M. comment:
I am a "pocket pet" owner (domesticated "fancy rat").

I am also in the indoor environment business (clean air, purified water.)

Eliminating toxins in both our indoor and outdoor environments is key to health for
all of us, most importantly our children and small pets, including rodents.

"These poisons pose serious risks to wildlife, children, and companion animals."
Thank you for banning them.
Michele Jones, Tucson, Arizona

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648023a17a', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'HUD-2007-0065-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'HUD', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'To Whom it May Concern,
Down Payment Assistance programs from non profit organizations have helped
many deserving buyers in the last 5 years realize the dream of homeownership.
These are buyers that are able to buy a home, make their payments and help
communities thrive, but they just had no avenues for getting the needed monies to
close on a house. I feel that if these programs are taken away it is going to take
away from the promotion of home ownership for many deserving buyers. In turn
this could have a negative effect on communities that need good homeowners to
help them thrive.

Thank you.
', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'HUD-2007-0065', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '090000648024062d', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2007-05-23T20:37:28Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-05-23T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-05-21T17:00:14Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment Submitted by Michael Wilson, US Bank', 'trackingNbr': '8024062d', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
To Whom it May Concern,
Down Payment Assistance programs from non profit organizations have helped
many deserving buyers in the last 5 years realize the dream of homeownership.
These are buyers that are able to buy a home, make their payments and help
communities thrive, but they just had no avenues for getting the needed monies to
close on a house. I feel that if these programs are taken away it is going to take
away from the promotion of home ownership for many deserving buyers. In turn
this could have a negative effect on communities that need good homeowners to
help them thrive.

Thank you.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064801ff600', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OAR-2006-0173-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'As a concerned citizen I urge the EPA to approve the requested waiver of
preemption for the group of states led by California on greenhouse gas emissions.
I am worried by the slow pace of federal regulation in the face of rapidly increasing
carbon dioxide emissions from motor vehicles. California has the ability to "test
drive" a set of moderate limits on greenhouse gas emissions without commiting
the rest of the country to a formal change in regulations. This is an opportunity for
change that cannot be passed up, and without it we will be no closer to
decreasing, or even reducing the increase of greenhouse gas emissions from
motor vehicles.

The United States was founded as a nation under God, and as the Lord's stewards
of this land it is our duty to ensure we protect and presereve it for His glory and our
future generations. Reducing the greenhouse gas emissions generated by our
vehicles will strengthen our nation and protect our children from future climate
catastrophe. I urge the EPA to take the important step of allowing California to go
forward in this noble experiment of reducing carbon emissions from the cars we all
drive.

Thank you for considering my comments.
', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'EPA-HQ-OAR-2006-0173', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802414c4', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2007-05-23T15:42:32Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 1, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-05-23T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2007-05-22T16:12:27Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-05-22T14:56:02Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Anonymous Comment ', 'trackingNbr': '802414c4', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
As a concerned citizen I urge the EPA to approve the requested waiver of
preemption for the group of states led by California on greenhouse gas emissions.
I am worried by the slow pace of federal regulation in the face of rapidly increasing
carbon dioxide emissions from motor vehicles. California has the ability to "test
drive" a set of moderate limits on greenhouse gas emissions without commiting
the rest of the country to a formal change in regulations. This is an opportunity for
change that cannot be passed up, and without it we will be no closer to
decreasing, or even reducing the increase of greenhouse gas emissions from
motor vehicles.

The United States was founded as a nation under God, and as the Lord's stewards
of this land it is our duty to ensure we protect and presereve it for His glory and our
future generations. Reducing the greenhouse gas emissions generated by our
vehicles will strengthen our nation and protect our children from future climate
catastrophe. I urge the EPA to take the important step of allowing California to go
forward in this noble experiment of reducing carbon emissions from the cars we all
drive.

Thank you for considering my comments.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006480a0c1f1', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2009-N-0247-0128', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Other Organizations - E0003', 'comment': 'Docket No. FDA-2009-N-0247
Food and Drug Administration
Comments regarding the FDA Transparency Task Force

The American Legacy Foundation (“Legacy”) appreciates the commitment of Food and Drug Administration (the “FDA”) Commissioner Hamburg and Principal Deputy Commissioner Scharfstein to transparency in the FDA’s decision making processes. Legacy urges the FDA to ensure that this commitment extends to all areas under the jurisdiction of the FDA including those newly added by the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act (the “Act”).

Please find our full comments attached.', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2009-N-0247', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006480a1070d', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-08-24T19:21:40Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2009-08-24T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2009-08-24T16:27:11Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'EREG-Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'American Legacy Foundation - Comment', 'trackingNbr': '80a1070d', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Docket No. FDA-2009-N-0247
Food and Drug Administration
Comments regarding the FDA Transparency Task Force

The American Legacy Foundation (“Legacy”) appreciates the commitment of Food and Drug Administration (the “FDA”) Commissioner Hamburg and Principal Deputy Commissioner Scharfstein to transparency in the FDA’s decision making processes. Legacy urges the FDA to ensure that this commitment extends to all areas under the jurisdiction of the FDA including those newly added by the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act (the “Act”).

Please find our full comments attached.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064809b8f1e', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2008-D-0253-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Health Care Association - D0022', 'comment': 'The Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy (AMCP) is pleased to provide comments to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) on the draft guidance for industry on “Presenting Risk Information in Prescription Drug and Medical Device Promotion.”

The Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy (AMCP) is a national professional association of pharmacists and other health care practitioners who serve society by the application of sound medication management principles and strategies to improve health care for all. The Academy's 5,700 members develop and provide a diversified range of clinical, educational and business management services and strategies on behalf of the more than 200 million Americans covered by a managed care pharmacy benefit.

The Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy (AMCP) is pleased to provide comments to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) on the draft guidance for industry on “Presenting Risk Information in Prescription Drug and Medical Device Promotion.”

The Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy (AMCP) is a national professional association of pharmacists and other health care practitioners who serve society by the application of sound medication management principles and strategies to improve health care for all. The Academy's 5,700 members develop and provide a diversified range of clinical, educational and business management services and strategies on behalf of the more than 200 million Americans covered by a managed care pharmacy benefit.

The Academy's comments appear in the attached letter.

{'commentOn': '09000064816cb41a', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2014-N-0189-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual Consumer', 'comment': 'Escaping FDA regulation by use of non-tobacco sourced nicotine – an evasion pathway the FDA needs to recognize and inhibit.

Some companies in the eCig industry would clearly prefer to escape coming FDA tobacco regulations. eCigs contain a variable amount of nicotine (from 0 to 36 mg per ml). Nicotine is the only tobacco derived constituent in most eCigs and some would argue is the only aspect of the product which enables the FDA tobacco regulations to apply. The argument goes that with use of non-tobacco sourced nicotine that the FDA Tobacco regulations would not apply. Brands have begun to advertise that they are not tobacco derived products (see attached GreenSmartLiving advertisement asserting use of non-tobacco nicotine sources).

It seems clear that the intent of Congress, when it gave the FDA authority over tobacco products in 2009, was to encompass all uses of nicotine intended for recreational (as opposed to therapeutic) use. Although use of non-tobacco nicotine is not economically feasible today, given the potential for unregulated profits, the industry could invest in a more cost effective synthesis. Common vegetables have nicotine, a chemical the plant produces as an insecticide. Tomatoes and Eggplant, for example, produce nicotine, albeit in microgram quantities rather than milligrams in tobacco leaf. As a gene exists in these plants to synthesize nicotine. With genetic manipulation it is entirely feasible that an alterative non-tobacco plant could be engineered to produce copious amounts of nicotine.

The FDA has a clear path forward to closing this potential 8 lane highway of escape from regulation. Nicotine products should have two choices: FDA tobacco or FDA drug regulation. There is no justification for a third, unregulated pathway.

Nicotine content of common vegetables. NEJM 1993; 329: 437

Robert K. Jackler, MD
Sewall Professor, Stanford University School of Medicine
Stanford Research Into the Impact of Tobacco Advertising

comment:
Escaping FDA regulation by use of non-tobacco sourced nicotine – an evasion pathway the FDA needs to recognize and inhibit.

Some companies in the eCig industry would clearly prefer to escape coming FDA tobacco regulations. eCigs contain a variable amount of nicotine (from 0 to 36 mg per ml). Nicotine is the only tobacco derived constituent in most eCigs and some would argue is the only aspect of the product which enables the FDA tobacco regulations to apply. The argument goes that with use of non-tobacco sourced nicotine that the FDA Tobacco regulations would not apply. Brands have begun to advertise that they are not tobacco derived products (see attached GreenSmartLiving advertisement asserting use of non-tobacco nicotine sources).

It seems clear that the intent of Congress, when it gave the FDA authority over tobacco products in 2009, was to encompass all uses of nicotine intended for recreational (as opposed to therapeutic) use. Although use of non-tobacco nicotine is not economically feasible today, given the potential for unregulated profits, the industry could invest in a more cost effective synthesis. Common vegetables have nicotine, a chemical the plant produces as an insecticide. Tomatoes and Eggplant, for example, produce nicotine, albeit in microgram quantities rather than milligrams in tobacco leaf. As a gene exists in these plants to synthesize nicotine. With genetic manipulation it is entirely feasible that an alterative non-tobacco plant could be engineered to produce copious amounts of nicotine.

The FDA has a clear path forward to closing this potential 8 lane highway of escape from regulation. Nicotine products should have two choices: FDA tobacco or FDA drug regulation. There is no justification for a third, unregulated pathway.

Nicotine content of common vegetables. NEJM 1993; 329: 437

Robert K. Jackler, MD
Sewall Professor, Stanford University School of Medicine
Stanford Research Into the Impact of Tobacco Advertising

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064816cb41a', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2014-N-0189-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Academia - E0007', 'comment': 'Celebrity Endorsements

Endorsement of cigarettes by movie stars, musicians, and sports heroes was banned in 1964 by the Cigarette Advertising code. (see accompanying Powerpoint) Many electronic cigarette brands use celebrity endorsers including Blu’s use of rock star Courtney Love and action movie star Steven Dorff. For the past four years, e-cigarettes have even been given out at the Oscars in their “swag bags” (Krave-2010, Blu-2011, Vapor Trim 2012, V2 and Vapor Couture -2012, and NJOY -2013). Even the image of dead celebrities have been exploited for eCig marketing purposes including Marilyn Monroe, John Lennon, James Dean, and even Benjamin Franklin. The FDA celebrity endorsement policy should align with that held for cigarettes for a half a century.

Robert K. Jackler, MD
Sewall Professor, Stanford University School of Medicine
Stanford Research Into the Impact of Tobacco Advertising

Jackler, MD Sewall Professor, Stanford University School of Medicine', 'trackingNbr': '1jy-8c4s-nlmv', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Celebrity Endorsements

Endorsement of cigarettes by movie stars, musicians, and sports heroes was banned in 1964 by the Cigarette Advertising code. (see accompanying Powerpoint) Many electronic cigarette brands use celebrity endorsers including Blu’s use of rock star Courtney Love and action movie star Steven Dorff. For the past four years, e-cigarettes have even been given out at the Oscars in their “swag bags” (Krave-2010, Blu-2011, Vapor Trim 2012, V2 and Vapor Couture -2012, and NJOY -2013). Even the image of dead celebrities have been exploited for eCig marketing purposes including Marilyn Monroe, John Lennon, James Dean, and even Benjamin Franklin. The FDA celebrity endorsement policy should align with that held for cigarettes for a half a century.

Robert K. Jackler, MD
Sewall Professor, Stanford University School of Medicine
Stanford Research Into the Impact of Tobacco Advertising

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064813a84a8', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2011-N-0921-0199', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Academia - E0007', 'comment': 'November 15, 2013

Division of Dockets Management (HFA-305)
Food and Drug Administration
5630 Fishers Lane, Rm. 1061
Rockville, MD 20582

Docket Nos. FDA-2011-N-0920 and FDA-2011-N-0921

Re: Comments on the Proposed Rule for Standards for the Growing, Harvesting, Packing, and Holding of Produce for Human Consumption and the Proposed Rule for Current Good Manufacturing Practice and Hazard Analysis and Risk-Based Preventive Controls for Human Food

The opinions expressed herein are our own and do not necessarily reflect the views of The Johns Hopkins University.

To Whom It May Concern:

The Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future (CLF) appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) proposed rule for Standards for the Growing, Harvesting, Packing, and Holding of Produce for Human Consumption (the Produce Rule) and the proposed rule for Current Good Manufacturing Practice and Hazard Analysis and Risk-Based Preventive Controls for Human Food (the Preventive Controls Rule).

The Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future is an academic and research center at the Bloomberg School of Public Health. The Center’s mission is to promote research and to develop and communicate information about the complex interrelationships among diet, food production, environment and human health, to advance an ecological perspective in reducing threats to the health of the public and to promote policies that protect health, the global environment and the ability to sustain life for future generations.

The Center has scientific, policy, and regulatory expertise in the areas of food systems and food safety, including food animal production and farming issues, as well as local and regional food systems and sustainable agriculture. Most recently, the Center issued the report, “Industrial Food Animal Production in America: Examining the Impact of the Pew Commission’s Priority Recommendations” that examined many of these issues.

There are two Center priorities with particular importance for this rulemaking – minimizing the negative public health impact of animal production facility practices and supporting local and regional food systems and sustainable food production for their public health benefits. Unfortunately, FDA’s proposed rules will hinder these critical goals, which will weaken produce safety. We are recommending in this comment that FDA take action to address these concerns.

First, FDA must issue a separate proposed rule that will explicitly cover the risks to produce safety from animal production facilities, particularly from animal manure contaminants migrating in environmental pathways and in manure sold or given to other farms for growing produce. This rulemaking is authorized by the Food Safety and Modernization Act (FSMA) and will be a more effective and equitable approach to control produce safety risks caused by animal production facilities.

Second, FDA must amend the Produce Rule and the Preventive Controls Rule to provide more flexibility for farms and businesses that are part of the local and regional food system and/or producing sustainably and that do not fit the current exemptions. Without this flexibility, many of these important farms will struggle to comply with the regulatory requirements. In this way, the current rules might unintentionally hinder farming and food production practices that are critical for public health. We support the similar comments of the American Public Health Association (APHA), the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition (NSAC) and other organizations advocating for more flexibility.

Finally, FDA must amend the Produce Rule to be consistent with current federal organic standards and impose additional conditions for allowing human waste in growing produce.

We appreciate you considering our comment (attached) and would be happy to answer any questions that you might have or assist further in these efforts.

Sincerely,

Kevin M. Fain, JD, MPH
DrPH Student
Department of Epidemiology
Bloomberg School of Public Health
Lerner Doctoral Fellow
Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future

Robert S. Lawrence, MD
The Center for a Livable Future Professor in Environmental Health Sciences and Professor
Departments of Environmental Health Sciences, Health Policy and Management, and International Health
Bloomberg School of Public Health
Director
Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future

Keeve E. Nachman, PhD, MHS
Assistant Scientist
Departments of Environmental Health Sciences and Health Policy and Management
Bloomberg School of Public Health
Program Director
Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future

Robert P. Martin
Senior Lecturer
Department of Environmental Health Sciences
Bloomberg School of Public Health
Program Director
Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future

Rebecca A. Klein, MS
Project Officer
Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future

Tyler J. S. Smith
Program Officer

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064813a84a8', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2011-N-0921-0199', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'State Government - G0012', 'comment': "Re: Standards for the Growing, Harvesting, Packing, and Holding of Produce for Human Consumption
Docket No. FDA-2011-N-0921
RIN 0910-AG35

California Department of Resources Recycling and Recovery (CalRecycle) appreciates the opportunity to comment on the proposed rule, “Standards for the Growing, Harvesting, Packing, and Holding of Produce for Human Consumption,” by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and supports the science-based standards for the safe production and harvesting of fruits and vegetables that minimize the risk of serious adverse health consequences.

CalRecycle supports the overall direction and agrees with the importance of protecting public health and safety. California has more than a decade of experience regulating composters. We offer comparisons to our current laws and regulations in the hope of standardizing terminology and building upon existing compost product standards and industry best practices. In that spirit, we would like to make the following recommendations:

This is an excerpt of our formal comment letter. Please see the letter for our additional comments.

112.54(c)(1) & 112.54(c)(2) – Requiring Curing piles to be covered
Compost pile curing is a process that occurs at lower temperatures and after the “Process to Further Reduce Pathogens” (PFRP, Title 14, CCR Section 17868.3). The curing process is not an extension of the PFRP process. Covering curing piles can prevent the pile from breathing properly, hindering the curing process. In addition, this requirement will serve as an operational hardship to composters. The insulation layer will not be removable and therefore, if a non-compost material is used (e.g. hay), the raw material will have to be certified pathogen and weed free before use, and then incorporated into the pile, which will extend the composting period. If the insulation layer is comprised of finished compost, it becomes an addition to the curing pile which is nearly indistinguishable from the composting feedstock itself, making enforcement of this rule difficult.

CalRecycle believes that PFRP should be relied upon for pathogen reduction. The curing process helps reduce other constituents of immature compost which may be harmful to plants. There are a number of reliable, commercially available tests to measure compost maturity and stability. California regulations reference both temperature and maturity. Both definitions below are from CCR, Title 14, Section 17852:
•(1) "Active Compost" means compost feedstock that is in the process of being rapidly decomposed and is unstable. Active compost is generating temperatures of at least 50 degrees Celsius (122 degrees Fahrenheit) during decomposition; or is releasing carbon dioxide at a rate of at least 15 milligrams per gram of compost per day, or the equivalent of oxygen uptake.
•(13) "Curing" means the final stage of the composting process that occurs after compost has undergone pathogen reduction, as described in section 17868.3, and after most of the readily metabolized material has been decomposed and stabilized.
California regulations require that aerated static pile composting processes insulate the active compost during the PFRP to ensure that all of the compostable material achieves proper temperatures. Windrow operators are required to turn 5 times for the same purpose, but are not required to insulate. CCR Title 14, Section 17868.3(4) states:
•If the operation or facility uses an aerated static pile composting process, all active compost shall be covered with 6 to 12 inches of insulating material, and the active compost shall be maintained at a temperature of 55 degrees Celsius (131 degrees Fahrenheit) or higher for a pathogen reduction period of 3 days.
•If the operation or facility uses a windrow composting process, active compost shall be maintained under aerobic conditions at a temperature of 55 degrees Celsius (131 degrees Fahrenheit) or higher for a pathogen reduction period of 15 days or longer. During the period when the compost is maintained at 55 degrees Celsius or higher, there shall be a minimum of five (5) turnings of the windrow.

Recommendations:
•Move the phrase ‘which includes proper insulation’ in section 112.54(c)(1) and strike the phrase ‘which includes proper insulation’ from section 112.54(c)(2)
•112.54(c)(1): Static composting that maintains aerobic (i.e., oxygenated) conditions at a minimum of 131F (55C) for 3 days which includes proper insulation and is followed by adequate curing which includes proper insulation;
•112.54(c)(2): Turned composting that maintains aerobic conditions at a minimum of 131F (55C) for 15 days, with a minimum of five turnings, and is followed by adequate curing, which includes proper insulation

Sincerely,
CalRecycle
