attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064817458e2', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'NOAA-NMFS-2013-0074-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'NOAA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': "August 7, 2014

Glenn Merrill
Assistant Regional Administrator
Sustainable Fisheries Division
Alaska Region, NMFS
P.O. Box 21668
Juneau, AK 99802-1668

Dear Mr. Merrill,

We are writing to comment on the reporting requirements for the proposed rule implementing Amendment 105 to the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands Fishery Management Plan (Amendment 105).

The Alaska Seafood Cooperative (AKSC) is a harvesting cooperative consisting of sixteen vessels and five companies. The multi species Amendment 80 sector operates under hard caps for yellowfin sole, flathead sole, rock sole, Pacific cod, Atka mackerel, and Pacific ocean perch, as well as halibut and crab. The North Pacific Fishery Management Council (Council) intended Amendment 105 to provide additional flexibility for Amendment 80 vessels harvesting yellowfin sole, rock sole, and flathead sole, which could result in more efficient use of these and other species.

We believe that proposed regulations implementing Amendment 105 will assist in maximizing flatfish harvests while maintaining statutory and regulatory harvesting limits. However, we have several comments about the reporting aspects of these regulations.

The preamble to the proposed rule and regulations at 679.20(b)(1)(iii)(A) state that the ABC reserve would be set after consultation with the Council or could be reduced if NMFS determines there is a need to set the ABC reserve below the ABC surplus. To inform ABC reserve decisions, regulations at 679.5(s)(7)(iii) describe information requirements for the Preliminary Amendment 80 Flatfish Exchange Report. This report proposed to be provided by industry. However, all of the information required on the Preliminary Amendment 80 Cooperative Flatfish Exchange Report form is available to NMFS. Requiring cooperatives to report this information is unnecessary and increases costs and reporting burden. Rather, NMFS could provide the same information to the Council at its December meeting.
Block B of the Flatfish Exchange Report requires information about quota exchanges. The headings in Block B are titled: Species Exchanged Into Cooperative Quota and Species Exchanged Out of Reserves. These headings are asking for the same information. As described in the proposed regulations, a cooperative would be exchanging CQ of one species for CQ of another species. For example, a cooperative could relinquish 1000 mt of flathead sole CQ and receive 1000 mt of yellowfin sole CQ. The cooperative would also exchange an equal amount of ABC reserve for both species. The current form confuses these two exchanges and should be corrected.
Block A of the Flatfish Exchange Application asks whether the exchange is CDQ or Amendment 80. Block B also asks for the same information in both the Species Exchanged In and Species Exchanged Out columns. This creates confusion, and suggests that a cooperative may exchange CDQ CQ for Amendment 80 CQ. We dont think this was the intention, and should be corrected. We believe its only necessary to state whether the exchange is CDQ or Amendment 80 in Block A.
The Flatfish Exchange Application instructions state that the exchange will be exchanged as of the date NMFS approves the exchange application. The instructions also state No exchange, adjustment, apportionment of flatfish may take effect until NMFS publishes notification in the Federal Register. The instructions arent clear if these are the same dates, and should be clarified. Also, NMFS should clarify the process they will follow to ensure there is no delay.

Feel free to contact me at jasonanderson@seanet.com if you have any questions or need additional input. Thank you for considering these comments.


", 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'NOAA-NMFS-2013-0074', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Jason', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481814a67', 'lastName': 'Anderson', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2014-08-09T20:13:33Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2014-08-09T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2014-08-08T22:26:05Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment from Jason Anderson', 'trackingNbr': '1jy-8dom-libg', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
August 7, 2014

Glenn Merrill
Assistant Regional Administrator
Sustainable Fisheries Division
Alaska Region, NMFS
P.O. Box 21668
Juneau, AK 99802-1668

Dear Mr. Merrill,

We are writing to comment on the reporting requirements for the proposed rule implementing Amendment 105 to the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands Fishery Management Plan (Amendment 105).

The Alaska Seafood Cooperative (AKSC) is a harvesting cooperative consisting of sixteen vessels and five companies. The multi species Amendment 80 sector operates under hard caps for yellowfin sole, flathead sole, rock sole, Pacific cod, Atka mackerel, and Pacific ocean perch, as well as halibut and crab. The North Pacific Fishery Management Council (Council) intended Amendment 105 to provide additional flexibility for Amendment 80 vessels harvesting yellowfin sole, rock sole, and flathead sole, which could result in more efficient use of these and other species.

We believe that proposed regulations implementing Amendment 105 will assist in maximizing flatfish harvests while maintaining statutory and regulatory harvesting limits. However, we have several comments about the reporting aspects of these regulations.

The preamble to the proposed rule and regulations at 679.20(b)(1)(iii)(A) state that the ABC reserve would be set after consultation with the Council or could be reduced if NMFS determines there is a need to set the ABC reserve below the ABC surplus. To inform ABC reserve decisions, regulations at 679.5(s)(7)(iii) describe information requirements for the Preliminary Amendment 80 Flatfish Exchange Report. This report proposed to be provided by industry. However, all of the information required on the Preliminary Amendment 80 Cooperative Flatfish Exchange Report form is available to NMFS. Requiring cooperatives to report this information is unnecessary and increases costs and reporting burden. Rather, NMFS could provide the same information to the Council at its December meeting.
Block B of the Flatfish Exchange Report requires information about quota exchanges. The headings in Block B are titled: Species Exchanged Into Cooperative Quota and Species Exchanged Out of Reserves. These headings are asking for the same information. As described in the proposed regulations, a cooperative would be exchanging CQ of one species for CQ of another species. For example, a cooperative could relinquish 1000 mt of flathead sole CQ and receive 1000 mt of yellowfin sole CQ. The cooperative would also exchange an equal amount of ABC reserve for both species. The current form confuses these two exchanges and should be corrected.
Block A of the Flatfish Exchange Application asks whether the exchange is CDQ or Amendment 80. Block B also asks for the same information in both the Species Exchanged In and Species Exchanged Out columns. This creates confusion, and suggests that a cooperative may exchange CDQ CQ for Amendment 80 CQ. We dont think this was the intention, and should be corrected. We believe its only necessary to state whether the exchange is CDQ or Amendment 80 in Block A.
The Flatfish Exchange Application instructions state that the exchange will be exchanged as of the date NMFS approves the exchange application. The instructions also state No exchange, adjustment, apportionment of flatfish may take effect until NMFS publishes notification in the Federal Register. The instructions arent clear if these are the same dates, and should be clarified. Also, NMFS should clarify the process they will follow to ensure there is no delay.

Feel free to contact me at jasonanderson@seanet.com if you have any questions or need additional input. Thank you for considering these comments.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': 'Green Valley Farm', 'address2': '878 Bliem Rd.', 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Sanatoga', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Docket Number 17005

The temporary ADIZ is a terrific example of bureaucracy gone wrong.

To the best of my knowledge, there has NEVER been a credible threat from any General Aviation aircraft. It would take terrorist planners just a moment of thought to rule out using small aircraft, as evidenced by the poor misguided young man who sympathetically flew the small aircraft into the office building in Florida shortly after 9/11. The airplane didn’t even make it all the way into the building.

There have been far more damage and lost of life by terrorists through the use of cars, trucks, and pedestrians.

The ADIZ is too large. It covers large areas of nonessential airspace. I have flown into the ADIZ on 3 occasions and have found it to be poorly thought through, administered clumsily, and stressful. (The air traffic controllers do a fine job; it is the process that is in error)

My wife and I used to take regular trips to Bay Bridge with friends…it is not worth it anymore, we go elsewhere. I used to fly in to Gaithersburg frequently for both business and to see family. We now meet the family half way in Delaware and I have reassigned my existing business clients to local offices. I have not flown into Gaithersburg again since the ADIZ went into effect.

I am certain that had the terrorist not used commercial aircraft, we would not even be having this discussion. But why the leap in restricting General Aviation aircraft to the small regional airports? I suggest that it is because the FAA has jurisdiction over both commercial airliners and small aircraft, not because small aircraft are a viable threat.

I suggest that the FAA work closely with the various General Aviation groups and evaluate the ACTUAL risks and arrive at a mutually agreeable way to address the real risks.

', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FAA-2004-17005', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Robert', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802e9028', 'lastName': 'Safford Jr.', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-02T08:16:00Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'PA', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Robert O. Safford Jr. - Comments', 'trackingNbr': '802e9028', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '19464', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Docket Number 17005

The temporary ADIZ is a terrific example of bureaucracy gone wrong.

To the best of my knowledge, there has NEVER been a credible threat from any General Aviation aircraft. It would take terrorist planners just a moment of thought to rule out using small aircraft, as evidenced by the poor misguided young man who sympathetically flew the small aircraft into the office building in Florida shortly after 9/11. The airplane didn’t even make it all the way into the building.

There have been far more damage and lost of life by terrorists through the use of cars, trucks, and pedestrians.

The ADIZ is too large. It covers large areas of nonessential airspace. I have flown into the ADIZ on 3 occasions and have found it to be poorly thought through, administered clumsily, and stressful. (The air traffic controllers do a fine job; it is the process that is in error)

My wife and I used to take regular trips to Bay Bridge with friends…it is not worth it anymore, we go elsewhere. I used to fly in to Gaithersburg frequently for both business and to see family. We now meet the family half way in Delaware and I have reassigned my existing business clients to local offices. I have not flown into Gaithersburg again since the ADIZ went into effect.

I am certain that had the terrorist not used commercial aircraft, we would not even be having this discussion. But why the leap in restricting General Aviation aircraft to the small regional airports? I suggest that it is because the FAA has jurisdiction over both commercial airliners and small aircraft, not because small aircraft are a viable threat.

I suggest that the FAA work closely with the various General Aviation groups and evaluate the ACTUAL risks and arrive at a mutually agreeable way to address the real risks.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'To Whom It May Concern:

I am a private pilot, logging apx. 100 hours a year based out of the Minneapolis area. I fly my personal airplane for business (real estate) and pleasure with family vacations.

As an AOPA & EAA member, pilot and proud citizen of our country, I’d like to request that public hearings be held on the ADIZ rule affecting Washington D.C. The issues that surround this ADIZ have been outlined by the AOPA and I strongly agree with their many contentions. I understand some wayward aviators have violated the DC ADIZ, but also note the incredible response of our homeland defense services and how they quickly responded and escorted those violators under military supervision for further inspection. General aviation has a great impact on many localities far beyond the gas purchased at the local FBO. The business I conduct in real estate alone moves millions in and out of cities as a result of the freedom general aviation affords me and my clients.

I am not against regulating airspace, but find it unbelievable that our government would make permanent measures put in place as a protection during a national crisis without much research or analysis of its effects, without first holding hearings so that all affected may offer their input. I expect such behavior from other totalitarian states, but not from the country I proudly call home.

Sincerely,
Frederick P. Skoda

', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FAA-2004-17005', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Frederick', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802e901e', 'lastName': 'Skoda', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-02T08:15:46Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Frederick Skoda - Comments', 'trackingNbr': '802e901e', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am a private pilot, logging apx. 100 hours a year based out of the Minneapolis area. I fly my personal airplane for business (real estate) and pleasure with family vacations.

As an AOPA & EAA member, pilot and proud citizen of our country, I’d like to request that public hearings be held on the ADIZ rule affecting Washington D.C. The issues that surround this ADIZ have been outlined by the AOPA and I strongly agree with their many contentions. I understand some wayward aviators have violated the DC ADIZ, but also note the incredible response of our homeland defense services and how they quickly responded and escorted those violators under military supervision for further inspection. General aviation has a great impact on many localities far beyond the gas purchased at the local FBO. The business I conduct in real estate alone moves millions in and out of cities as a result of the freedom general aviation affords me and my clients.

I am not against regulating airspace, but find it unbelievable that our government would make permanent measures put in place as a protection during a national crisis without much research or analysis of its effects, without first holding hearings so that all affected may offer their input. I expect such behavior from other totalitarian states, but not from the country I proudly call home.

Sincerely,
Frederick P. Skoda

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Alex Robatto
40 Merritt Drive
Lawrenceville, NJ 08648

February 3, 2006
Reference: FAA-2004-17005

To whom it may concern,

I write this letter in regards to the recent matter of docket number 17005. I am a private pilot with 600 hours of flight time. I hold privileges to fly by instruments as well. I fly approximately 50 hours per year and on occasion I fly in or around both New York and Washington/Baltimore class B airspace.

I feel that applying a permanent ADIZ in the Washington-Baltimore class would be detrimental to the general aviation community and also the multitude of business interests that are directly, or indirectly relate to general aviation. Please consider the following:

? I ask the FAA to hold public hearings on the ADIZ rule.

? The Washington, D.C., ADIZ is operationally unworkable and imposes major burdens on pilots and air traffic controllers alike, all with minimal security benefits, and it must NOT be made permanent.

? Protecting the unique assets in the nation's Capital is important, but this can be achieved with the existing requirements for the 15-mile Flight Restricted Zone (FRZ). This has been augmented by other security measures put in place around Washington, D.C., including ground-based missile defense systems, more nimble air interdiction capability with U.S. Customs helicopters, and a laser warning system.

? The FAA must implement safer, more efficient and rational security procedures for the airspace in the Washington, D.C., area. Lighter aircraft, flying at slower speeds, should not be subject to the current ADIZ requirements for filing a flight plan, obtaining a unique transponder code and maintaining two-way communications with Air Traffic Control.

? The proposed rule is flawed because the evaluation of the economic and operational impacts on pilots and aviation businesses and an analysis of alternatives are insufficient.

? No general aviation aircraft has ever been used in a terrorist attack. And the government has determined that not a single ADIZ violation was terrorist-related.

It is hoped that the aforementioned arguments are carefully considered before making a decision that can have irrevocable negative consequences to the general aviation community and business interests. I respectfully thank you for listening to my concerns.

Respectfully yours,

Alex Robatto

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '3479 Burbank Dr.', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Ann Arbor', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Establishing the ADIZ unnecessarily makes life difficult for ordinary law-abiding pilots. As anyone who rationally considers the question recognizes, the security threat from small general aviation aircraft is minimal at best. Even most of the smaller motor vehicles traveling in and out of the area hourly, 24/7, pose a greater security risk than a typical four-seat airplane. The load-carrying capacity and the mass just are not substantial in a small GA plane, as compared to most vehicles on the street.

', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FAA-2004-17005', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Kim', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802e9046', 'lastName': 'Palmo', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-02T08:16:40Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'MI', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Kim J. comment: Establishing the ADIZ unnecessarily makes life difficult for ordinary law-abiding pilots. As anyone who rationally considers the question recognizes, the security threat from small general aviation aircraft is minimal at best. Even most of the smaller motor vehicles traveling in and out of the area hourly, 24/7, pose a greater security risk than a typical four-seat airplane. The load-carrying capacity and the mass just are not substantial in a small GA plane, as compared to most vehicles on the street.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '230 Route 17A Suite 202', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Goshen', 'category': None, 'comment': "Docket Number 17005

I’m a 53 year old 600/hr. private pilot and airplane owner (Cessna 172K Hawk XP) based at Orange County Airport in Montgomery, New York (MGJ). I fly into Easton & Cambridge Maryland several times a year to visit relatives as well Dunnellon, Florida to visit my aging father. My typical flight path (MXE, PXT, RIC) takes me just east of the ADIZ. As a safety conscious VFR pilot, who always flies with flight following on cross country flights, I find it very frustrating to be denied flight following from PATUXENT APPROACH/DEPARTURE CONTROL because of the controllers work load being too heavy to accommodate my VFR flight.

On several flights through the area I have observed traffic requiring an evasive maneuver to keep safe separation. On one occasion a King Air passed off my left wing with less then one half mile separation.

Please consider the following points:
•Please continue to hold public hearings on the ADIZ rule.
•The Washington, D.C., ADIZ is operationally unworkable and imposes major burdens on pilots and air traffic controllers alike, all with minimal security benefits, and therefore, it must NOT be made permanent.
•Protecting the unique assets in the nation's Capital is important, but this can be achieved with the existing requirements for the 15-mile Flight Restricted Zone (FRZ). This has been augmented by other security measures put in place around Washington, D.C., including ground-based missile defense systems, more nimble air interdiction capability with U.S. Customs helicopters, and a laser warning system.
•The FAA must implement safer, more efficient and rational security procedures for the airspace in the Washington, D.C., area. Lighter aircraft, flying at slower speeds, should not be subject to the current ADIZ requirements for filing a flight plan, obtaining a unique transponder code and maintaining two-way communications with Air Traffic Control.
•The proposed rule is flawed because the evaluation of the economic and operational impacts on pilots and aviation businesses and an analysis of alternatives are insufficient.
•No general aviation aircraft has ever been used in a terrorist attack. And the government has determined that not a single ADIZ violation was terrorist-related.
Respectfully submitted,
William M. Jones
AOPA Member 04681283

comment:
Docket Number 17005

I’m a 53 year old 600/hr. private pilot and airplane owner (Cessna 172K Hawk XP) based at Orange County Airport in Montgomery, New York (MGJ). I fly into Easton & Cambridge Maryland several times a year to visit relatives as well Dunnellon, Florida to visit my aging father. My typical flight path (MXE, PXT, RIC) takes me just east of the ADIZ. As a safety conscious VFR pilot, who always flies with flight following on cross country flights, I find it very frustrating to be denied flight following from PATUXENT APPROACH/DEPARTURE CONTROL because of the controllers work load being too heavy to accommodate my VFR flight.

On several flights through the area I have observed traffic requiring an evasive maneuver to keep safe separation. On one occasion a King Air passed off my left wing with less then one half mile separation.

Please consider the following points:
•Please continue to hold public hearings on the ADIZ rule.
•The Washington, D.C., ADIZ is operationally unworkable and imposes major burdens on pilots and air traffic controllers alike, all with minimal security benefits, and therefore, it must NOT be made permanent.
•Protecting the unique assets in the nation's Capital is important, but this can be achieved with the existing requirements for the 15-mile Flight Restricted Zone (FRZ). This has been augmented by other security measures put in place around Washington, D.C., including ground-based missile defense systems, more nimble air interdiction capability with U.S. Customs helicopters, and a laser warning system.
•The FAA must implement safer, more efficient and rational security procedures for the airspace in the Washington, D.C., area. Lighter aircraft, flying at slower speeds, should not be subject to the current ADIZ requirements for filing a flight plan, obtaining a unique transponder code and maintaining two-way communications with Air Traffic Control.
•The proposed rule is flawed because the evaluation of the economic and operational impacts on pilots and aviation businesses and an analysis of alternatives are insufficient.
•No general aviation aircraft has ever been used in a terrorist attack. And the government has determined that not a single ADIZ violation was terrorist-related.
Respectfully submitted,
William M. Jones
AOPA Member 04681283

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '831 Gates AV #2', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Norfolk', 'category': None, 'comment': "To whom it may concern:
I am both a military helicopter and civilian pilot with the following FAA ratings: Airline Transport Pilot (multi-engine land), commercial privileges (airplane single engine land, rotorcraft helicopter), and instrument helicopter. I have 2550 total hours and fly approximately 200 hours per year. My wife is a private pilot with a tail wheel endorsement who is progressing towards her instrument and commercial ratings (single engine land) and has approximately 250 hours. Most recently, we have operated out of military (myself) and civil (both) airports in the southern Maryland area. We own our own aircraft, which is used mainly for personal transportation. I have 17 years of flight experience while my wife has 15 years. Additionally, I am a member of the Society of Experimental Test Pilots.

The implementation of the ADIZ has caused us to completely avoid flying in or around the metropolitan Washington, D.C., area. The procedures required to both plan a flight and to fly in that area are so cumbersome and inconsistent that destinations we once considered routine are no longer on our list of places to go.
As taxpayers whose money helps fund the FAA, we believe it is only right and proper that we be allowed to publicly comment on proposed changes to the ADIZ, especially when those changes include discussion regarding its permanency. We believe that all citizens have this right. The Washington, D.C., ADIZ is operationally unworkable and imposes major burdens on pilots and air traffic controllers alike, all with minimal security benefits, and it must not be made permanent. We strongly support our government, especially in its quest to fight terrorism and protect the capital. However, in its current form, the ADIZ regulations are not achieving that end. Enforcement of the existing requirements for the 15-mile Flight Restricted Zone (FRZ), coupled with other security measures, such as ground-based missile defense systems, more nimble air interdiction capability with U.S. Customs helicopters, and a laser warning system, may prove to be a more effective solution. The FAA must implement safer, more efficient and rational security procedures for the airspace in the Washington, D.C., area. Lighter aircraft, flying at slower speeds, should not be subject to the current ADIZ requirements for filing a flight plan, obtaining a unique transponder code and maintaining two-way communications with Air Traffic Control. The proposed rule is flawed because the evaluation of the economic and operational impacts on pilots and aviation businesses and an analysis of alternatives are insufficient. No general aviation aircraft has ever been used in a terrorist attack, and the government has determined that not a single ADIZ violation was terrorist-related.

Thank you for entertaining our concerns regarding the ADIZ.
", 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FAA-2004-17005', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Patrick', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802e91a6', 'lastName': 'Twomey', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-02T08:24:05Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2006-02-03T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'VA', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Patrick Twomey', 'trackingNbr': '802e91a6', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '23517', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
To whom it may concern:
I am both a military helicopter and civilian pilot with the following FAA ratings: Airline Transport Pilot (multi-engine land), commercial privileges (airplane single engine land, rotorcraft helicopter), and instrument helicopter. I have 2550 total hours and fly approximately 200 hours per year. My wife is a private pilot with a tail wheel endorsement who is progressing towards her instrument and commercial ratings (single engine land) and has approximately 250 hours. Most recently, we have operated out of military (myself) and civil (both) airports in the southern Maryland area. We own our own aircraft, which is used mainly for personal transportation. I have 17 years of flight experience while my wife has 15 years. Additionally, I am a member of the Society of Experimental Test Pilots.

The implementation of the ADIZ has caused us to completely avoid flying in or around the metropolitan Washington, D.C., area. The procedures required to both plan a flight and to fly in that area are so cumbersome and inconsistent that destinations we once considered routine are no longer on our list of places to go.
As taxpayers whose money helps fund the FAA, we believe it is only right and proper that we be allowed to publicly comment on proposed changes to the ADIZ, especially when those changes include discussion regarding its permanency. We believe that all citizens have this right. The Washington, D.C., ADIZ is operationally unworkable and imposes major burdens on pilots and air traffic controllers alike, all with minimal security benefits, and it must not be made permanent. We strongly support our government, especially in its quest to fight terrorism and protect the capital. However, in its current form, the ADIZ regulations are not achieving that end. Enforcement of the existing requirements for the 15-mile Flight Restricted Zone (FRZ), coupled with other security measures, such as ground-based missile defense systems, more nimble air interdiction capability with U.S. Customs helicopters, and a laser warning system, may prove to be a more effective solution. The FAA must implement safer, more efficient and rational security procedures for the airspace in the Washington, D.C., area. Lighter aircraft, flying at slower speeds, should not be subject to the current ADIZ requirements for filing a flight plan, obtaining a unique transponder code and maintaining two-way communications with Air Traffic Control. The proposed rule is flawed because the evaluation of the economic and operational impacts on pilots and aviation businesses and an analysis of alternatives are insufficient. No general aviation aircraft has ever been used in a terrorist attack, and the government has determined that not a single ADIZ violation was terrorist-related.

Thank you for entertaining our concerns regarding the ADIZ.

{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '204 Analomink Street', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'East Stroudsburg', 'category': None, 'comment': 'To whom it may concern,

I am an aspiring professional pilot. I have the opportunity to pursue this career by being privledged to be a US citizen. I respect the government's efforts to protect all of us. But I disagree with the proposal to make the ADIZ zone around DC permanent. What my relatives have fought for (we have had military members in our family in most conflicts from the revolutionary war to present) is freedom. Our civil liberties cannot be allowed to erode over erroneous fears. A light plane is not a true danger. The country does face potential attacks from the cowards who threaten us. Our freedoms and way of life is a threat to dogmatic radicals who are afraid to allow their peoples to think for themselves as we are blessed to be able to do. I fear that the ADIZ is step backwards and ultimately sends a message that the terrorist are winning. I also know as a FAA licensed commercial pilot, that we pilots are more than willing to aid our country in anyway possible - be it the airport security programs or other ideas. I thank the FAA and US government for allowing me these comments and pursuit of a career in aviation. thank you. Fred Monteabaro...

What my relatives have fought for (we have had military members in our family in most conflicts from the revolutionary war to present) is freedom. attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '829 Elbow Lane', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Warrington', 'category': None, 'comment': "February 3, 2006

Sirs:

As a pilot and aircraft owner, I wanted to express my dismay at the efforts to make the Washington Area ADIZ a permanent obstruction to proper and efficient flight planning. Many of times since it’s creation I have found myself flight planning a trip that sensible routing would take me through the ADIZ. Instead, I make my plan to go around the ADIZ, burning more fuel and putting more time on my airplane. I do this even though I am on an IFR flight plan, just out of fear of making a mistake and losing my flying privileges.

Also, I have a friend in Annapolis, who I have visited in the past. But now with Lee Airport lying in the tomb called an ADIZ, I am reluctant to drop in for a visit. That hurts the economy of that airport, the local restaurants and my 40 year friendship. These things may seem minor but America is about these kinds of freedoms and restricting them hurts all of us and gives our enemies one more thing to crow about. I do hope that the powers-to-be consider these issues and realize that the real threat does not come from these types of flights and that the ADIZ is would not really be effective in curbing someone bent on attacking our government.

Sincerely,

Michael E. Guckin
829 Elbow Lane
Warrington, PA 19044
N55319

comment:
February 3, 2006

Sirs:

As a pilot and aircraft owner, I wanted to express my dismay at the efforts to make the Washington Area ADIZ a permanent obstruction to proper and efficient flight planning. Many of times since it’s creation I have found myself flight planning a trip that sensible routing would take me through the ADIZ. Instead, I make my plan to go around the ADIZ, burning more fuel and putting more time on my airplane. I do this even though I am on an IFR flight plan, just out of fear of making a mistake and losing my flying privileges.

Also, I have a friend in Annapolis, who I have visited in the past. But now with Lee Airport lying in the tomb called an ADIZ, I am reluctant to drop in for a visit. That hurts the economy of that airport, the local restaurants and my 40 year friendship. These things may seem minor but America is about these kinds of freedoms and restricting them hurts all of us and gives our enemies one more thing to crow about. I do hope that the powers-to-be consider these issues and realize that the real threat does not come from these types of flights and that the ADIZ is would not really be effective in curbing someone bent on attacking our government.

Sincerely,

Michael E. Guckin
829 Elbow Lane
Warrington, PA 19044
N55319

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '4411 Corrales Rd', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Corrales', 'category': None, 'comment': 'An expanded Washington D.C. Air Defense Identification Zone (ADIZ) would severely limit the flexibility of our airplanes as we conduct business and bring travel revenue into the National Capital Region. We fully understand the need to limit access in the airspace immediately adjacent to the Capitol area and feel the 15 mile-wide restricted area meets that need. However, existing Washington Class B airspace and rules already provide the positive identification and tracking of airplanes in the greater Washington D.C. area that Docket 17005-1 seeks to establish. There is no need to further limit access to this airspace, which would serve only to negatively impact dozens of airports and hundreds of aviation-related businesses, as well as severely limit nonaviation commerce that depends on flexible use of business and personal aviation in the region.
The most troubling aspect of this Docket is the creation of an unprecedented class of restricted National Defense Airspace (NDA). This new designation goes far beyond even the existing ADIZ rules, which themselves were “temporarily” established as a result of now long-eased tensions in the build-up to the Iraq war. NDA would severely restrict free access to airspace, and unilaterally punish those who even as a result of in-flight mechanical failure or minor operational transgression lose contact with controllers while on an otherwise authorized flight. There is the very real threat that other cities would seize on such an airspace designation to establish no-fly zones elsewhere, further limiting access and commerce with no discernable increase in real security. This we cannot allow to happen as it would undermine the entire U.S. general aviation industry and the millions of citizens and businesses that are positively touched by non-airline aviation every day.

comment:
An expanded Washington D.C. Air Defense Identification Zone (ADIZ) would severely limit the flexibility of our airplanes as we conduct business and bring travel revenue into the National Capital Region. We fully understand the need to limit access in the airspace immediately adjacent to the Capitol area and feel the 15 mile-wide restricted area meets that need. However, existing Washington Class B airspace and rules already provide the positive identification and tracking of airplanes in the greater Washington D.C. area that Docket 17005-1 seeks to establish. There is no need to further limit access to this airspace, which would serve only to negatively impact dozens of airports and hundreds of aviation-related businesses, as well as severely limit nonaviation commerce that depends on flexible use of business and personal aviation in the region.
The most troubling aspect of this Docket is the creation of an unprecedented class of restricted National Defense Airspace (NDA). This new designation goes far beyond even the existing ADIZ rules, which themselves were “temporarily” established as a result of now long-eased tensions in the build-up to the Iraq war. NDA would severely restrict free access to airspace, and unilaterally punish those who even as a result of in-flight mechanical failure or minor operational transgression lose contact with controllers while on an otherwise authorized flight. There is the very real threat that other cities would seize on such an airspace designation to establish no-fly zones elsewhere, further limiting access and commerce with no discernable increase in real security. This we cannot allow to happen as it would undermine the entire U.S. general aviation industry and the millions of citizens and businesses that are positively touched by non-airline aviation every day.

I am also a former Air Force pilot with extensive world-wide flight experience. Making the Wachington DC ADIZ permanent is not the correct decision. The threat posed by general avaition aircraft is very minor. Due to the size and payload capacity of most GA aircraft, the typical SUV posses a much greater threat than a GA aircraft for example. The effects of the Washington DC ADIZ have already costs untold thousands of dollars and numerous loss of jobs for tax-paying United States citizens engaged in the aviation business around Washington DC. There are other means available to protect secure areas such as TFRs. A blanket, permanent ADIZ is not the answer. I urger the FAA to hold public hearings on the issue as well as to follow the recommendations of the Aircraft Oweners and Pilots Association as well as other advocacy groups. Thank you.

comment: I am an FAA ATP-licensed pilot with over 2500 hours flying time. I am also a former Air Force pilot with extensive world-wide flight experience. Making the Wachington DC ADIZ permanent is not the correct decision. The threat posed by general avaition aircraft is very minor. Due to the size and payload capacity of most GA aircraft, the typical SUV posses a much greater threat than a GA aircraft for example. The effects of the Washington DC ADIZ have already costs untold thousands of dollars and numerous loss of jobs for tax-paying United States citizens engaged in the aviation business around Washington DC. There are other means available to protect secure areas such as TFRs. A blanket, permanent ADIZ is not the answer. I urger the FAA to hold public hearings on the issue as well as to follow the recommendations of the Aircraft Oweners and Pilots Association as well as other advocacy groups. Thank you.

{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '21 Brookfield Lane', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'S. Setauket', 'category': None, 'comment': 'I live on Long Island NY and my daugher and son-in-law lives and work in the Washington D.C. area for the FDA. My wife and I enjoy flying to be with family. Family is the foundation of this country. Expanded Washington D.C. Air Defense Identification Zone would limit our quality of life and flexibility of our airplane as we conduct business, pleasue and bring travel revenue into the National Capital Region.

The American Bonanza Society represents over 10,400 aircraft owners and pilots. We are extremely concerned about the negative trend in airspace access reflected by Docket FAA-2004-17005 and hereby register our strong opposition to the proposed changes. We join the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association in calling for the FAA to hold public hearings on the proposed rule.

Many of our members live and fly in the Washington D.C. area, and many more fly to the area on business and pleasure trips. An expanded Washington D.C. Air Defense Identification Zone (ADIZ) would severely limit the flexibility of our airplanes as we conduct business and bring travel revenue into the National Capital Region. We fully understand the need to limit access in the airspace immediately adjacent to the Capitol area and feel the 15 mile-wide restricted area meets that need. However, existing Washington Class B airspace and rules already provide the positive identification and tracking of airplanes in the greater Washington D.C. area that Docket 17005-1 seeks to establish. There is no need to further limit access to this airspace, which would serve only to negatively impact dozens of airports and hundreds of aviation-related businesses, as well as severely limit nonaviation commerce that depends on flexible use of business and personal aviation in the region.



The most troubling aspect of this Docket is the creation of an unprecedented class of restricted National Defense Airspace (NDA). This new designation goes far beyond even the existing ADIZ rules, which themselves were “temporarily” established as a result of now long-eased tensions in the build-up to the Iraq war. NDA would severely restrict free access to airspace, and unilaterally punish those who even as a result of in-flight mechanical failure or minor operational transgression lose contact with controllers while on an otherwise authorized flight. There is the very real threat that other cities would seize on such an airspace designation to establish no-fly zones elsewhere, further limiting access and commerce with no discernable increase in real security. This we cannot allow to happen as it would undermine the entire U.S. general aviation industry and the millions of citizens and businesses that are positively touched by non-airline aviation every day.



Enforcement of pre-9/11 Class B airspace rules with allowances for in-flight equipment failures would have properly addressed the over 3000 accidental airspace penetrations that have occurred to date. Pilot education about existing airspace rules, not new regulation or heavy-handed punishment, is the key to keeping unauthorized airplanes away from the Federal capital. Representing over 10,400 aircraft owners and pilots, the American Bonanza Society ardently opposes the adoption of measures contained in Docket FAA-2004-17005.



Respectfully submitted,
Frank J. Pollina
21 Brookfield Lane
S. Setauket, New York 11720

We join the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association in calling for the FAA to hold public hearings on the proposed rule.

Many of our members live and fly in the Washington D.C. area, and many more fly to the area on business and pleasure trips. An expanded Washington D.C. Air Defense Identification Zone (ADIZ) would severely limit the flexibility of our airplanes as we conduct business and bring travel revenue into the National Capital Region. We fully understand the need to limit access in the airspace immediately adjacent to the Capitol area and feel the 15 mile-wide restricted area meets that need. However, existing Washington Class B airspace and rules already provide the positive identification and tracking of airplanes in the greater Washington D.C. area that Docket 17005-1 seeks to establish. There is no need to further limit access to this airspace, which would serve only to negatively impact dozens of airports and hundreds of aviation-related businesses, as well as severely limit nonaviation commerce that depends on flexible use of business and personal aviation in the region.



The most troubling aspect of this Docket is the creation of an unprecedented class of restricted National Defense Airspace (NDA). This new designation goes far beyond even the existing ADIZ rules, which themselves were “temporarily” established as a result of now long-eased tensions in the build-up to the Iraq war. NDA would severely restrict free access to airspace, and unilaterally punish those who even as a result of in-flight mechanical failure or minor operational transgression lose contact with controllers while on an otherwise authorized flight. There is the very real threat that other cities would seize on such an airspace designation to establish no-fly zones elsewhere, further limiting access and commerce with no discernable increase in real security. This we cannot allow to happen as it would undermine the entire U.S. general aviation industry and the millions of citizens and businesses that are positively touched by non-airline aviation every day.



Enforcement of pre-9/11 Class B airspace rules with allowances for in-flight equipment failures would have properly addressed the over 3000 accidental airspace penetrations that have occurred to date. Pilot education about existing airspace rules, not new regulation or heavy-handed punishment, is the key to keeping unauthorized airplanes away from the Federal capital. Representing over 10,400 aircraft owners and pilots, the American Bonanza Society ardently opposes the adoption of measures contained in Docket FAA-2004-17005.



Respectfully submitted,
Frank J. Pollina
21 Brookfield Lane
S. Setauket, New York 11720

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '2416 Stryker Ave.', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Vienna', 'category': None, 'comment': 'The following are comments in opposition to the Washington ADIZ.

I am a retired USAF Lt Col. I am a private pilot with 900 hours of flying time in my Cessna 172 aircraft (N5187G). I have owned this aircraft since 1993. My aircraft is based at Manassas (KHEF)

The Washington ADIZ must not be made permanent. I fully appreciate the need to protect our Capital City and our civilian and military leadership. However, the ADIZ brings no "value added" in terms of protection, and seriously limits a basic freedom that all Americans should have the opportunity to enjoy.

The ADIZ brings an increased workload to controllers, operators, and a substantial cost burden with no quantifiable improvement in "national security".

My office in Arlington overlooks the 14th Steet Bridge. Imagine the number of opportunities for inflicting damage each one of those vehicles carries....every hour of every day. And yet there is no ground-based equivalent ADIZ or security checkpoint.

After 20 years of military service, I appreciate that sometimes individual liberties must be sacrificed for the good of the Nation. The Washington ADIZ is not such a necessary sacrifice. By making this construct permanent, you have granted the Terrorists, and all who hate our Liberty, a victory.

Thanks for this opportunity to comment.

Respectfully,

Douglas Curt Osterheld
Lt Col, USAF (Ret)
Private Pilot

comment:
The following are comments in opposition to the Washington ADIZ.

I am a retired USAF Lt Col. I am a private pilot with 900 hours of flying time in my Cessna 172 aircraft (N5187G). I have owned this aircraft since 1993. My aircraft is based at Manassas (KHEF)

The Washington ADIZ must not be made permanent. I fully appreciate the need to protect our Capital City and our civilian and military leadership. However, the ADIZ brings no "value added" in terms of protection, and seriously limits a basic freedom that all Americans should have the opportunity to enjoy.

The ADIZ brings an increased workload to controllers, operators, and a substantial cost burden with no quantifiable improvement in "national security".

My office in Arlington overlooks the 14th Steet Bridge. Imagine the number of opportunities for inflicting damage each one of those vehicles carries....every hour of every day. And yet there is no ground-based equivalent ADIZ or security checkpoint.

After 20 years of military service, I appreciate that sometimes individual liberties must be sacrificed for the good of the Nation. The Washington ADIZ is not such a necessary sacrifice. By making this construct permanent, you have granted the Terrorists, and all who hate our Liberty, a victory.

Thanks for this opportunity to comment.

Respectfully,

Douglas Curt Osterheld
Lt Col, USAF (Ret)
Private Pilot

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '9395 Shadow Ridge Cove', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Cordova', 'category': None, 'comment': 'The purpose of this letter is to comment on docket # 17005. I am a professional pilot with an Airline Transport Pilot’s as well as Commercial, Multiengine, Single Engine Land ratings. I have between 12 and 15 thousand hours of total flying time and fly 500 to 1000 hours a year in both my commercial flying and my general aviation flying. I fly throughout the US and Canada commercially but mostly out of western Tennessee in my general aviation flying. I feel that restrictions (especially permanent ones) to airspace use (or any freedoms we have in our great nation) should only be allowed when there are three conditions met. First, there should be clear and continuing threats that the restrictions will definitely prevent. Secondly, the restrictions should be structured to affect the fewest non-threat citizens. Third, they should be lifted as soon as other more effective measures are in place to prevent the same threat. It appears to me that the proposal of a permanent ADIZ around Washington D.C. is not an effective measure, complicates the lives of thousands of flyers who are not a threat, and does not allow easy lifting of the restrictions, and sets a very dangerous precedent for future restrictions. On the contrary, it has been shown that every violator of the temporary ADIZ was determined to be a non-threat; that it complicates the lives and jobs of all pilots and controllers not just the ones it’s designed to keep out; that it is expensive and hard to enforce; and that it is a step toward out-of-control restrictions. Remember, in the extreme, if there are no takeoffs and landings, there will be no accidents, no threats to airspace, no noise abatement problems, and no need for the FAA.

As a minimum, I would recommend public hearings on the ADIZ proposal. The impact of making a permanent ADIZ over such a large area is not an easy prediction and requires further study. As a commercial airline pilot flying into Washington’s Reagan Airport (DCA), I am aware of the measures necessary in the training, review and supervision to comply with current (although now reduced) requirements. To put requirements on general aviation pilots who don’t fly nearly as often, and who often have aircraft with inadequate equipment and capability to comply, is the equivalent of telling them that they can’t fly anymore. These types of light aircraft have never been used as a terrorist weapon and aren’t capable of carrying large amounts of dangerous material. They fly at speeds slow enough to allow intercept using the current 15 mile Flight Restricted Zone that already protects the nation’s critical assets. In addition, there are other measures and protections already in place to add extra security to our nation’s capital.

In summary, I am against the proposed permanent ADIZ around the Washington, D.C. area and feel there are other more effective and more workable ways to increase security without denying thousands of pilots their current flying rights and without grounding many aircraft.

', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FAA-2004-17005', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'J. comment:
The purpose of this letter is to comment on docket # 17005. I am a professional pilot with an Airline Transport Pilot’s as well as Commercial, Multiengine, Single Engine Land ratings. I have between 12 and 15 thousand hours of total flying time and fly 500 to 1000 hours a year in both my commercial flying and my general aviation flying. I fly throughout the US and Canada commercially but mostly out of western Tennessee in my general aviation flying. I feel that restrictions (especially permanent ones) to airspace use (or any freedoms we have in our great nation) should only be allowed when there are three conditions met. First, there should be clear and continuing threats that the restrictions will definitely prevent. Secondly, the restrictions should be structured to affect the fewest non-threat citizens. Third, they should be lifted as soon as other more effective measures are in place to prevent the same threat. It appears to me that the proposal of a permanent ADIZ around Washington D.C. is not an effective measure, complicates the lives of thousands of flyers who are not a threat, and does not allow easy lifting of the restrictions, and sets a very dangerous precedent for future restrictions. On the contrary, it has been shown that every violator of the temporary ADIZ was determined to be a non-threat; that it complicates the lives and jobs of all pilots and controllers not just the ones it’s designed to keep out; that it is expensive and hard to enforce; and that it is a step toward out-of-control restrictions. Remember, in the extreme, if there are no takeoffs and landings, there will be no accidents, no threats to airspace, no noise abatement problems, and no need for the FAA.

As a minimum, I would recommend public hearings on the ADIZ proposal. The impact of making a permanent ADIZ over such a large area is not an easy prediction and requires further study. As a commercial airline pilot flying into Washington’s Reagan Airport (DCA), I am aware of the measures necessary in the training, review and supervision to comply with current (although now reduced) requirements. To put requirements on general aviation pilots who don’t fly nearly as often, and who often have aircraft with inadequate equipment and capability to comply, is the equivalent of telling them that they can’t fly anymore. These types of light aircraft have never been used as a terrorist weapon and aren’t capable of carrying large amounts of dangerous material. They fly at speeds slow enough to allow intercept using the current 15 mile Flight Restricted Zone that already protects the nation’s critical assets. In addition, there are other measures and protections already in place to add extra security to our nation’s capital.

In summary, I am against the proposed permanent ADIZ around the Washington, D.C. area and feel there are other more effective and more workable ways to increase security without denying thousands of pilots their current flying rights and without grounding many aircraft.

{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '204 Beaumont', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Wallingford', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Docket Number 17005

Hi,
I am NOT in favor of having the ADIZ remain. I want it removed permanently. I used to fly out of Potomac regularly until this security placebo farce was put in place. Haven't been back since. I lived outside the area so it has been an impact to the local economy. In fact, twice I stayed in DC overnight with my family so they could do the tourist thing while I took aerobatic lessons out of Potomac. Sad. As far as I am concerned, the terrorist won the "air war" over DC thanks to dumb politicians. What a bunch of loosers.

comment:
Docket Number 17005

Hi,
I am NOT in favor of having the ADIZ remain. I want it removed permanently. I used to fly out of Potomac regularly until this security placebo farce was put in place. Haven't been back since. I lived outside the area so it has been an impact to the local economy. In fact, twice I stayed in DC overnight with my family so they could do the tourist thing while I took aerobatic lessons out of Potomac. Sad. As far as I am concerned, the terrorist won the "air war" over DC thanks to dumb politicians. What a bunch of loosers.

{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'I am a pilot and aircraft owner (Cessna 182) and believe that the security threat from small general aviation aircraft is minimal or non-existant. Even most of the smaller motor vehicles traveling in and out of the area hourly, 24/7, pose a greater security risk than a typical four-seat plane such as mine. The load-carrying capacity and the mass just are not substantial in a small GA plane, as compared to most vehicles on the street. Establishing the ADIZ has affected business and is not a good idea.

comment: I am a pilot and aircraft owner (Cessna 182) and believe that the security threat from small general aviation aircraft is minimal or non-existant. Even most of the smaller motor vehicles traveling in and out of the area hourly, 24/7, pose a greater security risk than a typical four-seat plane such as mine. The load-carrying capacity and the mass just are not substantial in a small GA plane, as compared to most vehicles on the street. Establishing the ADIZ has affected business and is not a good idea.

Please let me put it in medical terms: Hyperactive Knee Jerk Reaction! I am very strongly opposed to the proposed ADIZ.
Service in the Navy for 10 years placed me in the Washington, D.C. are for about 4 years. During this time I utilized many of the local airports with my own private aircraft so I'm very familiar with the aviation make-up of the area.
I was designated a Naval Flight Surgeon in Dec. 1963 and Naval Aviator (pilot) in Oct. 1967. 10 years were spent in the Iowa ANG with 7 of those years spent as physician and pilot flying A-7's. Total flight time as pilot is about 7,000 hours.

R. L. Bendixen, M.D.
BGen, MC, (Ret.), Iowa ANG
ATP
Instructor: ASEL, AMEL, Instruments, helicopters

comment:
This comment is sent regarding the proposed unwarranted imposition of a permanent ADIZ in the Washington, D.C. area. Please let me put it in medical terms: Hyperactive Knee Jerk Reaction! I am very strongly opposed to the proposed ADIZ.
Service in the Navy for 10 years placed me in the Washington, D.C. are for about 4 years. During this time I utilized many of the local airports with my own private aircraft so I'm very familiar with the aviation make-up of the area.
I was designated a Naval Flight Surgeon in Dec. 1963 and Naval Aviator (pilot) in Oct. 1967. 10 years were spent in the Iowa ANG with 7 of those years spent as physician and pilot flying A-7's. Total flight time as pilot is about 7,000 hours.

R. L. Bendixen, M.D.
BGen, MC, (Ret.), Iowa ANG
ATP
Instructor: ASEL, AMEL, Instruments, helicopters

It is unnecessary to make the Washington DC ADIZ permanent.
GA does not pose a permanent threat and the ADIZ only serves to strangle general aviation.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '13988 Paradise Villas Grove', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Colorado Springs', 'category': None, 'comment': 'To: FAA
From: AOPA Member
00536115
Subject: Docket # 17005 Proposal

As a flight instructor for the last 25 years I have seen an ever increasing number of rules and restrictions imposed by the FAA, some good and some bad. However, with the help of the AOPA most changes have been good.

This proposed change to make permanente the TFR as stated in docket # 17005 is totally out to lunch. We are not the enemy and by doing this you are putting a large segment of GA out of business. This action is unnecessary and as usual is directed at the good guys, GA.

This proposed action is a smoke screen attempt to show Congress and the White House that the FAA is doing something.

Every two years I attend an AOPA flight seminar to renew my flight instructor certificate. One very important fact has become very evident and that is there are fewer and fewer instructors renewing. Why do you think that is? Well, I’ll tell you!
There are less students wanting to fly because it’s not fun anymore and the fear of making a mistake would cost the student, the instructor and any other licensed pilots everything. They could be shot down if they inadvertently crossed into a pop up TFR, or lose their license, or be fined a large sum, or go to jail, or all of the above.

A good example of a dumb move by the FAA is the TFR around the Super Bowl Stadium in Detroit. The only protection is from the US side, while the Canadian side has no restrictions. Does this mean that terrorist only come from the US? From the Canadian side anyone could fly right up to the stadium unchallenged. What is the point if the TFR if it doesn’t restrict flight all the way around?

What I am trying to say is don’t make another mistake and further injure General Aviation here in America.

Thank you for listening.

Sincerely,

Mel

comment:
To: FAA
From: AOPA Member
00536115
Subject: Docket # 17005 Proposal

As a flight instructor for the last 25 years I have seen an ever increasing number of rules and restrictions imposed by the FAA, some good and some bad. However, with the help of the AOPA most changes have been good.

This proposed change to make permanente the TFR as stated in docket # 17005 is totally out to lunch. We are not the enemy and by doing this you are putting a large segment of GA out of business. This action is unnecessary and as usual is directed at the good guys, GA.

This proposed action is a smoke screen attempt to show Congress and the White House that the FAA is doing something.

Every two years I attend an AOPA flight seminar to renew my flight instructor certificate. One very important fact has become very evident and that is there are fewer and fewer instructors renewing. Why do you think that is? Well, I’ll tell you!
There are less students wanting to fly because it’s not fun anymore and the fear of making a mistake would cost the student, the instructor and any other licensed pilots everything. They could be shot down if they inadvertently crossed into a pop up TFR, or lose their license, or be fined a large sum, or go to jail, or all of the above.

A good example of a dumb move by the FAA is the TFR around the Super Bowl Stadium in Detroit. The only protection is from the US side, while the Canadian side has no restrictions. Does this mean that terrorist only come from the US? From the Canadian side anyone could fly right up to the stadium unchallenged. What is the point if the TFR if it doesn’t restrict flight all the way around?

What I am trying to say is don’t make another mistake and further injure General Aviation here in America.

Thank you for listening.

Sincerely,

Mel

{'commentOn': '09000064802d8458', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2006-26139-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '1866 Orchard Wood Road', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Encinitas', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Please ending age discrimination by rising airline pilot retirement to age 65.

Although the FAA has begun the honorable process to rise the retirement age from 60 to 65 for airline pilots; some pilots are still fighting to keep retirement at age 60. In the months ahead you may see a campaign against rising the retirement age. The campaign will pay lip service to safety but is truly economic in nature.

The FAA is heading in the right direction by rising retirement to age 65 and ending age discrimination. The obsolete and arbitrary age 60 retirement rule, drafted at the dawn of the jet age, has out lived usefulness and is no longer valid.

Thank you for taking the high road and doing what is right by raising airline pilot retirement to age 65.

', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FAA-2006-26139', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'William', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802da7e9', 'lastName': 'Ermolovich', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-05T06:22:30Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'CA', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'William M. Ermolovich', 'trackingNbr': '802da7e9', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '92024', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Please ending age discrimination by rising airline pilot retirement to age 65.

Although the FAA has begun the honorable process to rise the retirement age from 60 to 65 for airline pilots; some pilots are still fighting to keep retirement at age 60. In the months ahead you may see a campaign against rising the retirement age. The campaign will pay lip service to safety but is truly economic in nature.

The FAA is heading in the right direction by rising retirement to age 65 and ending age discrimination. The obsolete and arbitrary age 60 retirement rule, drafted at the dawn of the jet age, has out lived usefulness and is no longer valid.

Thank you for taking the high road and doing what is right by raising airline pilot retirement to age 65.

{'commentOn': '09000064802d4e7a', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'NHTSA-2007-26851-0012-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '5013 Ox Road', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'NHTSA', 'city': 'Fairfax', 'category': None, 'comment': 'This is one of the worst idea's to date for trucking. Every day I am cut off, tailgated, given the finger and worse. Just for doing my job as a trucker.
As an owner operator I see more issues with the driving public not understanding the operation of a tractor trailer and making poor decisions in their driving with us on the roads.
There are a few truckers who abuse the speeds on any road they drive, but don't punish all driver's for the stupidity of others.
A lot of automobile driver's are just as bad or worse, so if you punish one set of driver's it should stand that ALL should be restricted, cars included.
We truckers are the sole reason America keeps running, start making it more difiicult and more drivers will leave the buisiness and slow the economy at the same time. You may think of us as trouble for the motoring public but we are the life blood of this country.
How about all who want to sign this measure go out with a truck driver for a couple of days and see what the real problem with your rules are. It's not the drivers of trucks.

comment:
This is one of the worst idea's to date for trucking. Every day I am cut off, tailgated, given the finger and worse. Just for doing my job as a trucker.
As an owner operator I see more issues with the driving public not understanding the operation of a tractor trailer and making poor decisions in their driving with us on the roads.
There are a few truckers who abuse the speeds on any road they drive, but don't punish all driver's for the stupidity of others.
A lot of automobile driver's are just as bad or worse, so if you punish one set of driver's it should stand that ALL should be restricted, cars included.
We truckers are the sole reason America keeps running, start making it more difiicult and more drivers will leave the buisiness and slow the economy at the same time. You may think of us as trouble for the motoring public but we are the life blood of this country.
How about all who want to sign this measure go out with a truck driver for a couple of days and see what the real problem with your rules are. It's not the drivers of trucks.

comment: Why don't you watch a super speed way race on NASCAR to see what spped limiters do and then think about what theat will do to our highways. I think yif you limit trucks then you should limit ALL vehicles to governed speed. I think this will just back up all the trucks in the right lane and no trucks can pass each other because they all go the same speed. I think this is just so all the BIG companies can try to squeeze the little companies out of business since by all having to drive the same speed.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802d4e7a', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'NHTSA-2007-26851-0012-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '4420 West Tennessee Avenue', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'NHTSA', 'city': 'Denver', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Speed Limiters is just another gimick of the big trucking companies to try to retain their drivers. If the ATA and the big trucking companies were really concerned about safety on the highways, they would restrict their trucks to the right lanes on Interstates. I have seen too many trucks from Werner, Swift, J.B. Hunt, etc, pull out in front of cars going 70 to 80 mph to pass another truck that is governed at approximately the same speed. I have seen too many cars and trucks have to slam on their brakes to avoid a rear end collision. The drivers for these big companies with governed trucks are very inconsiderte of the trucks and cars who are actually doing the posted speed limit. These large trucking companies are a big safety hazard to the motoring public! My truck can go the speed limit, but, I never pull out in front of a car that is going in excess of the speed limit. But, then, my boss does not tell me I have to drive at least 650 miles each day. My husband and I drive the speed limit, and even when we are in Nebr., Colo, UT, NM, or Arizona, we cannot, nor, do not drive 650 miles in 11 hours of driving. We normally can only drive around 625 miles in an 11 hour period when the speed limit is 75 mph. When we are up in OH, IL, MI, etc, we usually only drive 500 miles per shift. I still have not figured out how the big trucking companies can insist that their drivers go at least 650 miles when their trucks do not go 75 mph like mine does.

Oh, I know, I drive legally!!!!! When I come to a reduced speed zone (like 25 mph down a mountain, or 45 mph in a construction zone), I slow done. It amazes me how many of the trucks from the large trucking companies pass me. These large companies have their trucks governed and yet require so many miles per day. Their governed trucks, in no way, promote safety on our highways!

I can't tell you how many times I have passed an England or CRST truck, only to have them pass me in a construction zone when the left lane is ending. Then, they pull in front of me and cut me off. This behavior is not safety oriented in any way. With snow, rain, fog and other road conditions, trucks who are governed at 68 mph should only average 50 to 55 mph, or 600 miles, or less, in an 11 hour driving period.

Safety is not acheived by governing the speed of the truck. Safety is achieved by the safe truck drivers and companies who understand that even though the truck may be governed, the driver cannot consistantly run at the maximum speed.

When the weather conditions are bad, most owner/operators, and safe drivers slow down considerably or find a place to park. The company drivers, who drive for the BIG companies continue down the road with their foot held to the floor. They may be governed at 68 mph, but, that speed is too fast for the road conditions. Is it the big companies, or their dispatchers sitting behind a desk in a warm, cozy office that don't comprehend the safety aspect of driving a big truck?

As stated earlier, speed limiters will not provide safer highways. But, I suggest that all large companies require their trucks to stay in the right lane and not be allowed to pass any vehicle. I will probably pass them going up Vail pass, but, they will be required to slow down to 40 mph when I am in front of them and I slow down to descend down the pass going into Vail.

The best speed limiters are good safe drivers, NOT, trucks that are governed.
', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'NHTSA-2007-26851', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Bev', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802d5050', 'lastName': 'Fitzwater', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2008-01-04T01:45:28Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'CO', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Bev Fitzwater - Comments', 'trackingNbr': '802d5050', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '80219', 'openForComment': False}
comment:

I have seen too many trucks from Werner, Swift, J.B. Hunt, etc, pull out in front of cars going 70 to 80 mph to pass another truck that is governed at approximately the same speed. I have seen too many cars and trucks have to slam on their brakes to avoid a rear end collision.
