These large trucking companies are a big safety hazard to the motoring public! My truck can go the speed limit, but, I never pull out in front of a car that is going in excess of the speed limit. But, then, my boss does not tell me I have to drive at least 650 miles each day. My husband and I drive the speed limit, and even when we are in Nebr., Colo, UT, NM, or Arizona, we cannot, nor, do not drive 650 miles in 11 hours of driving. We normally can only drive around 625 miles in an 11 hour period when the speed limit is 75 mph. When we are up in OH, IL, MI, etc, we usually only drive 500 miles per shift. I still have not figured out how the big trucking companies can insist that their drivers go at least 650 miles when their trucks do not go 75 mph like mine does.

Oh, I know, I drive legally!!!!! When I come to a reduced speed zone (like 25 mph down a mountain, or 45 mph in a construction zone), I slow done. It amazes me how many of the trucks from the large trucking companies pass me. These large companies have their trucks governed and yet require so many miles per day. Their governed trucks, in no way, promote safety on our highways!

I can't tell you how many times I have passed an England or CRST truck, only to have them pass me in a construction zone when the left lane is ending. Then, they pull in front of me and cut me off. This behavior is not safety oriented in any way. With snow, rain, fog and other road conditions, trucks who are governed at 68 mph should only average 50 to 55 mph, or 600 miles, or less, in an 11 hour driving period.

Safety is not acheived by governing the speed of the truck. Safety is achieved by the safe truck drivers and companies who understand that even though the truck may be governed, the driver cannot consistantly run at the maximum speed.

When the weather conditions are bad, most owner/operators, and safe drivers slow down considerably or find a place to park. The company drivers, who drive for the BIG companies continue down the road with their foot held to the floor. They may be governed at 68 mph, but, that speed is too fast for the road conditions. Is it the big companies, or their dispatchers sitting behind a desk in a warm, cozy office that don't comprehend the safety aspect of driving a big truck?

As stated earlier, speed limiters will not provide safer highways. But, I suggest that all large companies require their trucks to stay in the right lane and not be allowed to pass any vehicle. I will probably pass them going up Vail pass, but, they will be required to slow down to 40 mph when I am in front of them and I slow down to descend down the pass going into Vail.

The best speed limiters are good safe drivers, NOT, trucks that are governed.

{'commentOn': '09000064802cbc05', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2007-27010-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '1, Rond-Point Maurice Bellonte', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Blagnac', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Comment to NPRM Docket N° FAA-2007-27010.

Airbus kindly inform FAA that Revision 1 of SB A300-28-6077 was released to operators on 26, October 2006. A copy of the SB is sent in parallel to the Manager, International Branch.

No additional work was introduced by Revision 1. We then hereby request FAA to take SB A300-28-6077 revision 1 into account in this proposed rulemaking.

Airbus appreciates the opportunity to comment on this NPRM.

Sincerely,

Valia Smith
A300/A310/A300-600 Continued Airworthiness Engineer
EAWA - Airbus central entity

comment:
Comment to NPRM Docket N° FAA-2007-27010.

Airbus kindly inform FAA that Revision 1 of SB A300-28-6077 was released to operators on 26, October 2006. A copy of the SB is sent in parallel to the Manager, International Branch.

No additional work was introduced by Revision 1. We then hereby request FAA to take SB A300-28-6077 revision 1 into account in this proposed rulemaking.

Airbus appreciates the opportunity to comment on this NPRM.

Sincerely,

Valia Smith
A300/A310/A300-600 Continued Airworthiness Engineer
EAWA - Airbus central entity

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802caafb', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940-0009', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '626 East Russell Road', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FMCSA', 'city': 'Sidney', 'category': None, 'comment': '
I am a company driver for a major carrier with just 3 yrs experience, and I have mixed emotions about EOBR's. I am liking the proposal of targeting the worst carriers with a 2yr penalty for HOS violations & the appeals process for those on border.

Unfortuantely, EORB's aren't going to address bigger issues with HOS compliance. The inflexibility of the 14 hr rule combined with "just in time" freight forces drivers into difficult situations everyday. A driver can lose much of what's left of their 14, if they are detained at a customer beyond a reasonable 3 hrs. That driver tries to do the best they can with what they have left over, only to discover that they are in an area where safe, legal parking for CMVs is at a premium. Their options are limited by this time. Some are so scared of violating HOS that they create a hazard in the parking lot by blocking other drivers in. Others will find a ramp or some other location to comply with HOS, or just keep on going til they find that elusive safe legal parking space.

Even with privacy concerns, EORB's can have an unintended side effects for a driver, if he/she decides to leave an EORB required company. A new potential employer can look up the driver's DAC & his/her present company's safety rating. An EOBR may give some potential employers a second thought about hiring a driver. EOBR's will make that more difficult for the industry to retain safe veteran drivers because the "black boxes" make many feel that they are in less control of their own lives.

EOBR's may be a great tool to get the worst carriers into compliance, but they still aren't going to address other issues concerning HOS compliance. The inflexibility of the 14 hr rule combined with the demands of just in time freight make a driver's job difficult enough. Also, add a lack of adequate parking in many areas of the country to comply with the 10 hr break. If you can add some flexiblity back to the HOS & encourage brokers & customers to help drivers run legal or pay them for dock time, EOBR's shouldn't be needed, as much. Thank you for the opportunity to comment on EOBR's.

Rebecca Reed
Sidney, OH

', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Rebecca', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802ca901', 'lastName': 'Reed', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-06T22:25:47Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'OH', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Rebecca M. Reed - Comments', 'trackingNbr': '802ca901', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '45365', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I am a company driver for a major carrier with just 3 yrs experience, and I have mixed emotions about EOBR's. I am liking the proposal of targeting the worst carriers with a 2yr penalty for HOS violations & the appeals process for those on border.

Unfortuantely, EORB's aren't going to address bigger issues with HOS compliance. The inflexibility of the 14 hr rule combined with "just in time" freight forces drivers into difficult situations everyday. A driver can lose much of what's left of their 14, if they are detained at a customer beyond a reasonable 3 hrs. That driver tries to do the best they can with what they have left over, only to discover that they are in an area where safe, legal parking for CMVs is at a premium. Their options are limited by this time. Some are so scared of violating HOS that they create a hazard in the parking lot by blocking other drivers in. Others will find a ramp or some other location to comply with HOS, or just keep on going til they find that elusive safe legal parking space.

Even with privacy concerns, EORB's can have an unintended side effects for a driver, if he/she decides to leave an EORB required company. A new potential employer can look up the driver's DAC & his/her present company's safety rating. An EOBR may give some potential employers a second thought about hiring a driver. EOBR's will make that more difficult for the industry to retain safe veteran drivers because the "black boxes" make many feel that they are in less control of their own lives.

EOBR's may be a great tool to get the worst carriers into compliance, but they still aren't going to address other issues concerning HOS compliance. The inflexibility of the 14 hr rule combined with the demands of just in time freight make a driver's job difficult enough. Also, add a lack of adequate parking in many areas of the country to comply with the 10 hr break. If you can add some flexiblity back to the HOS & encourage brokers & customers to help drivers run legal or pay them for dock time, EOBR's shouldn't be needed, as much. Thank you for the opportunity to comment on EOBR's.

Rebecca Reed
Sidney, OH

{'commentOn': '09000064802caafb', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940-0009', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': 'P.O. Box 151', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FMCSA', 'city': 'Talbott', 'category': None, 'comment': "I agree with some of your propasal,I do not agree with any part that will make these eobr required on all trucks or even all new trucks. I agree that we have a lot of safety problems in this industry,but these recorders will not address any of our main problems,one of which is companys hireing and untrained or undertrained drivers. I would support any proposal that would only require these on companys or drivers that continue to have serious violations .You will also need to change the 14 hour rule back to what it was before the last change that did not help anyone,it made drivers either drive unsafe or be forced to falsify there logs.I have talked to several expierenced drivers that have been driving for several years and they all feel the same as I do. You will impact this industry too much if you force this rule to be on all trucks.Most of us older experienced law abiding drivers will just quit the business.I wll quit the day that I am forced to drive with oun of these devices. You need to address more of the real problems in this industry,ie" companys hireing illegals,and the fact that companys and driving schools every day turn out drivers that are not trained well enough to drive anything especially a heavy truck.
I beg you please don't make these required on all trucks,because I need 8 to 10 more tears to retire and you will loose a dedicated safe driver if you do this.
Thank you for reading my coment,if you actually do read them.
The last thing I have to say is that you would get a lot more coments if you would make it a little easer.You should make it as easy as sending an email. All you would need is a email address.
THANK YOU
E.L.McMahan
", 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Ed', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802ca90d', 'lastName': 'McMahan', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-06T22:26:02Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'TN', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Ed L. You will impact this industry too much if you force this rule to be on all trucks.Most of us older experienced law abiding drivers will just quit the business.I wll quit the day that I am forced to drive with oun of these devices. You need to address more of the real problems in this industry,ie" companys hireing illegals,and the fact that companys and driving schools every day turn out drivers that are not trained well enough to drive anything especially a heavy truck.
I beg you please don't make these required on all trucks,because I need 8 to 10 more tears to retire and you will loose a dedicated safe driver if you do this.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802caafb', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940-0009', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '1610 West County Road 326', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FMCSA', 'city': 'Jourdanton', 'category': None, 'comment': "I think that speed limiters are a bad idea. If a company wants to limit the speed of their trucks on there own that is their perogative. We don't need more government regulation to tell us we can't travel at the posted speed limits. If the speed limit is 70 and the state thinks that is a safe speed for the motoring public, then we should be able to travel at that speed when conditions allow it.
I have been driving for 13 years and have witnessed the dangers of split speed limits. In my opinion it is safer when all vehichles ar traveling at a uniform speed. I get nervous in states where cars can go 70 mph and I am restricted to 55. I think that is dangerous.

thank you,
Marc Wisnosky
", 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Marc', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802ca90e', 'lastName': 'Wisnosky', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-06T22:26:04Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'TX', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Marc H. comment:
I think that speed limiters are a bad idea. If a company wants to limit the speed of their trucks on there own that is their perogative. We don't need more government regulation to tell us we can't travel at the posted speed limits. If the speed limit is 70 and the state thinks that is a safe speed for the motoring public, then we should be able to travel at that speed when conditions allow it.
I have been driving for 13 years and have witnessed the dangers of split speed limits. In my opinion it is safer when all vehichles ar traveling at a uniform speed. I get nervous in states where cars can go 70 mph and I am restricted to 55. I think that is dangerous.

thank you,
Marc Wisnosky

{'commentOn': '09000064802caafb', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940-0009', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '6617 Woodsman Drive', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FMCSA', 'city': 'Wesley Chapel', 'category': None, 'comment': 'I SURE HOPE THAR YOU RECIEVE PLENTY OF COMENTSON THIS SUBJECT. MINE ARE AS FOLLOWS.I WISH MY JOB WAS AS SIMPLE AS A 9 TO 5 JOB. BUT IT IS NOT. I AM SURE THAT YOU HAVE HEARD THAT THERE SEVERAL WAYS TO REACH ANY GOAL. AND THAT IS THE PROBLEM. WHO IS TO SAY ONE WAY IS BETTER THAN THE OTHER.YOU HAVE SPENT A LOT OF TIME HAVING THIS STUDIED. BUT I WOULD SUGEST THAT PERHAPS EITHER ON A WEEKEND OR MABY ON YOUR VACATION. PLAN A TRIP TO DRIVE 10 HOURS AND SPEND THE NIGHT AT THAT SPOT.THE RUB BEING THAT ONCE YOU HAVE DRIVEN THOSE 10 HOURS YOU MUST STOP. NO MATTER WHAT. TO EVEN DRIVE ACCROSS THE STREET WOULD BE ILLIGEL. THAT IS WHAT WE ARE UP AGAINST ON THE ROAD. WHEN A SHIPPER SCHULES A LOAD TO BE DELIVERED HE FIGURES YOU WILL DRIVE THE MAXIMUM AMOUNT OF TIME EACH DAY. SO, YOU CAN NOT STOP SHORT TODAY AND MAKE IT UP TOMORROW.IF YOU ARE 15 MINUTES LATE YOU MUST RESET YOUR APPOINTMENT FOR THE NEXT DAY. WHICH MESSES EVERYTHING UP. AND BELIEVE ME IT HAPPENS EVERY DAY.I THINK YOU HAVE TO FIND AWAY TO BRING SHIPPERS AND RECIEVERS UNDER YOUR UMBRELLA ALSO. BECAUSE WE THE DRIVERS ARE THE ONLY ONES THAT HAVE SO MANY TIME RESTRITIONS. THE SHIPPER CAN HOLD US AS LONG AS THEY WANT AND THE RECIEVERS CAN ALSO HOLD US AS LONG AS THEY WANT.JUST IMAGINE IF EVERY ONE IN YOUR OFFICE COULD DO THERE JOB ANY WAY THEY WANTED, BUT YOU HAD AN EXACT TIME TO GET YOUR JOB DONE AND IT DEPENDED ON THEM GETTING THEIR JOB DONE ON TIME. IF THEY DO NOT GET THEIRS DONE ON TIME NOTHING HAPPINS BUT IF YOU DO NOT GET YOURS DONE YOU WILL BE FIND OR FIRED. NOTHING CAN BE SUCCESFUL THAT WAY.I HOPE YOU CAN UNDERSTAND WHAT I AM SAYING, IT IS A LOT EASIER TO EXPLAIN IN PERSON AND I DO NOT SE HOW YOU CAN DO THAT. THANK YOU FOR YOUR TIME.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802caafb', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940-0009', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '15 Lazy Boy Lane', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FMCSA', 'city': 'Hendersonville', 'category': None, 'comment': "Please, someone save us from ourselves! I understand that people like Joan Claybrook of Public Citizen are under the gun to show leadership. We have difficult problems and we need courageous people like Ms. Claybrook to step up to deal with them. I have a problem however with something that resembles mindless, politically-correct ignorance. The Salem witch trials come to mind. There are other modern examples.
As an educated truck driver I can tell you that transportation is not as safe as it could be. It is an inherently dangerous activity. I can tell you that it takes courage to drive a truck. Even if they could get past their first year, most people would not do this job. I am of above average intelligence and I found that over the years, for many different reasons, it was almost impossible to continue driving. I kept at it. I am actually more comfortable now with the risks, but the risks are there.
I would like to see more science used to solve our problems rather than use technology to impose some questionable control. For example, how many drivers know the science of driving? From a physics book I recall something about which most people have no idea. Years ago I read that an object in uniform circlular motion is accelerating. Only recently did I understand what this meant. It means that every time you turn the wheel, the vehicle is accelerating. Many people know that you brake before going into a curve and then accelerate through it. They don't know an object accelerates as a physical phenomenon.A good example is how a bull whip works. The arm propels the whip at a modest speed. The tip of the whip breaks the sound barrier. I'd like to see our leaders use knowledge like this when they crack their whips.
One other thing that driving students should know. When an object it coming toward you, for example, a motorcycle coming toward you at an intersection, it should be known that you cannot judge an objects speed. The only thing a person can see is that the object gets larger as it approaches. It is easy to determine an objects speed when it is moving across the horizon. You sure don't want objects flying at you but this is the case everywhere you look on the road.
Good luck! Al

", 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Jonathan', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802ca918', 'lastName': 'Klees', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-06T22:26:15Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'WI', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Jonathan Klees - Comments', 'trackingNbr': '802ca918', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '28792', 'openForComment': False}

From a physics book I recall something about which most people have no idea. Years ago I read that an object in uniform circlular motion is accelerating. Only recently did I understand what this meant. It means that every time you turn the wheel, the vehicle is accelerating. Many people know that you brake before going into a curve and then accelerate through it. They don't know an object accelerates as a physical phenomenon.A good example is how a bull whip works. The arm propels the whip at a modest speed. The tip of the whip breaks the sound barrier. I'd like to see our leaders use knowledge like this when they crack their whips.
One other thing that driving students should know. When an object it coming toward you, for example, a motorcycle coming toward you at an intersection, it should be known that you cannot judge an objects speed. The only thing a person can see is that the object gets larger as it approaches. It is easy to determine an objects speed when it is moving across the horizon. You sure don't want objects flying at you but this is the case everywhere you look on the road.
Good luck! Al

{'commentOn': '09000064802caafb', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940-0009', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '220 Henry Road', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FMCSA', 'city': 'Madison', 'category': None, 'comment': 'I run team with my wife and I believe you should go back to the old hours for teams-you just cannot sleep 10 hours in a rolling truck. 5 hours on and 5 off was so much easier, and we were more rested when it was our turn to drive. I really like the 34 hours off to reset the clock. I don't feel like the need for black boxes in the team trucks has arrived. Owner-operators maybe... Thanks, Tom Walter

comment: I run team with my wife and I believe you should go back to the old hours for teams-you just cannot sleep 10 hours in a rolling truck. 5 hours on and 5 off was so much easier, and we were more rested when it was our turn to drive. I really like the 34 hours off to reset the clock. I don't feel like the need for black boxes in the team trucks has arrived. Owner-operators maybe... Thanks, Tom Walter

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802caafb', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940-0009', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FMCSA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': "Docket number FMCSA-2004-18940

This is concerning the automatic on board computers.

I think the FMCSA could solve the problem of H.O.S violations fairly easily if carriers put safety ahead of profit.
What you would need to do is require all interstate motor carriers to pay their drivers on an hourly basis. They would be free to pay any hourly amount as long as it was above the minimum wage.
There is really only one segment of the industry that is commiting 95% of the H.O.S violations and that is the irregular route truckload carriers. The easiest way to find the carriers that abuse the H.O.S rules the most is to find the carriers with the biggest driver turnover rate. The truckload carriers all pay component pay (miles,stops,ect.) and there is no financial incentive for the carriers to enforce the H.O.S rules. There however is a huge financial incentive for the carriers to break the rules. When drivers that are paid componant pay rather than hourly pay the cost to the carrier is the same per mile regardless if the driver works 14 or 18 hours per day. The carrier will increase their revenue the more miles driven per day.
My experience is the part of the H.O.S regulations most abused is the 14 hour rule and 70 / 8 day rule not the 11 hour driving rule. If drivers were paid hourly and were allowed state type labor protections they would earn over time as hours increased and the cost to the carrier would also increase causing a disincentive to over work drivers.
Truckload carriers also have a very strange way they pay drivers. Truckload drivers earn an amount per mile based on( shortest route ) computer miles, but the catch is the driver because of time or type of roads cannot drive the shortest route.
This means the driver drives an average of 10% more than they are paid. Example - If you drive enough miles to equal $1000. of pay per week you would only be paid $900. try that with the employees of the D.O.T .
Another issue a driver faces with regards to H.O.S rules is the mixed messages He/She will receive from a carriers management. On one hand the safety department will be telling a driver by memo that they must follow the rules regarding H.O.S . Having the driver sign documents stating the carrier rules regarding H.O.S and at the same time dispatch will be loading the driver up with work that is impossible to complete legally. If the driver decides to follow the rules they will - 1.) start to receive the worst runs , both in financial terms and delivery problems ( delays,traffic,NYC deliveries
2.) Most drivers because of low pay need to make those extra runs which cause them to break the rules.
I think all trucks should have the automatic on board computers installed on them in the future. I will leave the way that is accomplished to people with more expertise than me, however I do not think the driving public will be safer until the driver compensation issues are resolved.

Thank you for the opportunity to present my opinion.
K. Gibbons
", 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'K.', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802ca929', 'lastName': 'Gibbons', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-06T22:26:36Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'K. Gibbons - Comments', 'trackingNbr': '802ca929', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}

Docket number FMCSA-2004-18940

This is concerning the automatic on board computers.

I think the FMCSA could solve the problem of H.O.S violations fairly easily if carriers put safety ahead of profit.
What you would need to do is require all interstate motor carriers to pay their drivers on an hourly basis. They would be free to pay any hourly amount as long as it was above the minimum wage.
There is really only one segment of the industry that is commiting 95% of the H.O.S violations and that is the irregular route truckload carriers. The easiest way to find the carriers that abuse the H.O.S rules the most is to find the carriers with the biggest driver turnover rate. The truckload carriers all pay component pay (miles,stops,ect.) and there is no financial incentive for the carriers to enforce the H.O.S rules. There however is a huge financial incentive for the carriers to break the rules. When drivers that are paid componant pay rather than hourly pay the cost to the carrier is the same per mile regardless if the driver works 14 or 18 hours per day. The carrier will increase their revenue the more miles driven per day.
My experience is the part of the H.O.S regulations most abused is the 14 hour rule and 70 / 8 day rule not the 11 hour driving rule. If drivers were paid hourly and were allowed state type labor protections they would earn over time as hours increased and the cost to the carrier would also increase causing a disincentive to over work drivers.
Truckload carriers also have a very strange way they pay drivers. Truckload drivers earn an amount per mile based on( shortest route ) computer miles, but the catch is the driver because of time or type of roads cannot drive the shortest route.
This means the driver drives an average of 10% more than they are paid. Example - If you drive enough miles to equal $1000. of pay per week you would only be paid $900. try that with the employees of the D.O.T .
Another issue a driver faces with regards to H.O.S rules is the mixed messages He/She will receive from a carriers management. On one hand the safety department will be telling a driver by memo that they must follow the rules regarding H.O.S . Having the driver sign documents stating the carrier rules regarding H.O.S and at the same time dispatch will be loading the driver up with work that is impossible to complete legally. If the driver decides to follow the rules they will - 1.) start to receive the worst runs , both in financial terms and delivery problems ( delays,traffic,NYC deliveries
2.) Most drivers because of low pay need to make those extra runs which cause them to break the rules.
I think all trucks should have the automatic on board computers installed on them in the future. I will leave the way that is accomplished to people with more expertise than me, however I do not think the driving public will be safer until the driver compensation issues are resolved.

Thank you for the opportunity to present my opinion.
K. Gibbons

I am stand in oposition to the industry wide use of E.O.D.R.'s however I believe that the latest proposal is a good step toward pasification of special intrest groups and political preasure. Further if this proposal is inacted I believe it "may" help to bring less than safety minded carriers into awareness of the modern dynamics of the industry and leave those of us who attempt to project a positive and safety minded public image from the tremendous expense and punishment brought to light by our less than desirable counterparts. I urge you go ahead with your suggested measures and not require industry wide use. The profit margins are just to thin for owner operators to comply with a total requirement. comment: We in the trucking industry are all interested in safer highways. I have invested more than a third of my life in this persuit and have a safety record that is second to none. I am stand in oposition to the industry wide use of E.O.D.R.'s however I believe that the latest proposal is a good step toward pasification of special intrest groups and political preasure. Further if this proposal is inacted I believe it "may" help to bring less than safety minded carriers into awareness of the modern dynamics of the industry and leave those of us who attempt to project a positive and safety minded public image from the tremendous expense and punishment brought to light by our less than desirable counterparts. I urge you go ahead with your suggested measures and not require industry wide use. The profit margins are just to thin for owner operators to comply with a total requirement. Thank you for your consideration. Ira Doss

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802caafb', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940-0009', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FMCSA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'As a driver for 1.5 million miles, I really don't have any major issues with the OBR plan that FMCSA has announced. I currently work for a company that verifies my logbook accuracy against the Qualcomm's GPS location. The only concern I have is that if my company is one that is selected for mandatory use of an OBR or if they choose to volunteer to take part in the program, that the option of 'off duty personal use' is there. From time to time I have excess time when at company termianls in which I am permitted to drop the load that I am dispatched on, and use the truck for personal needs, such as shopping, food, or entertainment. All personal use, within a certain radius of the location logged off duty is permitted, just as long as the truck shows returning to the same location before beginning on duty status. I hope that the OBR's would have the option of being able to show a difference in on duty and off duty use.
', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FMCSA-2004-18940', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Anonymous', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802ca909', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-06T22:25:56Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Anonymous - Comments', 'trackingNbr': '802ca909', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: As a driver for 1.5 million miles, I really don't have any major issues with the OBR plan that FMCSA has announced. I currently work for a company that verifies my logbook accuracy against the Qualcomm's GPS location. The only concern I have is that if my company is one that is selected for mandatory use of an OBR or if they choose to volunteer to take part in the program, that the option of 'off duty personal use' is there. From time to time I have excess time when at company termianls in which I am permitted to drop the load that I am dispatched on, and use the truck for personal needs, such as shopping, food, or entertainment. All personal use, within a certain radius of the location logged off duty is permitted, just as long as the truck shows returning to the same location before beginning on duty status. I hope that the OBR's would have the option of being able to show a difference in on duty and off duty use.

comment:
As an avid boater and fisherman, I strongly recommend continuation of
eLORAN development and implementation. I always use LORAN and GPS
both, for position location on my offshore journeys. LORAN is not
just a backup for GPS, it is an excellent facility for cross-checking
position. eLORAN will make even more accurate and reliable.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802c841d', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCG-2006-24685-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCG', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'The Loran-C system should be continued in it's present form. I've been flying since '68 and love it. GPS is wonderful and I use it too. When flying instruments, you really must have a back-up. I don't know which backs up the other, but they work well together.

We know that solar flares might disrupt GPS operation, our military has demonstrated that hackers or terrorists can render GPS vulnerable, China has shown that they can knock out satelites with their missles. In emergency situations, Loran-C can be easily hardened against Electro-magnetic Pulse. Because of so few stations, can be more easily defended from terrorism. Because it's already in place, the cost to maintain would be a scintillion of what another system might cost. Yes, it's old and based on old technology, but it does the same now and is just as reliable as it was back then.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Ed Dobson

', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'USCG-2006-24685', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Ed', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802c8885', 'lastName': 'Dobson', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2008-01-04T01:28:18Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2007-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Ed Dobson', 'trackingNbr': '802c8885', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
The Loran-C system should be continued in it's present form. I've been flying since '68 and love it. GPS is wonderful and I use it too. When flying instruments, you really must have a back-up. I don't know which backs up the other, but they work well together.

We know that solar flares might disrupt GPS operation, our military has demonstrated that hackers or terrorists can render GPS vulnerable, China has shown that they can knock out satelites with their missles. In emergency situations, Loran-C can be easily hardened against Electro-magnetic Pulse. Because of so few stations, can be more easily defended from terrorism. Because it's already in place, the cost to maintain would be a scintillion of what another system might cost. Yes, it's old and based on old technology, but it does the same now and is just as reliable as it was back then.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Ed Dobson

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006483d1d6c2', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FNS-2019-0001-6698', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FNS', 'city': 'Saint Albans', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Dear Secretary Sonny Perdue,

The updated 2020-2025 Dietary Guidelines for Americans will, for the first time, include recommendations for infants and toddlers up to the age of 24 monthsaffecting the health of millions of kids now and in the future.

It is essential that these recommendations contain age appropriate advice based on the best available science. Developing added sugar limits for children, including the science-based recommendation that children under two eat no added sugar, is especially important for protecting their health.

Given the conflict of interest, food industry representatives or others with a political interest in the outcome of these guidelines should be excluded from the dietary guideline development and review process.

Many Americans encounter constant messages from certain food companies, promoting foods and beverages that should, on the basis of good health, be only rare treats. Please provide the essential, substantial, message counterweight to remind us of appropriate eating habits.

I strongly urge the Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee, the US Department of Agriculture, and the US Department of Health and Human Services to develop guidelines that are consistent with current science and prioritize vulnerable communities, especially when it comes to infants and toddlers.

Sincerely,
Ms. Mary Harbaugh
100 Congress St Saint Albans, VT 05478-1646
mary@strongstreet.com', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FNS-2019-0001', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Mary', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006484086f6b', 'lastName': 'Harbaugh', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2019-10-11T20:05:52Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2019-10-11T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2019-10-11T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'VT', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2019-12806', 'trackingNbr': '1k3-9coc-71hh', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Dear Secretary Sonny Perdue,

The updated 2020-2025 Dietary Guidelines for Americans will, for the first time, include recommendations for infants and toddlers up to the age of 24 monthsaffecting the health of millions of kids now and in the future.

It is essential that these recommendations contain age appropriate advice based on the best available science. Developing added sugar limits for children, including the science-based recommendation that children under two eat no added sugar, is especially important for protecting their health.

Given the conflict of interest, food industry representatives or others with a political interest in the outcome of these guidelines should be excluded from the dietary guideline development and review process.

Many Americans encounter constant messages from certain food companies, promoting foods and beverages that should, on the basis of good health, be only rare treats. Please provide the essential, substantial, message counterweight to remind us of appropriate eating habits.

I strongly urge the Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee, the US Department of Agriculture, and the US Department of Health and Human Services to develop guidelines that are consistent with current science and prioritize vulnerable communities, especially when it comes to infants and toddlers.

Sincerely,
Ms. Mary Harbaugh
100 Congress St Saint Albans, VT 05478-1646
mary@strongstreet.com

Given the conflict of interest, food industry representatives or others with a political interest in the outcome of these guidelines should be excluded from the dietary guideline development and review process.

I strongly urge the Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee, the US Department of Agriculture, and the US Department of Health and Human Services to develop guidelines that are consistent with current science and prioritize vulnerable communities, especially when it comes to infants and toddlers.

{'commentOn': '0900006483d1d6c2', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FNS-2019-0001-6698', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FNS', 'city': 'Lakeport', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Dear Secretary Sonny Perdue,

The updated 2020-2025 Dietary Guidelines for Americans will, for the first time, include recommendations for infants and toddlers up to the age of 24 monthsaffecting the health of millions of kids now and in the future.

It is essential that these recommendations contain age appropriate advice based on the best available science. Developing added sugar limits for children, including the science-based recommendation that children under two eat no added sugar, is especially important for protecting their health.

Given the conflict of interest, food industry representatives or others with a political interest in the outcome of these guidelines should be excluded from the dietary guideline development and review process.

I strongly urge the Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee, the US Department of Agriculture, and the US Department of Health and Human Services to develop guidelines that are consistent with current science and prioritize vulnerable communities, especially when it comes to infants and toddlers.

Sincerely,
Mr. Fred Squires
PO Box 1834 Lakeport, CA 95453-1834

comment:
Dear Secretary Sonny Perdue,

The updated 2020-2025 Dietary Guidelines for Americans will, for the first time, include recommendations for infants and toddlers up to the age of 24 monthsaffecting the health of millions of kids now and in the future.

It is essential that these recommendations contain age appropriate advice based on the best available science. Developing added sugar limits for children, including the science-based recommendation that children under two eat no added sugar, is especially important for protecting their health.

Given the conflict of interest, food industry representatives or others with a political interest in the outcome of these guidelines should be excluded from the dietary guideline development and review process.

I strongly urge the Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee, the US Department of Agriculture, and the US Department of Health and Human Services to develop guidelines that are consistent with current science and prioritize vulnerable communities, especially when it comes to infants and toddlers.

Sincerely,
Mr. Fred Squires
PO Box 1834 Lakeport, CA 95453-1834
fredxpress@hotmail.com

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006483ff1b87', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'NOAA-NMFS-2019-0113-0002', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'NOAA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'As a member of Mystic Aquarium I support its petition to import beluga whales for the following reasons:

Mystic Aquarium is a better home for these 5 beluga whales than their
current home at MarineLand Canada. The Mystic facility is the largest
outdoor beluga whale habitat in the United States and is a lab-equipped
institution that conducts extensive conservation research on the health of
belugas; non-invasive research that would not be possible without a cohort
of whales. Mystic Aquarium is also accredited by the Association of Zoos &
Aquariums as meeting the highest standards in animal care.
The whales that Mystic is asking to import were born in human care and
would not survive in the wild. Mystics state-of-the-art facility is the best
option for the well-being of the whales.
Mystic is importing these whales for conservation research purposes, not
exclusively for public display. The non-invasive research conducted on these
whales will be used to help protect depleted wild populations of beluga
whales across the globe.
In order to protect potentially endangered species like beluga whales, it is
essential that facilities like Mystic Aquarium are able to conduct noninvasive research and observe whales in human care.
Mystics permit application meets the Marine Mammal Commissions
requirements for importing beluga whales for research purposes and should
be approved.

Sincerely,

Cathy Milkofsky
Chester, CT ', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'NOAA-NMFS-2019-0113', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'CATHERINE', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006484088400', 'lastName': 'MILKOFSKY', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2019-10-11T19:45:51Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 1, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2019-10-11T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2019-10-11T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment from CATHERINE MILKOFSKY', 'trackingNbr': '1k3-9cof-1zey', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
As a member of Mystic Aquarium I support its petition to import beluga whales for the following reasons:

Mystic Aquarium is a better home for these 5 beluga whales than their
current home at MarineLand Canada. The Mystic facility is the largest
outdoor beluga whale habitat in the United States and is a lab-equipped
institution that conducts extensive conservation research on the health of
belugas; non-invasive research that would not be possible without a cohort
of whales. Mystic Aquarium is also accredited by the Association of Zoos &
Aquariums as meeting the highest standards in animal care.
The whales that Mystic is asking to import were born in human care and
would not survive in the wild. Mystics state-of-the-art facility is the best
option for the well-being of the whales.
Mystic is importing these whales for conservation research purposes, not
exclusively for public display. The non-invasive research conducted on these
whales will be used to help protect depleted wild populations of beluga
whales across the globe.
In order to protect potentially endangered species like beluga whales, it is
essential that facilities like Mystic Aquarium are able to conduct noninvasive research and observe whales in human care.
Mystics permit application meets the Marine Mammal Commissions
requirements for importing beluga whales for research purposes and should
be approved.

Sincerely,

Cathy Milkofsky
Chester, CT

The Mystic facility is the largest outdoor beluga whale habitat in the United Statesand is a lab-equipped institution that conducts extensive conservation research on the health of belugas; non-invasive research that would not be possible without a cohort of whales. Mystic Aquarium is also accredited by the Association of Zoos & Aquariums as meeting the highest standards in animal care.

Mystic Aquarium is known for their exceptional treatment of animals and since these animals were never free they would not make it in the wild. Why not help to secure the species future?!? ', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'NOAA-NMFS-2019-0113', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Alexis', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '090000648407ea52', 'lastName': 'Anonymous', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2019-10-11T19:33:21Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 1, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2019-10-11T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2019-10-10T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment from Alexis Anonymous', 'trackingNbr': '1k3-9cnv-d9n9', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Mystic Aquarium is a better home for these 5 beluga whales than their current home at MarineLandCanada. The Mystic facility is the largest outdoor beluga whale habitat in the United Statesand is a lab-equipped institution that conducts extensive conservation research on the health of belugas; non-invasive research that would not be possible without a cohort of whales. Mystic Aquarium is also accredited by the Association of Zoos & Aquariums as meeting the highest standards in animal care.

Mystic Aquarium is known for their exceptional treatment of animals and since these animals were never free they would not make it in the wild. Why not help to secure the species future?!?

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006483d1d6c2', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FNS-2019-0001-6698', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FNS', 'city': 'Fayetteville', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Dear Secretary Sonny Perdue,

The updated 2020-2025 Dietary Guidelines for Americans will, for the first time, include recommendations for infants and toddlers up to the age of 24 monthsaffecting the health of millions of kids now and in the future.

It is essential that these recommendations contain age appropriate advice based on the best available science. Developing added sugar limits for children, including the science-based recommendation that children under two eat no added sugar, is especially important for protecting their health.

Given the conflict of interest, food industry representatives or others with a political interest in the outcome of these guidelines should be excluded from the dietary guideline development and review process.

I strongly urge the Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee, the US Department of Agriculture, and the US Department of Health and Human Services to develop guidelines that are consistent with current science and prioritize vulnerable communities, especially when it comes to infants and toddlers.

Sincerely,
Dr. David Nikkel
1926 N Pearl St Fayetteville, NC 28303-4341
david.nikkel@uncp.edu', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FNS-2019-0001', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'David', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '090000648408896b', 'lastName': 'Nikkel', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2019-10-11T20:05:32Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2019-10-11T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2019-10-11T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'NC', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2019-12806', 'trackingNbr': '1k3-9cof-d0x8', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Dear Secretary Sonny Perdue,

The updated 2020-2025 Dietary Guidelines for Americans will, for the first time, include recommendations for infants and toddlers up to the age of 24 monthsaffecting the health of millions of kids now and in the future.

It is essential that these recommendations contain age appropriate advice based on the best available science. Developing added sugar limits for children, including the science-based recommendation that children under two eat no added sugar, is especially important for protecting their health.

Given the conflict of interest, food industry representatives or others with a political interest in the outcome of these guidelines should be excluded from the dietary guideline development and review process.

I strongly urge the Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee, the US Department of Agriculture, and the US Department of Health and Human Services to develop guidelines that are consistent with current science and prioritize vulnerable communities, especially when it comes to infants and toddlers.

Sincerely,
Dr. David Nikkel
1926 N Pearl St Fayetteville, NC 28303-4341
david.nikkel@uncp.edu

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006483d1d6c2', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FNS-2019-0001-6698', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FNS', 'city': 'Port Hueneme', 'category': None, 'comment': 'Dear Secretary Sonny Perdue,

The updated 2020-2025 Dietary Guidelines for Americans will, for the first time, include recommendations for infants and toddlers up to the age of 24 monthsaffecting the health of millions of kids now and in the future.

It is essential that these recommendations contain age appropriate advice based on the best available science.

The current science-based recommendation is that children under two should eat no added sugars. In other words, sugar that is a natural part of their food is the only sugar that they should ever eat. This is crucial for protecting their health and ensuring their proper development.

Given the conflict of interest, food industry representatives or others with a political interest in the outcome of these guidelines should be excluded from the dietary guideline development and review process. As an investor in some of these companies, I want to understood that I do NOT agree with their lobbying efforts.

I strongly urge the Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee, the US Department of Agriculture, and the US Department of Health and Human Services to develop guidelines that are consistent with current science and prioritize vulnerable communities, especially when it comes to infants and toddlers.

Sincerely,
Mr. Jim Carleton
1546 N 7th Pl Port Hueneme, CA 93041-2418

As an investor in some of these companies, I want to understood that I do NOT agree with their lobbying efforts.

{'commentOn': '0900006481169eb0', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'CMS-2012-0083-3524', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'CMS', 'city': None, 'category': 'Health Care Professional/Association - Physician', 'comment': 'I am writing to comment on file: CMS-1590-FC. I am a solo private practice neurologist and while I was aware that cuts were coming these drastic changes in such a short amount of time mean from a business standpoint I am caught in a tenuous position. I have no time to adjust revenue streams, adjust my practice focus, etc. I will have to make just as sudden and drastic changes in my business, which means laying off staff, closing the practice to medicare patients or potentially closing my practice completely. No business can adjust this rapidly to drastic cuts in revenue streams.

I am already aware of neurologists closing their practices and moving to large groups in other states or leaving clinical work altogether. This contraction of practitioners in an already small specialty means that patients will have longer wait times to have their studies or not be able to get a study done. This will lead to more frequent incorrect diagnoses or no diagnosis. Ultimately patient's diseases will be more progressive by the time they are finally diagnosed. With the nervous system "time is neurons" so if someone has a compressed nerve and they wait longer for diagnosis and treatment they may not recover fully or at all. This means they could be permanently disabled or unable to return to work. Additionally we know that elderly patients can have confusion from pain so if they are in pain longer they could fall or have other injuries related to these delays. If an elderly patient falls they may have more complicated outcomes requiring more expensive care (i.e. hip fracture requiring surgery).

It is vital that CMS reconsider these drastic and sudden changes in reimbursement. While costs of health care must be brought under control, neurological services are a small contributor to these expenses. Neurology is a small and struggling field and these cuts will compromise patient access and care. Please work with the AAN and AANEM to resolve this crisis.', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'CMS-2012-0083', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '090000648117e93b', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2013-01-18T16:13:20Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2013-01-18T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-12-04T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'RI', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'RI-Jones, Elaine', 'trackingNbr': '1jw-82ci-8056', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I am writing to comment on file: CMS-1590-FC. I am a solo private practice neurologist and while I was aware that cuts were coming these drastic changes in such a short amount of time mean from a business standpoint I am caught in a tenuous position. I have no time to adjust revenue streams, adjust my practice focus, etc. I will have to make just as sudden and drastic changes in my business, which means laying off staff, closing the practice to medicare patients or potentially closing my practice completely. No business can adjust this rapidly to drastic cuts in revenue streams.

I am already aware of neurologists closing their practices and moving to large groups in other states or leaving clinical work altogether. This contraction of practitioners in an already small specialty means that patients will have longer wait times to have their studies or not be able to get a study done. This will lead to more frequent incorrect diagnoses or no diagnosis. Ultimately patient's diseases will be more progressive by the time they are finally diagnosed. With the nervous system "time is neurons" so if someone has a compressed nerve and they wait longer for diagnosis and treatment they may not recover fully or at all. This means they could be permanently disabled or unable to return to work. Additionally we know that elderly patients can have confusion from pain so if they are in pain longer they could fall or have other injuries related to these delays. If an elderly patient falls they may have more complicated outcomes requiring more expensive care (i.e. hip fracture requiring surgery).

It is vital that CMS reconsider these drastic and sudden changes in reimbursement. While costs of health care must be brought under control, neurological services are a small contributor to these expenses. Neurology is a small and struggling field and these cuts will compromise patient access and care. Please work with the AAN and AANEM to resolve this crisis.

{'commentOn': '0900006481169eb0', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'CMS-2012-0083-3524', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'CMS', 'city': None, 'category': 'Physician - HC005', 'comment': 'The cuts will have a severe negative impact on specialty physician practices which inevitably will compromise access of care to Medicare/Medicaid beneficiaries.

The Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) and Electromyography (EMG) if adequately performed involve a degree of complexity technically and professionally that is SIGNIFICANTLY UNDERESTIMATED with the newly proposed Relative Value Unit (RVU).

I ask the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services to work with the American Academy of Neurology (AAN) and the American Association of Electrodiagnostic Medicine (AANEM) to solve this issue.

Thank you,

Juan Ros-Escalante, MD, FAANEM
Diplomate ABPN, Neurology
Diplomate ABPN, Clinical Neurophysiology
Diplomate ABEM, Electrodiagnostic Medicine

Active Member AAN
Fellow Member AANEM

comment:
The cuts will have a severe negative impact on specialty physician practices which inevitably will compromise access of care to Medicare/Medicaid beneficiaries.

The Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) and Electromyography (EMG) if adequately performed involve a degree of complexity technically and professionally that is SIGNIFICANTLY UNDERESTIMATED with the newly proposed Relative Value Unit (RVU).

I ask the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services to work with the American Academy of Neurology (AAN) and the American Association of Electrodiagnostic Medicine (AANEM) to solve this issue.

Thank you,

Juan Ros-Escalante, MD, FAANEM
Diplomate ABPN, Neurology
Diplomate ABPN, Clinical Neurophysiology
Diplomate ABEM, Electrodiagnostic Medicine

Active Member AAN
Fellow Member AANEM

attributes: {'commentOn': '0900006481169eb0', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'CMS-2012-0083-3524', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'CMS', 'city': None, 'category': 'Physician - HC005', 'comment': 'I am a practicing Neurologist for 27 years. I am known to patients and other physicians in my community as an excellent diagnostician. Electrodiagnostic studies have been an extension to my practice in both aiding in difficult diagnostic conditions and their treatment. The severe reduction in reimbusement will make it necessary to defer the time to other patients with other neurological conditions that will not require these studies. Medicine is a very costly business to run. With ever increasing overhead, Neurologists will need to make hard decisions on what type of patients they will continue to treat. Unfortunately, this will lead to less diagnosis and treatment of more complicated patients. Another very unfortunate situation is the countless "non Neurology" electrodiagnostic testing that has been performed throughout our nation by Chiropractors and other charlatans. No interest in our country has been made to raise these tests to the highest level under appropriate physician useage. ', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'CMS-2012-0083', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064811881da', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2013-01-18T14:08:32Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2013-01-18T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-12-11T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'FL', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'FL-Palm Beach Neurology', 'trackingNbr': '1jw-82hf-rtsy', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: I am a practicing Neurologist for 27 years. I am known to patients and other physicians in my community as an excellent diagnostician. Electrodiagnostic studies have been an extension to my practice in both aiding in difficult diagnostic conditions and their treatment. The severe reduction in reimbusement will make it necessary to defer the time to other patients with other neurological conditions that will not require these studies. Medicine is a very costly business to run. With ever increasing overhead, Neurologists will need to make hard decisions on what type of patients they will continue to treat. Unfortunately, this will lead to less diagnosis and treatment of more complicated patients. Another very unfortunate situation is the countless "non Neurology" electrodiagnostic testing that has been performed throughout our nation by Chiropractors and other charlatans. No interest in our country has been made to raise these tests to the highest level under appropriate physician useage.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481169eb0', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'CMS-2012-0083-3524', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'CMS', 'city': None, 'category': 'Physician - HC005', 'comment': 'Ms. Marilyn B. Tavenner
Principal Deputy Administrator, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services
Department of Health and Human Services
RE: CMS-1590-FC [2013 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule; Nerve Conduction Studies/EMG Values]

Dear Ms. Tavenner,
I AM A RECENTLY RETIRED PHYSCIAN WITH "NO SKIN IN THE GAME." As a neurologist who previously routinely used nerve conduction studies and EMG to diagnose patients with neurologic illnesses such as carpal tunnel, ALS, muscular dystrophy, and neuropathies, I am concerned that the values for these tests set by the 2013 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule will not only severely restrict patient access, but will delay timely diagnosis and appropriate treatment of these debilitating conditions.

The announcement of these cuts on November 1 leaves physicians and practices only 60 days to prepare for extraordinarily large cuts.

This testing is labor intensive, requires skill and no small amount of time; under-valuing it will force physicians into other areas (there are many--as you know there is a neurologist shortage) and disadvantage patients.

I strongly urge that you reconsider the scale of these reductions to ensure that Medicare beneficiary access to high quality care is not adversely impacted. I ask that you work with the American Academy of Neurology and other key stakeholders to find a solution to significantly mitigate these cuts to allow more time to adapt to any payment adjustments for nerve conduction studies and EMG tests.
Sincerely,

DAVID A KOLB MD

comment:
Ms. Marilyn B. Tavenner
Principal Deputy Administrator, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services
Department of Health and Human Services
RE: CMS-1590-FC [2013 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule; Nerve Conduction Studies/EMG Values]

Dear Ms. Tavenner,
I AM A RECENTLY RETIRED PHYSCIAN WITH "NO SKIN IN THE GAME." As a neurologist who previously routinely used nerve conduction studies and EMG to diagnose patients with neurologic illnesses such as carpal tunnel, ALS, muscular dystrophy, and neuropathies, I am concerned that the values for these tests set by the 2013 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule will not only severely restrict patient access, but will delay timely diagnosis and appropriate treatment of these debilitating conditions.

The announcement of these cuts on November 1 leaves physicians and practices only 60 days to prepare for extraordinarily large cuts.

This testing is labor intensive, requires skill and no small amount of time; under-valuing it will force physicians into other areas (there are many--as you know there is a neurologist shortage) and disadvantage patients.

I strongly urge that you reconsider the scale of these reductions to ensure that Medicare beneficiary access to high quality care is not adversely impacted. I ask that you work with the American Academy of Neurology and other key stakeholders to find a solution to significantly mitigate these cuts to allow more time to adapt to any payment adjustments for nerve conduction studies and EMG tests.
Sincerely,

DAVID A KOLB MD

comment: I wish to express opposition to the planned approval of genetically modified (transgenic) salmon into the US food system.   I believe it to be dangerous from a contamination point of view (contaminating wild salmon with the accidental release of these), as well as being irresponsible given that there is no law requiring the GM salmon to be labeled appropriately for consumers.   Lacking a labeling law will ensure that some folks who are sensitive to foods will react to this newly engineered fish.   If you approve this fish, then at least require its labeling.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648119a623', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2011-N-0899-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Food Industry - C0027', 'comment': 'FDA-2011-N-0899

I am writing to request that you do not approve genetically engineered salmon. I am against this because the health risks of consuming salmon that has been genetically altered to produce growth hormones at all times are completely unknown. Your claim that genetically engineered salmon is safe to eat is based on an assumption, not on rigorous scientific investigation.

Furthermore, this practice will endanger our world's ecosystems and make it impossible to avoid eating genetically altered organisms. The accidental release of transgenic salmon could be devastating to marine ecosystems and wild salmon populations. It is naïve to assume that no transgenic fish will escape into the wild. The National Academy of Sciences wrote that release of transgenic fish is “of immediate concern” and “might pose environmental hazards.” These impacts would likely be irreversible.

I urge you to put human health, the environment, and the economic well-being of coastal fishing communities first. The FDA should rely on independent and credible science, not on science supplied by the corporation that stands to profit from your approval.

Please delay approval of genetically engineered salmon until the results of independent scientific studies show that genetically engineered fish is safe to eat and harmless to the environment.

Please also require the labeling of GE foods, to allow consumers to make an informed choice.

Sincerely,

Michelle Cyr', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2011-N-0899', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064811b5566', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2013-01-18T22:02:06Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2013-01-18T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2013-01-10T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'Michelle Suzanne Cyr - Comment', 'trackingNbr': '1jx-8315-eww3', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
FDA-2011-N-0899

I am writing to request that you do not approve genetically engineered salmon. I am against this because the health risks of consuming salmon that has been genetically altered to produce growth hormones at all times are completely unknown. Your claim that genetically engineered salmon is safe to eat is based on an assumption, not on rigorous scientific investigation.

Furthermore, this practice will endanger our world's ecosystems and make it impossible to avoid eating genetically altered organisms. The accidental release of transgenic salmon could be devastating to marine ecosystems and wild salmon populations. It is naïve to assume that no transgenic fish will escape into the wild. The National Academy of Sciences wrote that release of transgenic fish is “of immediate concern” and “might pose environmental hazards.” These impacts would likely be irreversible.

I urge you to put human health, the environment, and the economic well-being of coastal fishing communities first. The FDA should rely on independent and credible science, not on science supplied by the corporation that stands to profit from your approval.

Please delay approval of genetically engineered salmon until the results of independent scientific studies show that genetically engineered fish is safe to eat and harmless to the environment.

Please also require the labeling of GE foods, to allow consumers to make an informed choice.

Sincerely,

Michelle Cyr

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481169eb0', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'CMS-2012-0083-3524', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'CMS', 'city': None, 'category': 'Physician - HC005', 'comment': 'I am a board certified, mostly office based neurologist.

Regarding fees:

1) office based EMG\\NCV\\ENG\\EEG of all sorts are vastlly overused and function most often in my community as a billing procedure. This is true across most physicians who do in-office testing or treatment.
2) hospital based studies seem not overutlized.
3) over utilization in neurology is driven by the lack of payment for cognitive services (thinking about it) versus the relative ease of paying for a discrete service.

4) Suggestion: decrease payment for studies, especially in-office, and increase payment for cognitive services.', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'CMS-2012-0083', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481173fa3', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2013-01-18T16:13:20Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2013-01-18T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-11-26T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'CA', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'CA-FRESNO NEUROBEHAVIORAL', 'trackingNbr': '1jw-827a-27ue', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I am a board certified, mostly office based neurologist.

Regarding fees:

1) office based EMG\NCV\ENG\EEG of all sorts are vastlly overused and function most often in my community as a billing procedure. This is true across most physicians who do in-office testing or treatment.
2) hospital based studies seem not overutlized.
3) over utilization in neurology is driven by the lack of payment for cognitive services (thinking about it) versus the relative ease of paying for a discrete service.

4) Suggestion: decrease payment for studies, especially in-office, and increase payment for cognitive services.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481169eb0', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'CMS-2012-0083-3524', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'CMS', 'city': None, 'category': 'Physician - HC005', 'comment': 'Re: CMS-1590-FC

To Whom It May Concern,

The American Academy of Neurology, of which I am a member, asked its members to contact Medicare regarding the reduced reimbursements of nerve conduction and needle EMG studies beginning in January, 2013. The drastic cut in reimbursement will force my practice (I am a solo neurologist) to consider eliminating one or possibly two positions to compensate for this loss of revenue, particularly since my expenses are not going down. This will adversely affect these employees given the current economy. It will also make it much more difficult for me to continue to accept Medicare patients.

It is important for CMS to work with the AAN and its sister organizations to reduce or eliminate this drastic cut in reimbursement for these studies.

Adam S. comment:
Re: CMS-1590-FC

To Whom It May Concern,

The American Academy of Neurology, of which I am a member, asked its members to contact Medicare regarding the reduced reimbursements of nerve conduction and needle EMG studies beginning in January, 2013. The drastic cut in reimbursement will force my practice (I am a solo neurologist) to consider eliminating one or possibly two positions to compensate for this loss of revenue, particularly since my expenses are not going down. This will adversely affect these employees given the current economy. It will also make it much more difficult for me to continue to accept Medicare patients.

It is important for CMS to work with the AAN and its sister organizations to reduce or eliminate this drastic cut in reimbursement for these studies.

Cordially,

Adam S. Mednick, MD, PhD
