attributes: {'commentOn': '090000648414d496', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'The proposed revisions to the existing Lead and Copper Rule to reduce exposure by regulating lead tap sampling, consumer awareness, and public education is absolutely necessary. It has been proven that lead can cause damaging health risks, especially in children. After reading that the EPA suggests that 20% of lead exposure is due to drinking water, I believe it is extremely important to focus on sampling drinking water outlets at children's schools to reduce lead in the water. However, I also believe it is important to note that these revisions do not dive deeper into further regulating copper exposure. While the effects do not specifically target adolescents, I think it is important to further regulate both for public health and the safety of all people. Additionally, I think that the Lead Service Line Replacement proposal is a great idea, but I am unsure how it can be fully implemented by the water systems. There are lots of logistics with the labor for that process and financial aspects, but steps do need to be taken eventually lead up to LSLR.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006484340cc8', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2020-10-05T01:55:08Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 1, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2020-02-18T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2020-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2020-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Anonymous public comment', 'trackingNbr': '1k4-9ewm-zbbl', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: The proposed revisions to the existing Lead and Copper Rule to reduce exposure by regulating lead tap sampling, consumer awareness, and public education is absolutely necessary. It has been proven that lead can cause damaging health risks, especially in children. After reading that the EPA suggests that 20% of lead exposure is due to drinking water, I believe it is extremely important to focus on sampling drinking water outlets at children's schools to reduce lead in the water. However, I also believe it is important to note that these revisions do not dive deeper into further regulating copper exposure. While the effects do not specifically target adolescents, I think it is important to further regulate both for public health and the safety of all people. Additionally, I think that the Lead Service Line Replacement proposal is a great idea, but I am unsure how it can be fully implemented by the water systems. There are lots of logistics with the labor for that process and financial aspects, but steps do need to be taken eventually lead up to LSLR.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648414d496', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': '1. According to this report Non-Transient, Non-Community Water Systems are being given three alternatives to comply with the proposed lower trigger warning 10 g/L. If smaller non communal water users are given the choice to partially or fully postpone action until the higher level of 15 g/L is reached they will inevitably delay action to save money. These alternative options should be removed and instead grants should be more heavily allocated towards non communal water users. The report states: "...Congress appropriated $50 million in FY2018, to fund grants to small and disadvantaged communities for developing and maintaining infrastructure, for lead reduction projects, and to support the voluntary testing of drinking water in schools and child care centers." Smaller disadvantaged communities should have increased outreach and funding to comply with this new regulation fully instead of using alternatives to allow them to stay stagnant in their environmental efforts. Smaller communities are a vulnerable population and due to low income being linked to less comprehensive healthcare it is of the utmost importance that any regulation enhancing health and safety is enforced to the fullest extent in these areas. Lessening their requirement is counterproductive.

2. As of 1967 the Clean Water act was amended to include an annual water quality report from Community Water Systems, known as the Consumer Confidence Report. This report is being proposed to have new and more comprehensive language to warn people of the negative effects lead can have on children especially. The language reads: "Exposure to lead can cause serious health effects in all age groups. Infants and children who drink water containing lead could have decreases in IQ and attention span and increases in learning and behavior problems. Lead exposure among women who are pregnant increases prenatal risks. Lead exposure among women who later become pregnant has similar risks if lead stored in the mother's bones is released during pregnancy. Recent science suggests that adults who drink water containing lead have increased risks of heart disease, high blood pressure, kidney or nervous system problems." This language should also be mandated to be distributed to primary care physicians of families who have young children or are expecting children. Children and developing fetuses are most prone to harm due to lead and the prevention of these effects should be emphasized just as much as the remediation that this trigger warning offers. Parents will be more prone to beware of lead if they find out from their doctor versus a water quality report that there is 1) no guarantee consumers will read and 2) will not be shown to non-communal water users.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006484343458', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2020-10-05T03:19:04Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 1, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2020-02-18T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2020-02-10T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2020-02-10T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Anonymous public comment', 'trackingNbr': '1k4-9exh-3422', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
1. According to this report Non-Transient, Non-Community Water Systems are being given three alternatives to comply with the proposed lower trigger warning 10 g/L. If smaller non communal water users are given the choice to partially or fully postpone action until the higher level of 15 g/L is reached they will inevitably delay action to save money. These alternative options should be removed and instead grants should be more heavily allocated towards non communal water users. The report states: "...Congress appropriated $50 million in FY2018, to fund grants to small and disadvantaged communities for developing and maintaining infrastructure, for lead reduction projects, and to support the voluntary testing of drinking water in schools and child care centers." Smaller disadvantaged communities should have increased outreach and funding to comply with this new regulation fully instead of using alternatives to allow them to stay stagnant in their environmental efforts. Smaller communities are a vulnerable population and due to low income being linked to less comprehensive healthcare it is of the utmost importance that any regulation enhancing health and safety is enforced to the fullest extent in these areas. Lessening their requirement is counterproductive.

2. As of 1967 the Clean Water act was amended to include an annual water quality report from Community Water Systems, known as the Consumer Confidence Report. This report is being proposed to have new and more comprehensive language to warn people of the negative effects lead can have on children especially. The language reads: "Exposure to lead can cause serious health effects in all age groups. Infants and children who drink water containing lead could have decreases in IQ and attention span and increases in learning and behavior problems. Lead exposure among women who are pregnant increases prenatal risks. Lead exposure among women who later become pregnant has similar risks if lead stored in the mother's bones is released during pregnancy. Recent science suggests that adults who drink water containing lead have increased risks of heart disease, high blood pressure, kidney or nervous system problems." This language should also be mandated to be distributed to primary care physicians of families who have young children or are expecting children. Children and developing fetuses are most prone to harm due to lead and the prevention of these effects should be emphasized just as much as the remediation that this trigger warning offers. Parents will be more prone to beware of lead if they find out from their doctor versus a water quality report that there is 1) no guarantee consumers will read and 2) will not be shown to non-communal water users.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648414d496', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': "PG. 61688
PROPOSED CHANGE: Find and Fix: Perform needed corrective action.
COMMENT: There may be no corrective action to take if the service line is not the problem. The interior plumbing may be and water purveyors have no control over it.

PG. 61698 paragraph 2
PROPOSED CHANGE: Whenever a water system conducts partial LSLR....taking a tap sample after three months....
COMMENT: The property owner that is unable or unwilling to complete the private portion of the service line replacement may not cooperate with the tap sample procedure.

PG. 61699 paragraph 2
PROPOSED CHANGE: The EPA is proposing that a water system may discontinue its goal based LSLR program after......
COMMENT: Why would anyone discontinue a successful program of removing lead services? Lead in service line WILL ALWAYS be a problem waiting to be exposed.

PG. 61706 J.
PROPOSED CHANGE: Public Education and Sampling at Schools and Child Care Facilities
COMMENT: The Agency established the voluntary 3t's program. I assume this program is not effective or the water systems would not be faced with this proposed change. Water systems should not be expected to be responsible for Interior plumbing systems. This seems to be more in the purview of the Health Department and the responsibility of the School System or facility owner.

PROPOSED CHANGE: Exhibit 6.2National Annualized Sampling Costs $80,955,000-81,276,00.
COMMENT: These costs to test and monitor for a problem that is well known and documented. Lead in service lines will always be a potential problem until it is eliminated. These funds would be better spent eliminating lead service lines.

PG. 61716
PROPOSED CHANGE: Exhibit 6-4National Annualized Corrosion Control Technology Costs $414,967,000 - 431,866,000
COMMENT: These cost mitigate the effects of a problem that will always be a potential problem until it is eliminated. These funds would be better spent eliminating lead service lines.

Opinion/ Recommendations
It has been well known that lead in drinking water is a health risk for more than a century. This issue was also addressed with the Safe Drinking Water Act nearly fifty years ago. The first Lead and Copper Rule came out nearly thirty years ago. The same towns have the same risks from the same water pipes and appurtenances today that were identified in 1991. With these proposed changes, the actual problem is still being deferred to future generations. Within these revisions, water systems are to be required to maintain complex and fragile scales in pipes to protect the public from lead leaching into their drinking water. While water purveyors take pride in providing the safe drinking water that our customers rely on, maintaining scale in pipes is counterintuitive to our objective of keeping water flowing efficiently. We want to minimize scale or growth in pipes. We want efficient and predictable water flow. Also, most water systems do not have the expertise or resources to meet these rule changes effectively. We do not have scientists and chemists on staff to manage portions of the proposed rules and we do not have the cooperation of the public. Even with all of the proposed rules followed, we still have no control over private plumbing systems and what changes are made to the water quality in them. Instead of spending millions of dollars testing and monitoring for lead that we already know is a potential problem, we should remove the lead and not allow it to be a risk to generations in the future.

In my opinion this is what should be done:

Require Water Systems to identify water services.

Require water systems to replace or arrange for the FULL replacement of the service line WITH A DEDICATED DRINKING WATER TAP INSIDE THE HOME JUST AFTER THE MAIN VALVE TO BE PIPED TO A DEDICATED DRINKING WATER FAUCET thereby eliminated the risk of drinking water through the home plumbing system.

Facilitate/support the authority of water systems to discontinue the supply of water to a residence until the required replacement of the private portion of the water service line including the DEDICATED DRINKING WATER TAP just past the main valve is completed.

USEPA should make grant money available to finance the private portion of the water service lines INLUDING THE DEDICATED DRINKING WATER TAP if the owner can demonstrate financial hardship to the water system.

Eliminate the inefficient lead testing program at homes by water purveyors. It is burdensome, inefficient and unpopular with the public. It is more and more difficult to gain proper sites and cooperation. US or State EPA staff should participate in testing or studies that they feel are worthwhile.

Devote resources to the many other challenges facing Public Water Systems.

Andreas W. Eddy

W. Eddy', 'trackingNbr': '1k4-9eyj-8oet', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}

COMMENT: The Agency established the voluntary 3t's program. I assume this program is not effective or the water systems would not be faced with this proposed change. Water systems should not be expected to be responsible for Interior plumbing systems. This seems to be more in the purview of the Health Department and the responsibility of the School System or facility owner.

COMMENT: These costs to test and monitor for a problem that is well known and documented. Lead in service lines will always be a potential problem until it is eliminated. These funds would be better spent eliminating lead service lines.

COMMENT: These cost mitigate the effects of a problem that will always be a potential problem until it is eliminated. These funds would be better spent eliminating lead service lines.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648414d496', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': "(Submitted electronically via www.regulations.gov)
Andrew R. Wheeler
Administrator
Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W.
Mail Code: 1101A
Washington, DC 20460

RE:National Primary Drinking Water Regulations: Proposed Lead and Copper Rule Revisions
Docket No. EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300

Dear Administrator Wheeler,
The New Jersey State League of Municipalities ("League") appreciates the opportunity to provide input to the Environmental Protection Agency's ("EPA") November 13, 2019 Federal Register notice, proposing revisions to the Lead and Copper Rule.
The League is a voluntary association created to help communities do a better job of self-government through pooling information resources and brain power. We have been authorized by state statute, and since 1915, have been serving local officials throughout the State of New Jersey. All 565 municipalities are members of the League. Over 560 mayors and 13,000 elected and appointed officials are entitled to all of the benefits and privileges of the League.
Lead in drinking water is a well-recognized public health concern. Accordingly, it is the shared responsibility of water systems, customers, consumers, state regulators, federal agencies, local governments and many others to develop policies and plans to address this concern. It is the duty of each of entities and individuals to take steps within their authority to reduce lead in water.
To that end, the League has worked with local and state officials to develop a plan to effectively, efficiently, and expeditiously address this issue. In this endeavor common concerns from the perspective of municipal water systems have cropped up. The League respectfully asks that, in finalizing the Lead and Copper Rule, the EPA consider these concerns:
1.Clearly state in the rule that lead service line inventories are intended to guide proactive actions based on available information like that described in the proposed rule and additional date collected in the course of routine water system activities. Moreover, water systems, or portions therein, constructed following the Safe Drinking Water Act Lead Ban or other state or local policies with like effect, should be able to certify that lead service lines are not present rather than complete the inventory-related activities in the rule. Lead service line inventories are further complicated by the split-nature of the ownership over such lines. Expeditiously completing and maintaining an accurate inventory of customer owned service lines entails significant resources.

2.Corrosion control is a critical tool in managing lead in drinking water that must be implemented taking many more considerations than are reflected in the proposed rule into account. EPA must allow water systems to identify and manage corrosion control using an array of tools to support timely and cost-effective decision-making rather than the rigid framework proposed. Evaluation of corrosion control should begin with an assessment of whether the system is currently implementing its corrosion control strategy effectively rather than immediately revisiting what corrosion control strategy is appropriate.

3.If the EPA is not going to identify a 90th percentile lead level above 15 ppb that poses a serious adverse health effect due to short-term exposure, then the associated Tier 1 public notice and associated risk communication must be carefully gauged as to not cause undue public panic.

4.Finally, EPA must consider how small and medium communities are going to fund these additional requirements. While the goal of every municipal water system is to produce the best quality water for their consumers, these systems are also dealing with personnel shortages, limited funding, and aging infrastructure, which all have a direct influence on water quality and should be considered when placing deadlines on some of the proposed requirements.

Very truly yours,

Frank Marshall
Associate General Counsel
New Jersey State League of Municipalities

comment:
(Submitted electronically via www.regulations.gov)
Andrew R. Wheeler
Administrator
Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W.
Mail Code: 1101A
Washington, DC 20460

RE:National Primary Drinking Water Regulations: Proposed Lead and Copper Rule Revisions
Docket No. EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300

Dear Administrator Wheeler,
The New Jersey State League of Municipalities ("League") appreciates the opportunity to provide input to the Environmental Protection Agency's ("EPA") November 13, 2019 Federal Register notice, proposing revisions to the Lead and Copper Rule.
The League is a voluntary association created to help communities do a better job of self-government through pooling information resources and brain power. We have been authorized by state statute, and since 1915, have been serving local officials throughout the State of New Jersey. All 565 municipalities are members of the League. Over 560 mayors and 13,000 elected and appointed officials are entitled to all of the benefits and privileges of the League.
Lead in drinking water is a well-recognized public health concern. Accordingly, it is the shared responsibility of water systems, customers, consumers, state regulators, federal agencies, local governments and many others to develop policies and plans to address this concern. It is the duty of each of entities and individuals to take steps within their authority to reduce lead in water.
To that end, the League has worked with local and state officials to develop a plan to effectively, efficiently, and expeditiously address this issue. In this endeavor common concerns from the perspective of municipal water systems have cropped up. The League respectfully asks that, in finalizing the Lead and Copper Rule, the EPA consider these concerns:
1.Clearly state in the rule that lead service line inventories are intended to guide proactive actions based on available information like that described in the proposed rule and additional date collected in the course of routine water system activities. Moreover, water systems, or portions therein, constructed following the Safe Drinking Water Act Lead Ban or other state or local policies with like effect, should be able to certify that lead service lines are not present rather than complete the inventory-related activities in the rule. Lead service line inventories are further complicated by the split-nature of the ownership over such lines. Expeditiously completing and maintaining an accurate inventory of customer owned service lines entails significant resources.

2.Corrosion control is a critical tool in managing lead in drinking water that must be implemented taking many more considerations than are reflected in the proposed rule into account. EPA must allow water systems to identify and manage corrosion control using an array of tools to support timely and cost-effective decision-making rather than the rigid framework proposed. Evaluation of corrosion control should begin with an assessment of whether the system is currently implementing its corrosion control strategy effectively rather than immediately revisiting what corrosion control strategy is appropriate.

3.If the EPA is not going to identify a 90th percentile lead level above 15 ppb that poses a serious adverse health effect due to short-term exposure, then the associated Tier 1 public notice and associated risk communication must be carefully gauged as to not cause undue public panic.

4.Finally, EPA must consider how small and medium communities are going to fund these additional requirements. While the goal of every municipal water system is to produce the best quality water for their consumers, these systems are also dealing with personnel shortages, limited funding, and aging infrastructure, which all have a direct influence on water quality and should be considered when placing deadlines on some of the proposed requirements.

Very truly yours,

Frank Marshall
Associate General Counsel
New Jersey State League of Municipalities

{'commentOn': '090000648414d496', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Comments submitted by Ben Ct, President, Sanexen Water Inc., and Jeff Tanner, President, Flow-Liner Systems, Ltd.
We represent two companies that offer innovative, cost-efficient, trenchless pipe lining technology to prevent lead and copper from entering the public water supply from the interiors of delivery piping. Where the statute demands replacement, EPA should allow in-line technology to be installed in existing lead service lines. With prudent adjustment of rules accordingly, the nation's drinking water systems and owners of homes and other buildings with lead service lines will benefit from hundreds of millions of dollars in savings while improving the safety of their drinking water.
See attached file.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064843549cc', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2020-10-05T02:31:10Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 1, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2020-02-18T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2020-02-11T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2020-02-11T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Company/Organization Comment', 'title': 'Comment submitted by Tim Cansler, Cansler Consulting LLC on behalf of Ben Cote, President, Sanexen Water Inc. and Jeff Tanner, President, Flow-Liner Systems, Ltd.', 'trackingNbr': '1k4-9eyo-qcvl', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Comments submitted by Ben Ct, President, Sanexen Water Inc., and Jeff Tanner, President, Flow-Liner Systems, Ltd.
We represent two companies that offer innovative, cost-efficient, trenchless pipe lining technology to prevent lead and copper from entering the public water supply from the interiors of delivery piping. Where the statute demands replacement, EPA should allow in-line technology to be installed in existing lead service lines. With prudent adjustment of rules accordingly, the nation's drinking water systems and owners of homes and other buildings with lead service lines will benefit from hundreds of millions of dollars in savings while improving the safety of their drinking water.
See attached file.

attributes: {'commentOn': '090000648414d496', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'It is absolutely unconscionable that the EPA  is considering a change in the rule controlling the percentage of lead service lines that must be replaced annually that will reduce the number of dangerous pipes.  No levels of lead are safe.  Safe, clean drinking water is a critical and basic government services that should be available to everyone in this advanced country.  Lowering the percentage to 3% from the current 7% will damage the long-term health of far too many of our citizens.  The National Resources Defense Council estimates it will take 13 years to replace all of the lead service lines under the current rule, but 33 years under the proposed change.  That's nearly 2 generations of children who could be permanently damaged.  I am thoroughly opposed to any change that lengthens the time anyone living in the United States could potentially be exposed to lead.  ', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006484349c68', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2020-10-05T03:23:47Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 1, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2020-02-18T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2020-02-10T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2020-02-10T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Anonymous public comment', 'trackingNbr': '1k4-9ey0-12im', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: It is absolutely unconscionable that the EPA  is considering a change in the rule controlling the percentage of lead service lines that must be replaced annually that will reduce the number of dangerous pipes.  No levels of lead are safe.  Safe, clean drinking water is a critical and basic government services that should be available to everyone in this advanced country.  Lowering the percentage to 3% from the current 7% will damage the long-term health of far too many of our citizens.  The National Resources Defense Council estimates it will take 13 years to replace all of the lead service lines under the current rule, but 33 years under the proposed change.  That's nearly 2 generations of children who could be permanently damaged.  I am thoroughly opposed to any change that lengthens the time anyone living in the United States could potentially be exposed to lead.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648414d496', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300-0001', 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Dear Administrator Wheeler,

I urge you to address deficiencies in the Proposed Lead and Copper Rule Revisions. We know how to reduce lead at the tap, and now is the time to do everything we can to get lead out of contact with our drinking water. I especially urge you to:

Require all water systems to fully replace all lead service lines within a specified timeline

Prohibit partial lead service line replacements, which put people's health at risk and are inefficient

Water systems with elevated lead levels should fully replace lead service lines at a rate of at least 7% each year.

Please make sure that the Lead and Copper Rule is effective and visionary, and that EPA robustly supports implementation and enforcement.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0300', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '090000648423036e', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2020-10-05T03:30:02Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 1, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2020-02-18T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2019-12-18T05:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2019-12-18T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Anonymous public comment', 'trackingNbr': '1k3-9dxy-wy5x', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Dear Administrator Wheeler,

I urge you to address deficiencies in the Proposed Lead and Copper Rule Revisions. We know how to reduce lead at the tap, and now is the time to do everything we can to get lead out of contact with our drinking water. I especially urge you to:

Require all water systems to fully replace all lead service lines within a specified timeline

Prohibit partial lead service line replacements, which put people's health at risk and are inefficient

Water systems with elevated lead levels should fully replace lead service lines at a rate of at least 7% each year.

Please make sure that the Lead and Copper Rule is effective and visionary, and that EPA robustly supports implementation and enforcement.

attributes: {'commentOn': '09000064825a1f28', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'DOI-2017-0002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'DOI', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Every single one of our parks, monuments and cultural or historic sites is worthwhile and belongs as a part of the American story. I am adamantly opposed to any effort to eliminate or diminish protections for national monuments and I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain protected. attributes: {'commentOn': '09000064825a1f28', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'DOI-2017-0002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'DOI', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'I am appalled that our treasured National monuments are up for review at all.  Every single one of our parks, monuments and cultural or historic sites is worthwhile and belongs as a part of the American story. I am adamantly opposed to any effort to eliminate or diminish protections for national monuments and I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain protected. The short review you are undertaking makes a mockery of the decades of work that local communities have invested to protect these places for future generations, especially Bears Ears National monument, which is the first on the list for this review. Five Tribal nations, Hopi, Navajo, Uintah and Ouray Ute Indian Tribe, Ute Mountain Ute and Zuni tribes came together, for the first time ever, to protect their shared sacred land by advocating for Bears Ears to be made a national monument. Now the Bears Ears Inter-Tribal Coalition is working to protect the national monument, and maintain its integrity. Hear me, and the overwhelming number of people who agree with me: PUBLIC LANDS BELONG IN PUBLIC HANDS. It is your job as the Secretary of the Dept. of Interior to protect and safeguard our national treasures. Please make sure you side with the people who support national parks, monuments, historical and cultural sites. ', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'DOI-2017-0002', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Marcy', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006482775f68', 'lastName': 'Welch', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-06-25T08:45:26Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-06-25T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2017-06-24T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2017-09490', 'trackingNbr': '1k1-8x50-4o9i', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: I am appalled that our treasured National monuments are up for review at all.  Every single one of our parks, monuments and cultural or historic sites is worthwhile and belongs as a part of the American story. I am adamantly opposed to any effort to eliminate or diminish protections for national monuments and I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain protected. The short review you are undertaking makes a mockery of the decades of work that local communities have invested to protect these places for future generations, especially Bears Ears National monument, which is the first on the list for this review. Five Tribal nations, Hopi, Navajo, Uintah and Ouray Ute Indian Tribe, Ute Mountain Ute and Zuni tribes came together, for the first time ever, to protect their shared sacred land by advocating for Bears Ears to be made a national monument. Now the Bears Ears Inter-Tribal Coalition is working to protect the national monument, and maintain its integrity. Hear me, and the overwhelming number of people who agree with me: PUBLIC LANDS BELONG IN PUBLIC HANDS. It is your job as the Secretary of the Dept. of Interior to protect and safeguard our national treasures. Please make sure you side with the people who support national parks, monuments, historical and cultural sites.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064825a1f28', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'DOI-2017-0002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'DOI', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Secretary Zinke,
This letter is in support of protecting the Antiquities Act, which has been in place in this great country for over 100 years. Our public lands are one of the greatest treasures we have. They allow exploration, communing with nature, and most importantly for me, rock climbing these wonderful desert towers in Indian Creek, Utah. Climbing is the only thing that saved my life while in my 20s. I became a heavy IV drug user after high school, when my brother died. I lived for nothing, other than finding the next bag of heroin. My family forced me into a wilderness excursion rehab trip in Indian Creek, Utah. The first few days were horrible and unpleasant. But , something about watching the rock climbers ascend the sandstone, really spoke to me. I found that being on the rock was something that made me forget about drugs, if only for a short time. I hiked and climbed with the group of recovering addicts for nearly three weeks. The beautiful desert walls served as a antidote to my addiction, and over the next year, I gradually became drug free. This landscape we have in this country has made me appreciate life again. Please protect it.

Thank you,
Chris Martin
Longmont , CO', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'DOI-2017-0002', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Chris', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064827763ac', 'lastName': 'Martin', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-06-25T08:45:56Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-06-25T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2017-06-24T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2017-09490', 'trackingNbr': '1k1-8x54-aggu', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Secretary Zinke,
This letter is in support of protecting the Antiquities Act, which has been in place in this great country for over 100 years. Our public lands are one of the greatest treasures we have. They allow exploration, communing with nature, and most importantly for me, rock climbing these wonderful desert towers in Indian Creek, Utah. Climbing is the only thing that saved my life while in my 20s. I became a heavy IV drug user after high school, when my brother died. I lived for nothing, other than finding the next bag of heroin. My family forced me into a wilderness excursion rehab trip in Indian Creek, Utah. The first few days were horrible and unpleasant. But , something about watching the rock climbers ascend the sandstone, really spoke to me. I found that being on the rock was something that made me forget about drugs, if only for a short time. I hiked and climbed with the group of recovering addicts for nearly three weeks. The beautiful desert walls served as a antidote to my addiction, and over the next year, I gradually became drug free. This landscape we have in this country has made me appreciate life again. Please protect it.

Thank you,
Chris Martin
Longmont , CO

comment: Every single one of our parks, monuments and cultural or historic sites is worthwhile and belongs as a part of the American story. I am adamantly opposed to any effort to eliminate or diminish protections for national monuments and I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain protected. Hear me, and the overwhelming number of people who agree with me: PUBLIC LANDS BELONG IN PUBLIC HANDS. It is your job as the Secretary of the Dept. of Interior to protect and safeguard our national treasures. Please make sure you side with the people who support national parks, monuments, historical and cultural sites.

comment:
DOI-2017-0002

What the heck are you people in the Trump administration trying to do? Do you want to take America back to the 1950s when the air was toxic, waterways were unswimmable, and environmental disasters like Love Canal were beginning to weave their evil spells? Enough already! It's 2017 for God's sake. Science matters, environmental regulations work, and "we the people" demand a healthy and robust natural environment!

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,

It is impossible to believe we are now in this situation, Teddy Roosevelt established monuments and parks and now we have a complete imbecile destroying our heritage. I feel as if we are living in a world I no longer know or care for. We as humans have had our chance.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064825a1f28', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'DOI-2017-0002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'DOI', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,

I am writing to ask that you please protect the current National Monument Status of the San Gabriel Mountains.

The San Gabriel Mountains are a unique landform that provide invaluable resources, including water and air, to the greater Los Angeles community. As any visitor to LA can see, much of the city has fallen victim to urbanization.

As with any city, not all locations in the city are created equally. One needs only look at recent scientific studies focused on the negative effects of noise and air pollution on individuals to understand the impacts that these aspects of LA's urban landscape have on its residents. In fact, LA was recently singled out as having the worst noise pollution in the country. And, it is no secret that negative air quality has plagued LA's residents for some time.

When President Obama designated the San Gabriel Mountains a National Monument, he demonstrated that he could clearly hear the cries of a city in desperate need of solace from the troubles of urbanization. Los Angeles is not an equitable city; it is a city divided by income. Those with money are fortunate; they live in verdant neighborhoods. Unfortunately, it is those without financial resources who struggle most in this city, who are at the mercy of endless noise and air pollution. These mountains offer an opportunity for all LA residents, regardless of socioeconomic status to breathe clean air and to listen to the sounds of an open and wild space.

When I first moved to LA, I was saddened by the lack of accessible wilderness, until I discovered the San Gabriel Mountains. In true LA fashion, I was trapped in what seemed like an endless line of cars all heading into the mountains. Each car was filled with many different faces from many walks of life. There were Jaguars and Toyotas from the 1980s. There were families, extended families, children, dogs, couples, and single folks. The mountains are the great equalizer. Once outside of our cars we were all the same. We were just people in search of peace and connection. That is beautiful and that is worth protecting.

You could decide that short-term goals are more important than long-term benefits. You could open these mountains up to extraction, industry, and commercialization. But haven't we been there before? Was it not President Harrison in the late 1800s who declared a Timber Sanctuary in the San Gabriel Mountains? The reason he did that, of course, was that destruction in the mountains was detrimental to the community below.

Denude the landscape and destroy all of the resources that one takes for granted. Los Angeles has never had an abundant water supply. This is a fact of a southerly latitude, cold ocean temperatures, and prevailing wind patterns. But the San Gabriel Mountains trap cool and moist Pacific Air. Thanks to orographic lifting, some of the moisture condenses and falls as rain on the slopes of the San Gabriels, which of course collects into streams and supplies a relatively dry land with water. A true miracle.

At the time when President Harrison decided to declare portions of the San Gabriels a Timberland Reserve he did so in response to a decline in overall water quality. A water that the growing city of LA had become dependent upon. In this designation, he understood that the long-term benefits far outweighed the short-term gain of fleeting resources.

Today, the San Gabriel's still provide local water. They still trap moist cool Pacific air, leading to a more hospitable climate. They are the home to unique vegetation, to ancient predators, to our cultural past, and to a peace that can only be known on its slopes.

As a geologist, I understand the the Earth is always changing, but as a human I understand the time we spend on it can seem long. I know that we can make choices to make the lives of those around us healthier and happier. Please protect the San Gabriels.

Thank you for you time and consideration on this issue.

Sincerely,
Christyanne Melendez
Los Angeles, CA 90066', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'DOI-2017-0002', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Christyanne', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '090000648277728e', 'lastName': 'Melendez', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-06-25T08:47:23Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-06-25T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2017-06-24T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2017-09490', 'trackingNbr': '1k1-8x5d-wai2', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,

I am writing to ask that you please protect the current National Monument Status of the San Gabriel Mountains.

The San Gabriel Mountains are a unique landform that provide invaluable resources, including water and air, to the greater Los Angeles community. As any visitor to LA can see, much of the city has fallen victim to urbanization.

As with any city, not all locations in the city are created equally. One needs only look at recent scientific studies focused on the negative effects of noise and air pollution on individuals to understand the impacts that these aspects of LA's urban landscape have on its residents. In fact, LA was recently singled out as having the worst noise pollution in the country. And, it is no secret that negative air quality has plagued LA's residents for some time.

When President Obama designated the San Gabriel Mountains a National Monument, he demonstrated that he could clearly hear the cries of a city in desperate need of solace from the troubles of urbanization. Los Angeles is not an equitable city; it is a city divided by income. Those with money are fortunate; they live in verdant neighborhoods. Unfortunately, it is those without financial resources who struggle most in this city, who are at the mercy of endless noise and air pollution. These mountains offer an opportunity for all LA residents, regardless of socioeconomic status to breathe clean air and to listen to the sounds of an open and wild space.

When I first moved to LA, I was saddened by the lack of accessible wilderness, until I discovered the San Gabriel Mountains. In true LA fashion, I was trapped in what seemed like an endless line of cars all heading into the mountains. Each car was filled with many different faces from many walks of life. There were Jaguars and Toyotas from the 1980s. There were families, extended families, children, dogs, couples, and single folks. The mountains are the great equalizer. Once outside of our cars we were all the same. We were just people in search of peace and connection. That is beautiful and that is worth protecting.

You could decide that short-term goals are more important than long-term benefits. You could open these mountains up to extraction, industry, and commercialization. But haven't we been there before? Was it not President Harrison in the late 1800s who declared a Timber Sanctuary in the San Gabriel Mountains? The reason he did that, of course, was that destruction in the mountains was detrimental to the community below.

Denude the landscape and destroy all of the resources that one takes for granted. Los Angeles has never had an abundant water supply. This is a fact of a southerly latitude, cold ocean temperatures, and prevailing wind patterns. But the San Gabriel Mountains trap cool and moist Pacific Air. Thanks to orographic lifting, some of the moisture condenses and falls as rain on the slopes of the San Gabriels, which of course collects into streams and supplies a relatively dry land with water. A true miracle.

At the time when President Harrison decided to declare portions of the San Gabriels a Timberland Reserve he did so in response to a decline in overall water quality. A water that the growing city of LA had become dependent upon. In this designation, he understood that the long-term benefits far outweighed the short-term gain of fleeting resources.

Today, the San Gabriel's still provide local water. They still trap moist cool Pacific air, leading to a more hospitable climate. They are the home to unique vegetation, to ancient predators, to our cultural past, and to a peace that can only be known on its slopes.

As a geologist, I understand the the Earth is always changing, but as a human I understand the time we spend on it can seem long. I know that we can make choices to make the lives of those around us healthier and happier. Please protect the San Gabriels.

Thank you for you time and consideration on this issue.

Sincerely,
Christyanne Melendez
Los Angeles, CA 90066

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064825a1f28', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'DOI-2017-0002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'DOI', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,

Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our shared historical, cultural, and natural heritage. I am concerned that the recent Executive Order attempts to undermine our national monuments and to roll back protections of these public lands. Protected public lands are an important part of what makes America great. I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.

Since President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act into law in 1906, 16 Presidents - 8 Republicans and 8 Democrats - have used the authority granted by the act to safeguard public lands, oceans, and historic sites in order to share America's story with future generations. These national monument designations are broadly supported from coast to coast and provide a myriad of benefits to local communities, including economic boosts from tourism, places to enjoy the outdoors, clean air and water, protection for ecologically sensitive areas, and windows into our country's history.

Sending a signal that protections for our shared history, culture, and natural treasures are temporary would set a terrible precedent. National monuments have been shown to be tremendous drivers of the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities.

From Maine's magnificent Katahdin Woods to the colorful canyons of Utah's Grand Staircase-Escalante to the western history held in New Mexico's Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks, these landmarks, landscapes, and seascapes have value which far exceeds their physical features; they manifest the core democratic ideals of freedom, justice, and equality. They are our legacy to our children and our children's children, and a gift that belongs to all Americans.

I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for our national monuments. I urge you to support the following list of National Monuments and recommend that our current national monuments remain as they are today.

AMERICAN SAMOA
Rose Atoll

ARIZONA
Grand Canyon - Parashant
Ironwood Forest
Vermillion Cliffs
Sonoran Desert

CALIFORNIA
Giant Sequoia
Carrizo Plain
Cascade-Siskiyou
San Gabriel Mountains
Berryessa Snow Mountain
Mojave Trails
Sand to Snow

COLORADO
Canyons of the Ancients

HAWAII
Papahnaumokukea

IDAHO
Craters of the Moon

MAINE
Katahdin Woods & Waters

MONTANA
Upper Missouri River Breaks

NEW ENGLAND

NEW MEXICO

NEVADA
Basin and Range

OREGON

PACIFIC OCEAN
Marianas Trench
Pacific Remote Islands

UTAH
Grand Staircase-Escalante
Bears Ears

WASHINGTON
Hanford Reach

Sincerely,
Peter Mulshine
Phillipsburg, NJ 08865', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'DOI-2017-0002', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Peter', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006482777361', 'lastName': 'Mulshine', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-06-25T08:47:29Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-06-25T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2017-06-24T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2017-09490', 'trackingNbr': '1k1-8x5e-vz3n', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,

Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our shared historical, cultural, and natural heritage. I am concerned that the recent Executive Order attempts to undermine our national monuments and to roll back protections of these public lands. Protected public lands are an important part of what makes America great. I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.

Since President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act into law in 1906, 16 Presidents - 8 Republicans and 8 Democrats - have used the authority granted by the act to safeguard public lands, oceans, and historic sites in order to share America's story with future generations. These national monument designations are broadly supported from coast to coast and provide a myriad of benefits to local communities, including economic boosts from tourism, places to enjoy the outdoors, clean air and water, protection for ecologically sensitive areas, and windows into our country's history.

Sending a signal that protections for our shared history, culture, and natural treasures are temporary would set a terrible precedent. National monuments have been shown to be tremendous drivers of the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities.

From Maine's magnificent Katahdin Woods to the colorful canyons of Utah's Grand Staircase-Escalante to the western history held in New Mexico's Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks, these landmarks, landscapes, and seascapes have value which far exceeds their physical features; they manifest the core democratic ideals of freedom, justice, and equality. They are our legacy to our children and our children's children, and a gift that belongs to all Americans.

I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for our national monuments. I urge you to support the following list of National Monuments and recommend that our current national monuments remain as they are today.

{'commentOn': '09000064825a1f28', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'DOI-2017-0002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'DOI', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,
Please listen with open ears in regards to your actions with protected public lands. If your mother or father's tombstone was abruptly moved to another location or that area was used for another purpose how would that make you feel? Just like that area where your mother or father may be buried or will be buried is designated to honor them, let these protected public lands be preserved to honor the memories and people that have contributed to protecting this land. Please consider environmental concerns and the backlash you and your fellow staff members will receive. Thanks,

-Jay Wilson', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'DOI-2017-0002', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'James', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006482777421', 'lastName': 'Wilson', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-06-25T08:47:39Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-06-25T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2017-06-25T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2017-09490', 'trackingNbr': '1k1-8x5g-yssh', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,
Please listen with open ears in regards to your actions with protected public lands. If your mother or father's tombstone was abruptly moved to another location or that area was used for another purpose how would that make you feel? Just like that area where your mother or father may be buried or will be buried is designated to honor them, let these protected public lands be preserved to honor the memories and people that have contributed to protecting this land. Please consider environmental concerns and the backlash you and your fellow staff members will receive. Thanks,

-Jay Wilson

Protected public lands are an important part of what makes America great. I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.

Since President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act into law in 1906, 16 Presidents - 8 Republicans and 8 Democrats - have used the authority granted by the act to safeguard public lands, oceans, and historic sites in order to share America's story with future generations. These national monument designations are broadly supported from coast to coast and provide a myriad of benefits to local communities, including economic boosts from tourism, places to enjoy the outdoors, clean air and water, protection for ecologically sensitive areas, and windows into our country's history.

Sending a signal that protections for our shared history, culture, and natural treasures are temporary would set a terrible precedent. National monuments have been shown to be tremendous drivers of the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities.

From Maine's magnificent Katahdin Woods to the colorful canyons of Utah's Grand Staircase-Escalante to the western history held in New Mexico's Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks, these landmarks, landscapes, and seascapes have value which far exceeds their physical features; they manifest the core democratic ideals of freedom, justice, and equality. They are our legacy to our children and our children's children, and a gift that belongs to all Americans.

I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for our national monuments. I urge you to support the following list of National Monuments and recommend that our current national monuments remain as they are today.

AMERICAN SAMOA
Rose Atoll

ARIZONA
Grand Canyon - Parashant

comment:
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,

Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our shared historical, cultural, and natural heritage. I am concerned that the recent Executive Order attempts to undermine our national monuments and to roll back protections of these public lands. Protected public lands are an important part of what makes America great. I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.

Since President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act into law in 1906, 16 Presidents - 8 Republicans and 8 Democrats - have used the authority granted by the act to safeguard public lands, oceans, and historic sites in order to share America's story with future generations. These national monument designations are broadly supported from coast to coast and provide a myriad of benefits to local communities, including economic boosts from tourism, places to enjoy the outdoors, clean air and water, protection for ecologically sensitive areas, and windows into our country's history.

Sending a signal that protections for our shared history, culture, and natural treasures are temporary would set a terrible precedent. National monuments have been shown to be tremendous drivers of the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities.

From Maine's magnificent Katahdin Woods to the colorful canyons of Utah's Grand Staircase-Escalante to the western history held in New Mexico's Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks, these landmarks, landscapes, and seascapes have value which far exceeds their physical features; they manifest the core democratic ideals of freedom, justice, and equality. They are our legacy to our children and our children's children, and a gift that belongs to all Americans.

I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for our national monuments. I urge you to support the following list of National Monuments and recommend that our current national monuments remain as they are today.

AMERICAN SAMOA
Rose Atoll

ARIZONA
Grand Canyon - Parashant
Ironwood Forest
Vermillion Cliffs
Sonoran Desert

CALIFORNIA
Giant Sequoia

comment:
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,

Each and every park you are reviewing had public consultation completed before being created. Respect that. Dont give in to big resource extraction businesses. Support all the small tourism and recreation businesses those monuments support. (As if protecting the land and wildlife is not enough). Dont be bullied into reducing the size of any of these monuments.. Not one acre.

Sincerely,
Donna Larsen
Las Cruces, NM 88011

comment:
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,

Stop shrinking our majestic lands so that we can preserve them for our children and for ourselves. We do not need more mini malls in place of this beautiful landscape. Just say no to shrinking or eliminating our monuments.

{'commentOn': '09000064825a1f28', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'DOI-2017-0002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'DOI', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'The thing I am most proud of America for is our dedication to preserving public land. Because of this, I would like to urge Ryan Zinke to resist the land-grab attempts and to keep all National Monuments intact, as they are. As a Utahn living in Salt Lake, I would especially like protections and borders to remain as is in Bears Ears and Escalante. I visit both frequently and I want my children and grandchildren to be able to enjoy them also, which is the point of the antiquities act: to preserve for all Americans, present and future. Setting a precedent of shrinking or removing these monuments will forever endanger our legacy. So please leave the monuments as they are!

Douglas Rombough
456 e 1300 s
Salt Lake City, UT 84115
Drrombough@gmail.com', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'DOI-2017-0002', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Douglas', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064827779ba', 'lastName': 'Rombough', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2017-06-25T13:39:43Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2017-06-25T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2017-06-25T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2017-09490', 'trackingNbr': '1k1-8x5o-xdj3', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
The thing I am most proud of America for is our dedication to preserving public land. Because of this, I would like to urge Ryan Zinke to resist the land-grab attempts and to keep all National Monuments intact, as they are. As a Utahn living in Salt Lake, I would especially like protections and borders to remain as is in Bears Ears and Escalante. I visit both frequently and I want my children and grandchildren to be able to enjoy them also, which is the point of the antiquities act: to preserve for all Americans, present and future. Setting a precedent of shrinking or removing these monuments will forever endanger our legacy. So please leave the monuments as they are!

Douglas Rombough
456 e 1300 s
Salt Lake City, UT 84115
Drrombough@gmail.com

{'commentOn': '09000064825a1f28', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'DOI-2017-0002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'DOI', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Dear Secretary Zinke,

I am a Montanan who had spent considerable time in the Upper Missouri River Breaks National Monument here in Montana. The most recent time was this May when I paddled from Coal Banks Landing to the Judith River, spending a week hiking the Breaks.

As usual, I found the monument teeming with wildlife and I thoroughly enjoyed visiting the numerous historic sites along the way. I have also noticed the partnership between the BLM and local ranchers that allows for grazing in the monument.

I strongly urge you to not recommend any changes to this incredible area of Montana. Keep it as it is!!

Michael Koeppen

comment:
Dear Secretary Zinke,

I am a Montanan who had spent considerable time in the Upper Missouri River Breaks National Monument here in Montana. The most recent time was this May when I paddled from Coal Banks Landing to the Judith River, spending a week hiking the Breaks.

As usual, I found the monument teeming with wildlife and I thoroughly enjoyed visiting the numerous historic sites along the way. I have also noticed the partnership between the BLM and local ranchers that allows for grazing in the monument.

I strongly urge you to not recommend any changes to this incredible area of Montana. Keep it as it is!!

Michael Koeppen
Florence, Montana

{'commentOn': '09000064800b8893', 'commentOnDocumentId': None, 'duplicateComments': 1, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'EPA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'especially our children who are being harmed by this toxic pesticide. Not only is it in the food we eat, but we are exposed to it with headlice and scabies treatments.
Lindane has caused seizures, aplasitc anemia, has been linked to Parkinson's disease, epilepsy, breast cancer, brain cancer and in some instances death.
It is still used as a pediculide and scabicide on our most vunerable, our children and the elderly.
Lindane is covered by medicaid and Child Health Plus, so as to give our neediest citizens no choice but to get Lindane by prescription, when there are far safer treatments available, such as a lice comb and nontoxic shampoos and lotions.
I'm sure you are aware that there are many cases of adverse effects from Lindane, some reported to Medwatch, but sadly many more are not reported.
Many times a physician does not have the knowledge to connect an illness to Lindane.
Or a trusting parent using Lindane on their child, not realizing just how toxic lindane is, only to have their child suffer permanent injury.
I hope the EPA considers banning lindane completely, thus helping to ensure a healthier quality of life for our children, our future.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'EPA-HQ-OPP-2004-0246', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064800b88f8', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2006-09-02T14:00:21Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 1, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2005-05-01T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2005-05-01T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Comments Submitted by a Private Citizen', 'trackingNbr': '800b88f8', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
especially our children who are being harmed by this toxic pesticide. Not only is it in the food we eat, but we are exposed to it with headlice and scabies treatments.
Lindane has caused seizures, aplasitc anemia, has been linked to Parkinson's disease, epilepsy, breast cancer, brain cancer and in some instances death.
It is still used as a pediculide and scabicide on our most vunerable, our children and the elderly.
Lindane is covered by medicaid and Child Health Plus, so as to give our neediest citizens no choice but to get Lindane by prescription, when there are far safer treatments available, such as a lice comb and nontoxic shampoos and lotions.
I'm sure you are aware that there are many cases of adverse effects from Lindane, some reported to Medwatch, but sadly many more are not reported.
Many times a physician does not have the knowledge to connect an illness to Lindane.
Or a trusting parent using Lindane on their child, not realizing just how toxic lindane is, only to have their child suffer permanent injury.
I hope the EPA considers banning lindane completely, thus helping to ensure a healthier quality of life for our children, our future.
