comment:
This is to express my hope that the Washinton ADIZ will not be made permanent. I don't fly in the Washington area, but my fear is that this unnecessary restriction on general aviation will spread to other airports in the country.
I've been a private pilot since 1999. I have a little over 800 hours total time and I fly about 100 hours per year. I own a 1960 Champion 7EC that was completely restored a couple years ago.
I'm a fair weather VFR pilot, but I do use my plane as a transportation tool on occasion. From where I hangar at Oelwein, IA (OLZ) I can fly to Schaumburg, IL (06C) in about two hours and take a taxi to O'Hare (ORD) to catch a flight to wherever I need to go. For me to drive to O'Hare would take over 5 hours.
I've already heard rumblings that the Mayor of Chicago wants his own ADIZ, just like the one in Washington. Well, we all know what a friend to general aviation he is.
The financial losses to businesses in the Washington ADIZ area is well documented. The inconvenience to travelers who use general aviation is apparent. The irony is that it isn't little airplanes like mine that brought about the perceived need for this ADIZ, and it isn't little airplanes that pose any real threat to our nation's security. Unfortunately it is the little planes that are made to suffer the consequences to mollify the fears of an uninformed public.
If the ADIZ in Washington is made permanent we can chalk that up as a victory for the terrorists. Their goal is to destroy our way of life and our freedoms. Clear thinking must realize that a permanent ADIZ in Washington, or any of our other cities, doesn't really offer us any heightened security, and it comes at way too high a cost.
Thank you for your consideration of my concerns.
Jim Tuchscherer
621 W Charles St
Oelwein, IA 50662

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '535 La Marina', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Santa Barbara', 'category': None, 'comment': 'I am a newly licensed private pilot with a VFR rating. I live in Santa Barbara, California but visit my family in Philadelphia, PA on a regular basis. I rent aircraft in Santa Barbara and Philadelphia for both personal and business transportation.

I was alarmed to see the FAA create the ADIZ rule. This was done without any reasonable consideration of usefulness or consequences. Due to the complexity of the existing ADIZ rule, I have chosen to avoid flying in the Washington, DC area, and have taken my business to other locations. In at least one case, I determined that the potential risk of an inadvertent ADIZ violation outweighted any benefit from my travel to the area, and so I cancelled by planned trip.

I believe that the existing 15 mile Flight Restricted Zone is adequate to protect the region. There is no evidence that the ADIZ has created a more effective deterrent to terrorist activities. In my view, the ADIZ itself has created exactly the type of economic costs and disruption that terrorist have stated they wish to create in the United States – an atmosphere of unreasonable fear and additional costs. In that way, it could be viewed that the creation of the ADIZ supports the ultimate goals of the terrorists it purported seeks to defend against. In that way, the proposed rule is seriously flawed. I request that the FAA hold public hearings on this matter.

Very truly yours,

David H. Paul, M.D.

Due to the complexity of the existing ADIZ rule, I have chosen to avoid flying in the Washington, DC area, and have taken my business to other locations. In at least one case, I determined that the potential risk of an inadvertent ADIZ violation outweighted any benefit from my travel to the area, and so I cancelled by planned trip.

I believe that the existing 15 mile Flight Restricted Zone is adequate to protect the region. There is no evidence that the ADIZ has created a more effective deterrent to terrorist activities. In my view, the ADIZ itself has created exactly the type of economic costs and disruption that terrorist have stated they wish to create in the United States – an atmosphere of unreasonable fear and additional costs. In that way, it could be viewed that the creation of the ADIZ supports the ultimate goals of the terrorists it purported seeks to defend against. In that way, the proposed rule is seriously flawed. I request that the FAA hold public hearings on this matter.

Very truly yours,

David H. Paul, M.D.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '129 Glendale Drive', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'New Windsor', 'category': None, 'comment': "To FAA and all concerned:

I am a private pilot with 100 hours logged to date. My family and I rent planes to go on day and weekend trips to some of our favorite spots in the northeast.

I am extremely against the Washington DC ATIZ. I live near the New York class B area, and with all of the unnecessary TRF’s and other airspace restrictions (most importantly the Washington DC ATIZ). It is almost impossible for the controllers to have time to give flight following or other services that greatly increase the safety of all pilots. To leave the Washington DC ATIZ, or worse by making it permanent, will not only cripple aviation, but also take away the freedom from all Americans that this country is based on.

", 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'postmarkDate', 'label': 'Answer Date', 'tooltip': 'Date the document was postmarked'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FAA-2004-17005', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'George', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064802e69a3', 'lastName': 'Ciaschi', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-06-02T04:51:14Z', 'organization': 'AOPA', 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2005-10-24T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': '2005-10-24T04:00:00Z', 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2005-10-24T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'New York', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'George Ciaschi - Comments', 'trackingNbr': '802e69a3', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '12553', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
To FAA and all concerned:

I am a private pilot with 100 hours logged to date. My family and I rent planes to go on day and weekend trips to some of our favorite spots in the northeast.

I am extremely against the Washington DC ATIZ. I live near the New York class B area, and with all of the unnecessary TRF’s and other airspace restrictions (most importantly the Washington DC ATIZ). It is almost impossible for the controllers to have time to give flight following or other services that greatly increase the safety of all pilots. To leave the Washington DC ATIZ, or worse by making it permanent, will not only cripple aviation, but also take away the freedom from all Americans that this country is based on.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064802e6127', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FAA-2004-17005-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': 'PO Box 812', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FAA', 'city': 'Ironwood', 'category': None, 'comment': 'To whom it may concern,

My name is Gordon Hart. I am a Commercial, Multi-engine instrument rated pilot. I have logged nearly 500 hours to date. I fly primarily for pleasure but hope to fly for business purposes and am working towards my CFI. I live and fly in the Midwest and have occasion to fly near places like Milwaukee, Chicago, Detroit and Cleveland.

My belief is that the Washington, DC Air Defense Identification Zone (ADIZ) is operationally unworkable and imposes major burdens on pilots and air traffic controllers alike, all with minimal security benefits, and it must NOT be made permanent.

No general aviation aircraft as ever been used in a terrorist attack. And the government has determined that not a single ADIZ violation was terrorist-related.

Protecting the Washington, DC area can be achieved with the existing requirements for the 15-mile Flight Restricted Zone (FRZ), but lighter aircraft, flying at slower speeds, should not be subject to the current ADIZ requirements for filing a flight plan, obtaining a unique transponder code and maintaining two-way communications with air traffic control.

The proposed rule is flawed because the evaluation of the economic and operational impacts on pilots and aviation businesses and an analysis of alternatives are insufficient.

Sincerely,

Gordon L. Hart

comment:
To whom it may concern,

My name is Gordon Hart. I am a Commercial, Multi-engine instrument rated pilot. I have logged nearly 500 hours to date. I fly primarily for pleasure but hope to fly for business purposes and am working towards my CFI. I live and fly in the Midwest and have occasion to fly near places like Milwaukee, Chicago, Detroit and Cleveland.

My belief is that the Washington, DC Air Defense Identification Zone (ADIZ) is operationally unworkable and imposes major burdens on pilots and air traffic controllers alike, all with minimal security benefits, and it must NOT be made permanent.

No general aviation aircraft as ever been used in a terrorist attack. And the government has determined that not a single ADIZ violation was terrorist-related.

Protecting the Washington, DC area can be achieved with the existing requirements for the 15-mile Flight Restricted Zone (FRZ), but lighter aircraft, flying at slower speeds, should not be subject to the current ADIZ requirements for filing a flight plan, obtaining a unique transponder code and maintaining two-way communications with air traffic control.

The proposed rule is flawed because the evaluation of the economic and operational impacts on pilots and aviation businesses and an analysis of alternatives are insufficient.

Sincerely,

Gordon L. Hart

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481c95e75', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2015-N-2002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual Consumer', 'comment': 'I am commenting on the Proposed Rule "Clarification of When Products Made or Derived From Tobacco Are Regulated as Drugs, Devices, or Combination Products; Amendments to Regulations Regarding 'Intended Uses'"(Docket No. FDA-2015-N-2002)

I was a cigarette smoker for 35 years and I had tried stopping many time with no success. Little more than 4 years ago a friend told me about e-cigarettes, so at the mall there was a booth that was selling this little cigarette looking e-cigarettes so I got one. It was ok? But I still wanted a cigarette most of the time. there was a e-cigarettes shop in town I heard about. So I stopped by and talked to the people working in it and they showed me some of the newer e-cigarettes and told me that these were a much better equivalent to a real cigarette but that it was much less harmful. It didn't look anything like a cigarette but I bought one And gave it a try that was 4 years ago and I haven't had a cigarette since that day. comment:
I am commenting on the Proposed Rule "Clarification of When Products Made or Derived From Tobacco Are Regulated as Drugs, Devices, or Combination Products; Amendments to Regulations Regarding 'Intended Uses'"(Docket No. FDA-2015-N-2002)

I was a cigarette smoker for 35 years and I had tried stopping many time with no success. Little more than 4 years ago a friend told me about e-cigarettes, so at the mall there was a booth that was selling this little cigarette looking e-cigarettes so I got one. It was ok? But I still wanted a cigarette most of the time. there was a e-cigarettes shop in town I heard about. So I stopped by and talked to the people working in it and they showed me some of the newer e-cigarettes and told me that these were a much better equivalent to a real cigarette but that it was much less harmful. It didn't look anything like a cigarette but I bought one And gave it a try that was 4 years ago and I haven't had a cigarette since that day. I have Asthma/COPD and I was using a lot of medicines for it now 4 years later I'm off of a lot of the medicines and doing much better. But if I would have to go back to those little cigarette looking e-cigs I know it would be know time until I would be back to using tobacco cigarettes again and I hate that Idea. But I know I can't stop.

Thank You for your time

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481c95e75', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2015-N-2002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual Consumer', 'comment': 'I am commenting on the Proposed Rule "Clarification of When Products Made or Derived From Tobacco Are Regulated as Drugs, Devices, or Combination Products; Amendments to Regulations Regarding 'Intended Uses'"(Docket No. FDA-2015-N-2002)
I am a CASAA member.
After wanting to quit smoking and trying without success gum, and cold turkey...
1. I First learned that e-cigarettes were an effective alternative to smoking from an e-cigarette advertisement, even though it was for a specific product I did not end up using.
2. I was also persuaded to try e-cigarettes based on information on a manufacturer's webpage.
3. I was inspired to switch by testimonials on a manufacturer's website, and from other who had tried them.
4 I received information at a vapor shop regarding how these products are an effective alternative to smoking and/or information about how you can successfully quit smoking using e-cigarettes.
I have now been "weaning" my self down from 18% Nicotine to 1.5% in under twelve months, and expect to be at zero or not even using within the next 6 months.

I think that with current laws regulating "Truth in Advertising" would be enough regulation without the FDA stepping in with additional rules, regulations or worse; laws. After smoking for over 20 years, and being able to make an informed decision by using "e-cigarettes", I have improved my physical health, eliminated harmful by products of actual cigarettes and been able to self reduce the amount of nicotine to now almost zero.
I and those like me do not need the government or it's agencies to "fix" something that does not need fixing. We have enough regulations in too many aspects of our lives. You already have rules for the tobacco industry, there is not a need for getting involved in the "e-cigarette" industry. The market demand will control itself and will either survive or will eliminate itself by market demand. The FDA should at a minimum shelf this intended regulation until further studies can be done to determine if this is harmful in itself or kill the bill completely without prejudice; versus what we all already know that tobacco is unhealthy and proven such whereas these products just without the included by products of actual cigarettes are inherently better than smoking an actual cigarette.

Thank you', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2015-N-2002', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481d66b52', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T14:23:35Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2015-11-21T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'Comment from Ed', 'trackingNbr': '1jz-8mdy-tl3u', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481c95e75', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2015-N-2002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual Consumer', 'comment': 'I am commenting on the Proposed Rule "Clarification of When Products Made or Derived From Tobacco Are Regulated as Drugs, Devices, or Combination Products; Amendments to Regulations Regarding 'Intended Uses'"(Docket No. FDA-2015-N-2002)

I was a two pack a day smoker for 14 years. Thanks to electronic cigarettes I was able to completely quit smoking tobacco for the past 5 years. My health has greatly improved, from no longer getting bronchitis or pneumonia, no more shortness of breath walking up stairs and no longer having smoker's cough.

I watched my many smoker friends switch to this safer alternative and am so grateful that I did. If not for e-cigs I would still be smoking 2 packs a day. I recall years earlier seeing an ad for an e-cig in my poker magazine that spoke about a safe alternative. Few years later, after seeing my best friend quit after 15 years I knew I could also.

Thank you', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2015-N-2002', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481d66af3', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T14:20:21Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2015-11-21T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'Comment from Jennifer Zhang', 'trackingNbr': '1jz-8mdx-bre8', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481c95e75', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2015-N-2002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual Consumer', 'comment': 'I am commenting on the Proposed Rule "Clarification of When Products Made or Derived From Tobacco Are Regulated as Drugs, Devices, or Combination Products; Amendments to Regulations Regarding 'Intended Uses'"(Docket No. FDA-2015-N-2002)

When I was considering to switch to vaping from smoking the information that first intrigued me was that is was just vapor, just like what comes out if a nebulizer for asthma treatments in the hospital. Yes, e-liquid has nicotine instead of medicine but, the two devices and liquid used in the two devices produce a vapor that are very much the same. This information helped me make the switch vaping along with the fact that it would be cheaper. Not only immediately, with buying products for vaping but also, with less health issues in the long term. I personally believe that vapor products should be sold as a healthier alternative to smoking not necessarily as a smoking cessation method, even though when you make the switch to vaping in full you are no longer smoking, you are vaping, you are still inhaling nicotine most of the time.

Thank you for taking the time to review my comment.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2015-N-2002', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481d66afe', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T14:18:20Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2015-11-21T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'Comment from Andrew Wallace', 'trackingNbr': '1jz-8mdx-8u3s', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481c95e75', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FDA-2015-N-2002-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FDA', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual Consumer', 'comment': 'I am commenting on the Proposed Rule "Clarification of When Products Made or Derived From Tobacco Are Regulated as Drugs, Devices, or Combination Products; Amendments to Regulations Regarding 'Intended Uses'"(Docket No. FDA-2015-N-2002). I learned of the new proposal issued by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) through an organized consumer association called "The Consumer Advocates for Smoke-free Alternatives Association" (CASAA) that I am a member of. You can visit their web site at:

http://casaa.org

I started using electronic cigarettes 5 years ago and have quit smoking and using tobacco for 4 years. If this proposed regulation was in place then, I doubt I would be tobacco free now. Initially, I saw advertisements on manufacturer's web sites indicating that using electronic cigarettes are a safer alternative to tobacco cigarettes, which I will call "analog cigarettes." I grew interested and soon some of my friends started using them. They received information online and on stands for product displays about electronic cigarettes being a safe alternative to smoking. I was skeptical until I saw they quit using analog cigarettes after a while and witnessed their health and quality of life improve.

I decided to buy a simple starter device at a convenience store at that point. I was able to cut back on my use of analog cigarettes, but could not replace them at that point with the device I had. I heard about a good vape shop from a friend and decided to pay a visit. They informed me that I should try using different e-liquid with higher nicotine and higher quality ingredients along with a different device if I wanted to be successful in replacing analog cigarettes.

After about a year, I learned through the vape shops, online advertisements, and word of mouth about other smaller, private companies that produced devices and e-liquid for use as an alternative to smoking analog cigarettes. These products gave me a sufficient experience to that of smoking an analog cigarette, and so the electronic cigarettes replaced the analog cigarettes. In fact, with the current devices I have access to and the quality e-liquids that are out there, I always prefer to use electronic cigarettes over analog cigarettes because of the good flavors and adequate vapor they emit. I enjoy the variety of flavors that are out there, whether it be fruits, candy, baked goods, tobacco, drinks, menthol, or others. It's also fun to do it yourself (DIY) and make my own flavors.

In the end, I no longer crave tobacco products. Electronic cigarettes have now easily replaced my tobacco use, thanks to companies and people informing me that I can use electronic cigarettes to replace smoking analog cigarettes. As a result of consuming electronic cigarette products, my health and quality of life have much improved. It has become a hobby for me and I am a happier and healthier person as a result of using the safer electronic cigarettes as an alternative to analog cigarettes.

I want to mention an association within the e-liquid industry called American E-Liquid Manufacturing Standards Association (AEMSA), est. 2012. They are making strides in self-regulation including facility, ingredients, traceability, delivery, packaging, and transaction standards in the industry. All of these standards combined provide part of the solution to safe e-liquid consumption. It ensures safety in all aspects of e-liquid manufacturing and shipping to protect workers, consumers, and others. Their website can be found at:

http://www.aemsa.org/

Thank you.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FDA-2015-N-2002', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481d66b62', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T14:30:13Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2015-11-21T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Electronic Regulation from Form', 'title': 'Comment from Michael Scheeres', 'trackingNbr': '1jz-8mdy-bo9f', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I am commenting on the Proposed Rule "Clarification of When Products Made or Derived From Tobacco Are Regulated as Drugs, Devices, or Combination Products; Amendments to Regulations Regarding 'Intended Uses'"(Docket No. FDA-2015-N-2002). I learned of the new proposal issued by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) through an organized consumer association called "The Consumer Advocates for Smoke-free Alternatives Association" (CASAA) that I am a member of. You can visit their web site at:

http://casaa.org

I started using electronic cigarettes 5 years ago and have quit smoking and using tobacco for 4 years. If this proposed regulation was in place then, I doubt I would be tobacco free now. Initially, I saw advertisements on manufacturer's web sites indicating that using electronic cigarettes are a safer alternative to tobacco cigarettes, which I will call "analog cigarettes." I grew interested and soon some of my friends started using them. They received information online and on stands for product displays about electronic cigarettes being a safe alternative to smoking. I was skeptical until I saw they quit using analog cigarettes after a while and witnessed their health and quality of life improve.

I decided to buy a simple starter device at a convenience store at that point. I was able to cut back on my use of analog cigarettes, but could not replace them at that point with the device I had. I heard about a good vape shop from a friend and decided to pay a visit. They informed me that I should try using different e-liquid with higher nicotine and higher quality ingredients along with a different device if I wanted to be successful in replacing analog cigarettes.

After about a year, I learned through the vape shops, online advertisements, and word of mouth about other smaller, private companies that produced devices and e-liquid for use as an alternative to smoking analog cigarettes. These products gave me a sufficient experience to that of smoking an analog cigarette, and so the electronic cigarettes replaced the analog cigarettes. In fact, with the current devices I have access to and the quality e-liquids that are out there, I always prefer to use electronic cigarettes over analog cigarettes because of the good flavors and adequate vapor they emit. I enjoy the variety of flavors that are out there, whether it be fruits, candy, baked goods, tobacco, drinks, menthol, or others. It's also fun to do it yourself (DIY) and make my own flavors.

In the end, I no longer crave tobacco products. Electronic cigarettes have now easily replaced my tobacco use, thanks to companies and people informing me that I can use electronic cigarettes to replace smoking analog cigarettes. As a result of consuming electronic cigarette products, my health and quality of life have much improved. It has become a hobby for me and I am a happier and healthier person as a result of using the safer electronic cigarettes as an alternative to analog cigarettes.

I want to mention an association within the e-liquid industry called American E-Liquid Manufacturing Standards Association (AEMSA), est. 2012. They are making strides in self-regulation including facility, ingredients, traceability, delivery, packaging, and transaction standards in the industry. All of these standards combined provide part of the solution to safe e-liquid consumption. It ensures safety in all aspects of e-liquid manufacturing and shipping to protect workers, consumers, and others. Their website can be found at:

http://www.aemsa.org/

Thank you.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481dde800', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCIS-2015-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCIS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'This is Un American. It is an afront to all Americans and must be stopped. This is not only WRONG, but it is illegal under the U.S. Constitution. Presidents do not get to enact laws! Since when does a President get to overule Congress on a domestic matter?

The proposed rule would increase the number of foreign citizens authorized to work in the United States above the limits set by Congress. These lower paid foreign workers will be able to take jobs in hundreds of industries at the expense of American workers and their wages. Under the proposed rule, DHS will issue work permits to foreign workers after the six-year limit imposed by Congress expires. I believe this rule will encourage employers to submit more applications for employment-based green cards on behalf of foreign tech workers, knowing that the workers will be able to stay regardless of whether a green card is even available. This proposed rule hurts American tech workers and students who are earning degrees in STEM fields and should be withdrawn.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'USCIS-2015-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481e4f39c', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T17:39:25Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-02-04T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment Submitted by Ken Sorensen', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8nrr-uzwi', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
This is Un American. It is an afront to all Americans and must be stopped. This is not only WRONG, but it is illegal under the U.S. Constitution. Presidents do not get to enact laws! Since when does a President get to overule Congress on a domestic matter?

The proposed rule would increase the number of foreign citizens authorized to work in the United States above the limits set by Congress. These lower paid foreign workers will be able to take jobs in hundreds of industries at the expense of American workers and their wages. Under the proposed rule, DHS will issue work permits to foreign workers after the six-year limit imposed by Congress expires. I believe this rule will encourage employers to submit more applications for employment-based green cards on behalf of foreign tech workers, knowing that the workers will be able to stay regardless of whether a green card is even available. This proposed rule hurts American tech workers and students who are earning degrees in STEM fields and should be withdrawn.

comment:
This guideline won't help high-skilled immigrants, please consider the underneath remarks while actualizing the last run the show.

1. Give EAD and Advance Parole to I-140 approved holders following 3 years for EB2 and following 5 years for EB-3.

2. Rule ought to give portability not to re-apply PERM and I-140 in the event that one changes employer.

Much obliged to you.

attributes: {'commentOn': '0900006481dde800', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCIS-2015-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCIS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'America is a land of opportunities only for some immigrants. attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481dde800', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCIS-2015-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCIS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'The proposed rule in it's current form doesn't help the legal immigrant community. Please consider to include following suggestions to the proposed rule.

1. No "compelling circumstance" was required to issue EAD's for DACA and H4 EAD. why is it required now? Please remove "compelling circumstance" from proposed rule.

2. EADs should be issued for 3 years which should be renewable till the applicant and dependents can file AOS.

3. Allowing for EAD renewal only if the PD is close to 1 year of cut-off date in VB does not make sense as cutoff date movement in VB is unpredictable. Does USCIS itself know where the cut-off dates for India will be 1 or 2 years from now? How can an applicant know if he will be eligible for EAD extension based on his PD date? This requirement should be removed.

', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'USCIS-2015-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481e5617c', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T12:51:38Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment Submitted by Lavanya Paruchuri', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8nsk-iqwd', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
The proposed rule in it's current form doesn't help the legal immigrant community. Please consider to include following suggestions to the proposed rule.

1. No "compelling circumstance" was required to issue EAD's for DACA and H4 EAD. why is it required now? Please remove "compelling circumstance" from proposed rule.

2. EADs should be issued for 3 years which should be renewable till the applicant and dependents can file AOS.

3. Allowing for EAD renewal only if the PD is close to 1 year of cut-off date in VB does not make sense as cutoff date movement in VB is unpredictable. Does USCIS itself know where the cut-off dates for India will be 1 or 2 years from now? How can an applicant know if he will be eligible for EAD extension based on his PD date? This requirement should be removed.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481dde800', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCIS-2015-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCIS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'I completely oppose this disappointing proposed rule in its current half baked form. Here are some recommendations:
1. EAD for all approved I-140 holders (may be after 180 days or certain duration)
2. Eliminating the need to file PERM and I-140 again if switching employers, whether for same/ similar occupation or change in role/ duties.
3. Removing compelling circumstance clause in the draft rule. "Compelling circumstance" is very subjective. How does this make the life of an applicant easy?
4. Extending the 60 day grace period to include usage of this period more than once. Considering most people in EB2 &3 India category have stayed here more than 6 years and are highly skilled immigrants, it is only fair that this be extended.

5. Advance Parole to ease the travel
', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'USCIS-2015-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481e56805', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T17:39:36Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment Submitted by Sachin Saxena (2nd Comment)', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8nso-xkv2', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I completely oppose this disappointing proposed rule in its current half baked form. Here are some recommendations:
1. EAD for all approved I-140 holders (may be after 180 days or certain duration)
2. Eliminating the need to file PERM and I-140 again if switching employers, whether for same/ similar occupation or change in role/ duties.
3. Removing compelling circumstance clause in the draft rule. "Compelling circumstance" is very subjective. How does this make the life of an applicant easy?
4. Extending the 60 day grace period to include usage of this period more than once. Considering most people in EB2 &3 India category have stayed here more than 6 years and are highly skilled immigrants, it is only fair that this be extended.

5. Advance Parole to ease the travel

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481dde800', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCIS-2015-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCIS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'I strongly oppose this rule in its current form because it does not allow filing I-485 EAD/AP when 140 approved petitioner is waiting for the priority date to become current. This was exactly what Mr. President proposed in the EO made on immigration and the current proposal published failed to address it.

I am working in a development position (same employer) in a product company for 7 years and have a 140 approved petition. My PERM took over 2 years to certify because of randam audits and very long processing backlogs in PWD and PERM certification. Overall to reach 140 approved stage it took 3 years,

I am neither able to take up management positions in the same company nor move to a different employer because of the fact that I have to refile PERM from scratch and it is going to be another 3+ years.

The current regulation needs to be modified to provide the portability to change positions without having the need to refile PERM and 140 again by allowing applicants to file I-485 when they have 140 approved petitions and their priority date is backlogged for the EB classification.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'USCIS-2015-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481e56729', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T12:51:45Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment Submitted by Karthik Arun Koteeswaran', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8nsl-p56z', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I strongly oppose this rule in its current form because it does not allow filing I-485 EAD/AP when 140 approved petitioner is waiting for the priority date to become current. This was exactly what Mr. President proposed in the EO made on immigration and the current proposal published failed to address it.

I am working in a development position (same employer) in a product company for 7 years and have a 140 approved petition. My PERM took over 2 years to certify because of randam audits and very long processing backlogs in PWD and PERM certification. Overall to reach 140 approved stage it took 3 years,

I am neither able to take up management positions in the same company nor move to a different employer because of the fact that I have to refile PERM from scratch and it is going to be another 3+ years.

The current regulation needs to be modified to provide the portability to change positions without having the need to refile PERM and 140 again by allowing applicants to file I-485 when they have 140 approved petitions and their priority date is backlogged for the EB classification.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481dde800', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCIS-2015-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCIS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'When president announced this E.O, as an Indian on H1 visa awaiting the long route to green card, I was overjoyed to hear that I and my family would soon be able to apply for EAD card. Not green card, EAD card. Green card is still a distant dream for us Indians on employment based category. But now, reading this proposal, all my hopes are crushed.

What is a "compelling circumstance"? A H1b from any other country in the world can get their green card in 3-4 years. But someone from India has wait over 10 years? Is this fair? Is this just? Having to wait so long is a "compelling circumstance". I would request you to make changes such that anyone with approved I140 who has been waiting for more than 2 years should be eligible for EAD. Last time I went to India, I had to renew my visa and my visa renewal was refused on grounds of 221(g) administrative processing. I was told, the delay is usually around 90 days. It ended up being 9 months! Please also issue a advance parole along with this EAD. There is no point of issuing just the EAD without the AP.

The wait for green card for an Indian on EB2 and EB3 category is painful and excruciatingly long. I do not think it is fair to single out someone for such treatment based on their country of birth. Please allow EAD and AP for I140 approved cases. The rule in its current form is just a waste of time and is not going to help anyone.
', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'USCIS-2015-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481e567c1', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T12:51:48Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment Submitted by Rajeev Shukla', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8nsm-ymer', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
When president announced this E.O, as an Indian on H1 visa awaiting the long route to green card, I was overjoyed to hear that I and my family would soon be able to apply for EAD card. Not green card, EAD card. Green card is still a distant dream for us Indians on employment based category. But now, reading this proposal, all my hopes are crushed.

What is a "compelling circumstance"? A H1b from any other country in the world can get their green card in 3-4 years. But someone from India has wait over 10 years? Is this fair? Is this just? Having to wait so long is a "compelling circumstance". I would request you to make changes such that anyone with approved I140 who has been waiting for more than 2 years should be eligible for EAD. Last time I went to India, I had to renew my visa and my visa renewal was refused on grounds of 221(g) administrative processing. I was told, the delay is usually around 90 days. It ended up being 9 months! Please also issue a advance parole along with this EAD. There is no point of issuing just the EAD without the AP.

The wait for green card for an Indian on EB2 and EB3 category is painful and excruciatingly long. I do not think it is fair to single out someone for such treatment based on their country of birth. Please allow EAD and AP for I140 approved cases. The rule in its current form is just a waste of time and is not going to help anyone.

attributes: {'commentOn': '0900006481dde800', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCIS-2015-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCIS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'I don't see anything there in the new rule. I am totally disapointed with the new rule. It is just the clarification of the old rule, nothing else. Simple word, after I-140 approve please issue EAD with AP so that we can work peacefully and contribute to US economy. There is no reason not to give EAD - AP to the non immigrant who has approved I-140. If there is any issue please prove that.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'USCIS-2015-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481e5688a', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T12:51:50Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment Submitted by Anirban Roy', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8nsn-9646', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: I don't see anything there in the new rule. I am totally disapointed with the new rule. It is just the clarification of the old rule, nothing else. Simple word, after I-140 approve please issue EAD with AP so that we can work peacefully and contribute to US economy. There is no reason not to give EAD - AP to the non immigrant who has approved I-140. If there is any issue please prove that.

attributes: {'commentOn': '0900006481dde800', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCIS-2015-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCIS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'We do not need more foreign workers. It has been shown that Disney and most of the tech companies are laying off American workers and making them train their foreign replacements. The labor participation rate is 62%. Americans cannot find jobs and any new job is snapped up by a foreign  and / or illegal cheaper worker. What is wrong with this government. It is no longer for the people. Immigration should be for the benefit of America, not big business and corrupt lawmakers that are bought off and financed by big business. Listen to Jeff Sessions, Mark Levine, Rush, and Joe Arapio. I can't wait for this next election so we can throw you out. We need Convention of States and term limits.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'USCIS-2015-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481e568e4', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T12:51:52Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment Submitted by Mike Hunt', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8nso-jnau', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: We do not need more foreign workers. It has been shown that Disney and most of the tech companies are laying off American workers and making them train their foreign replacements. The labor participation rate is 62%. Americans cannot find jobs and any new job is snapped up by a foreign  and / or illegal cheaper worker. What is wrong with this government. It is no longer for the people. Immigration should be for the benefit of America, not big business and corrupt lawmakers that are bought off and financed by big business. Listen to Jeff Sessions, Mark Levine, Rush, and Joe Arapio. I can't wait for this next election so we can throw you out. We need Convention of States and term limits.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481dde800', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCIS-2015-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCIS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'This rule will give flexibility and freedom for the person to take care of their family. Due to processing times, it takes years and we have to wait until our number comes, by approving this rule, it will put us one step ahead.
1) Provide a rule where a person approved 140 can change job without have to worry about i140 revoke.
2) Give EAD to the person and family without he/she has to renew any visa until they get Green Card. Visa renewal time/process is a nightmare.
This rule will establish faith in legal immigrants for the Government.

You can limit number of immigrants so there will be job for all. But by limiting persons ability who is already here is not fair for anybody. Specially the mental trauma the family has to go through. and also a person can not switch job easily even there is a growth. Treat every body who same with the law and give them flexibility, who are living in the US legally and paying tax.

I wish good luck to all. Thank you for giving us this opportunity. ', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'USCIS-2015-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481e568ee', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T12:51:52Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-02-05T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment Submitted by joy lobo', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8nso-6st5', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
This rule will give flexibility and freedom for the person to take care of their family. Due to processing times, it takes years and we have to wait until our number comes, by approving this rule, it will put us one step ahead.
1) Provide a rule where a person approved 140 can change job without have to worry about i140 revoke.
2) Give EAD to the person and family without he/she has to renew any visa until they get Green Card. Visa renewal time/process is a nightmare.
This rule will establish faith in legal immigrants for the Government.

You can limit number of immigrants so there will be job for all. But by limiting persons ability who is already here is not fair for anybody. Specially the mental trauma the family has to go through. and also a person can not switch job easily even there is a growth. Treat every body who same with the law and give them flexibility, who are living in the US legally and paying tax.

I wish good luck to all. Thank you for giving us this opportunity.

comment:
I came to this country 10 years ago to pursue Masters. I have been with same employer for past 8 years and have lost many opportunities for the fear starting all the process for I140 over and over again. We have atmost 2 years every time we file for H1. These days getting 3 year H1 has become an achievement. If approved for 3 years H1 then have to find a job prove your self worthy for new employer to start the GC process. Every major employer wants at least a year to two to do this.

It is challenging to progress when your immigration status is so vague. Same applies to make any investment decision. Not able to invest in any thing like home or business.

Please, Keep it simple. Let employees change Jobs without any need to involve existing or new employer.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006481dde800', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCIS-2015-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCIS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Here are some of my comments and suggestions:

Allow porting to a new employer with approved I-140 so that the employee does not have to restart the Green Card (GC) process all over again. This is the biggest deterrent against job mobility and hinders the engineering talent to solve some of the challenges faced by humanity today. This ability to change employers in turn help in jobs creation and improving the economy with the engineering skills of the GC Applicants.

Advance Parole should be provided along with EADs (Employment Authorization Documents) so that applicants can travel to their home countries for Emergencies or planned vacation without any difficulties. This should be provided to H1B applicants and their dependents who are already on their path to becoming Legal Permanent Residents and citizens of this country.

EADs should be issued for 3 years which should be renewable till the applicant and dependents can file AOS.

Adjudicate H4 EADs within 90 days. If it cannot be approved, USCIS should issue interim EADs. The EAD applicant has to take unpaid leave and may even be fired from the job with no fault of their own and even after applying in a timely fashion. USCIS should make every attempt to issue EADs in timely fashion or issue interim EADs to prevent work disruptions.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'USCIS-2015-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481e57526', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T12:51:59Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-02-06T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment Submitted by Vinod Machcharla', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8nsy-2fzy', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Here are some of my comments and suggestions:

Allow porting to a new employer with approved I-140 so that the employee does not have to restart the Green Card (GC) process all over again. This is the biggest deterrent against job mobility and hinders the engineering talent to solve some of the challenges faced by humanity today. This ability to change employers in turn help in jobs creation and improving the economy with the engineering skills of the GC Applicants.

Advance Parole should be provided along with EADs (Employment Authorization Documents) so that applicants can travel to their home countries for Emergencies or planned vacation without any difficulties. This should be provided to H1B applicants and their dependents who are already on their path to becoming Legal Permanent Residents and citizens of this country.

EADs should be issued for 3 years which should be renewable till the applicant and dependents can file AOS.

Adjudicate H4 EADs within 90 days. If it cannot be approved, USCIS should issue interim EADs. The EAD applicant has to take unpaid leave and may even be fired from the job with no fault of their own and even after applying in a timely fashion. USCIS should make every attempt to issue EADs in timely fashion or issue interim EADs to prevent work disruptions.

attributes: {'commentOn': '0900006481dde800', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'USCIS-2015-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'USCIS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Please provide individuals waiting in this lengthy green card backlog with work authorization immediately as these individuals are being exploited by employers due to the lack of choice switching jobs and as a result citizens are not being considered for such opportunities. Why not make the playing field even and let these individuals who will anyways be permanent residents in due course have to compete with American workers. The disadvantage that such backlogged individuals have in the form of limitation to switch jobs, is in fact a huge disadvantage for the American workforce in reality.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'USCIS-2015-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481e576b3', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2016-02-08T12:52:00Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2016-02-08T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2016-02-06T05:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Comment(s)', 'title': 'Comment Submitted by S Mani', 'trackingNbr': '1k0-8nt2-1v8q', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: Please provide individuals waiting in this lengthy green card backlog with work authorization immediately as these individuals are being exploited by employers due to the lack of choice switching jobs and as a result citizens are not being considered for such opportunities. Why not make the playing field even and let these individuals who will anyways be permanent residents in due course have to compete with American workers. The disadvantage that such backlogged individuals have in the form of limitation to switch jobs, is in fact a huge disadvantage for the American workforce in reality.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006480fdc8a0', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'CMS-2012-0031-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'CMS', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual - I0001', 'comment': 'I urge the Obama Administration to protect and respect the rights of conscience and reverse its plan to force employers to pay directly or indirectly for contraception or abortion-inducing drugs or devices to which they may have religious or conscientious objection. To protect the sanctity of the First Amendment and the right of conscience upon which our nation was founded, this administration must act to preserve the freedom of employers to follow the dictates of their conscience. Women will still be able to freely purchase these drugs, as was the case before this regulation was proposed. However, there is no need to force employers to violate their religious beliefs and conscience and provide these drugs for free to their employees. This proposed plan will not bring down health care costs, and will gravely endanger religious freedom and the right of conscience.
', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'CMS-2012-0031', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006480fe3dd5', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2012-07-12T22:47:30Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2012-07-12T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-03-29T14:52:20Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'IN', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'FORM 6', 'trackingNbr': '80fe3dd5', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment: I urge the Obama Administration to protect and respect the rights of conscience and reverse its plan to force employers to pay directly or indirectly for contraception or abortion-inducing drugs or devices to which they may have religious or conscientious objection. To protect the sanctity of the First Amendment and the right of conscience upon which our nation was founded, this administration must act to preserve the freedom of employers to follow the dictates of their conscience. Women will still be able to freely purchase these drugs, as was the case before this regulation was proposed. However, there is no need to force employers to violate their religious beliefs and conscience and provide these drugs for free to their employees. This proposed plan will not bring down health care costs, and will gravely endanger religious freedom and the right of conscience.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '0900006480fdc8a0', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'CMS-2012-0031-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'CMS', 'city': None, 'category': 'Individual', 'comment': 'I urge the Obama administration to respect and protect the rights of conscience and discontinue plans to force employers to pay (directly or indirectly) for abortion-inducing and contraceptive drugs or devices to which they may have a religious or conscientious objection. To protect the sanctity of the First Amendment and the right of conscience upon which our nation was founded, I believe this administration must act to PRESERVE THE FREEDOM OF EMPLOYERS TO FOLLOW THE DICTATES OF THEIR CONSCIENCE. Women will still be able to freely purchase these drugs, as was the case before this regulation was proposed. However, there is no need to force employers to violate their religious beliefs and conscience and provide these drugs for free to their employees. This proposed plan will not bring down health care costs, and will gravely endanger religious freedom and the right of conscience.
Thank you for your time and attention.', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'CMS-2012-0031', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006480fe50ae', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2012-07-12T22:46:31Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2012-07-12T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-03-30T16:17:40Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'KY', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'FORM 6', 'trackingNbr': '80fe50ae', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
I urge the Obama administration to respect and protect the rights of conscience and discontinue plans to force employers to pay (directly or indirectly) for abortion-inducing and contraceptive drugs or devices to which they may have a religious or conscientious objection. To protect the sanctity of the First Amendment and the right of conscience upon which our nation was founded, I believe this administration must act to PRESERVE THE FREEDOM OF EMPLOYERS TO FOLLOW THE DICTATES OF THEIR CONSCIENCE. Women will still be able to freely purchase these drugs, as was the case before this regulation was proposed. However, there is no need to force employers to violate their religious beliefs and conscience and provide these drugs for free to their employees. This proposed plan will not bring down health care costs, and will gravely endanger religious freedom and the right of conscience.
Thank you for your time and attention.

{'commentOn': '090000648100eec9', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'SBA-2012-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '2071 Lemoine Ave #302', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'SBA', 'city': 'Fort lee', 'category': 'Other', 'comment': 'A- Keeping with the intent of Congress, foreign ownership of SBIR companies is a bad idea and should not be allowed. SBA should restore the requirement that to be considered a domestic business concern, more than 50% of the business must either directly or indirectly be owned by U.S. citizens, permanent resident aliens, or domestic (US OWNED) corporations, partnerships or limited liability companies (LLCs).

B- The proposed changes to the affiliation rules are bad for small business and the SBIR program in general. SBA should continue to apply its current affiliation provisions to the SBIR/STTR programs.', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'SBA-2012-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Kamran', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '0900006481089232', 'lastName': 'Mahbobi', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2012-07-12T14:08:41Z', 'organization': 'MaXentric Technologies, LLC', 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2012-07-12T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-07-12T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'NJ', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2012-11586', 'trackingNbr': '81089232', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '07024', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
A- Keeping with the intent of Congress, foreign ownership of SBIR companies is a bad idea and should not be allowed. SBA should restore the requirement that to be considered a domestic business concern, more than 50% of the business must either directly or indirectly be owned by U.S. citizens, permanent resident aliens, or domestic (US OWNED) corporations, partnerships or limited liability companies (LLCs).

B- The proposed changes to the affiliation rules are bad for small business and the SBIR program in general. SBA should continue to apply its current affiliation provisions to the SBIR/STTR programs.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '090000648100eec9', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'SBA-2012-0008-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': '4 Arrow Drive', 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'SBA', 'city': 'Woburn', 'category': 'Private Industry', 'comment': 'Prior to this renewed legislation, the SBIR program was a vehicle for start-up companies such as BioSense Technologies to reduce the technical and commercial risks of unproven innovative technologies to a level where private investment was comfortable assuming the risk and bringing the technology to the marketplace. Consequently, if a company obtained VC or other private investment they had ‘graduated’ from the program and no longer needed SBIR funding.

It will be tough enough going forward having to compete with well-funded home-grown companies. Don’t force us to have to compete with foreign interests too. Whatever happened to “Buy American”?

The eligibility rules as currently proposed do not reflect the intent of Congress and foreign ownership of SBIR companies should not be allowed. I support restoring the eligibility requirement that a domestic business concern be considered more than 50% of the business must either directly or indirectly be owned by U.S. citizens, permanent resident aliens, or domestic (US OWNED) corporations, partnerships or limited liability companies (LLCs).
', 'country': 'United States', 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'SBA-2012-0008', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Ron', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '090000648108948b', 'lastName': 'Rieder', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2012-07-12T15:14:11Z', 'organization': 'BioSense Technologies, Inc.', 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2012-07-12T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-07-12T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': 'MA', 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment on FR Doc # 2012-11586', 'trackingNbr': '8108948b', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': '01801', 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Prior to this renewed legislation, the SBIR program was a vehicle for start-up companies such as BioSense Technologies to reduce the technical and commercial risks of unproven innovative technologies to a level where private investment was comfortable assuming the risk and bringing the technology to the marketplace. Consequently, if a company obtained VC or other private investment they had ‘graduated’ from the program and no longer needed SBIR funding.

It will be tough enough going forward having to compete with well-funded home-grown companies. Don’t force us to have to compete with foreign interests too. Whatever happened to “Buy American”?

The eligibility rules as currently proposed do not reflect the intent of Congress and foreign ownership of SBIR companies should not be allowed. I support restoring the eligibility requirement that a domestic business concern be considered more than 50% of the business must either directly or indirectly be owned by U.S. citizens, permanent resident aliens, or domestic (US OWNED) corporations, partnerships or limited liability companies (LLCs).

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064810105bc', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'FEMA-2012-0012-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'FEMA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'The changes being proposed in a Notice of Intent from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), as well as successfully being ushered through congress, to the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) and the flood plain maps, from the perspective of a North Dakotan and Missouri River basin citizen, are another effort by one government agency of the government — FEMA — to remove any responsibility for the inadequacy of another — U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE). In my view, FEMA is, therefore, inadequate also. Residents of New Orleans and all gulf states could attest to that from a number of years ago. The changes further eliminates any assistance FEMA may provide for EMERGENCIES.

The USACE has been given the job to manage the Missouri River's mainstem dams. The initial, most-important purpose for those dams came from the desire of the region's people for flood protection for the plains of the country's bread basket. Flood protection is what began the process for the building of the dams. The many other important purposes the dams came along as bonuses. To eliminate the government-sponsored flood insurance effectively removes all accountability for flooding like what happened on the Missouri River system in the summer of 2011. And, that could have been prevented. No patronizing meetings with the USACE blaming the unpredictability of the weather will convince me or many other North Dakotans otherwise.

The USACE needs to be accountable for not fulfilling the first order of management of the dam system — flood control. Since last summer, FEMA has helped this Missouri basin landowner very little. I'd imagine the action proposed for NFIP will completely eliminate all assistance for future Corps' incompetency.

I think this action by FEMA and the action in Congress should be stopped. I will appeal to the North Dakota government officials to follow this closely for the citizens of their state. I believe they are likewise displeased by these actions.', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'FEMA-2012-0012', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064810895b0', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2012-07-12T14:51:29Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': None, 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2012-07-12T04:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2012-07-12T04:00:00Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment Submitted by J.C. Balcom', 'trackingNbr': '810895b0', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
The changes being proposed in a Notice of Intent from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), as well as successfully being ushered through congress, to the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) and the flood plain maps, from the perspective of a North Dakotan and Missouri River basin citizen, are another effort by one government agency of the government — FEMA — to remove any responsibility for the inadequacy of another — U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE). In my view, FEMA is, therefore, inadequate also. Residents of New Orleans and all gulf states could attest to that from a number of years ago. The changes further eliminates any assistance FEMA may provide for EMERGENCIES.

The USACE has been given the job to manage the Missouri River's mainstem dams. The initial, most-important purpose for those dams came from the desire of the region's people for flood protection for the plains of the country's bread basket. Flood protection is what began the process for the building of the dams. The many other important purposes the dams came along as bonuses. To eliminate the government-sponsored flood insurance effectively removes all accountability for flooding like what happened on the Missouri River system in the summer of 2011. And, that could have been prevented. No patronizing meetings with the USACE blaming the unpredictability of the weather will convince me or many other North Dakotans otherwise.

The USACE needs to be accountable for not fulfilling the first order of management of the dam system — flood control. Since last summer, FEMA has helped this Missouri basin landowner very little. I'd imagine the action proposed for NFIP will completely eliminate all assistance for future Corps' incompetency.

I think this action by FEMA and the action in Congress should be stopped. I will appeal to the North Dakota government officials to follow this closely for the citizens of their state. I believe they are likewise displeased by these actions.

attributes: {'commentOn': '09000064810106dc', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'APHIS-2011-0003-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'APHIS', 'city': 'Fort Lauderdale', 'category': None, 'comment': 'I strongly oppose to the proposed changes to the rules. The changes are absolutely unnecessary with respect to home bred cats because there are no large scale nor commercial breeding of  home-bred purebred cats. Such operation just doesn't exist! The moment you raise the number of cats in a home and the number of kittens being born in a season , sharing the areas in which homeownwers live  as bedrooms, livingrooms, kitchens, etc it just becomes impossible to handle. Not only that. A home is not a breeding facility. A home doesn't have the ability to be cleaned and sanitized as a factory, nor being hosed from floor to ceiling with desinfectants, therefore the home based operation is absolutely self limiting, because the moment cats and kittens raise from a certain limit, health problems start and people's lives become absolutely miserable. Vet costs sky rocket and the whole fun of home breeding and showing purebred cats is GONE!  We do not need regulation in this matter because the activity is TOTALLY self regulating!!  There are going to be very ugly unwanted consequences if this rule is passed. A lot of breeders will be forced out of their hobby and cat shows will  begin to dissapear. This is going to be detrimental to the economy as well. comment: I strongly oppose to the proposed changes to the rules. The changes are absolutely unnecessary with respect to home bred cats because there are no large scale nor commercial breeding of  home-bred purebred cats. Such operation just doesn't exist! The moment you raise the number of cats in a home and the number of kittens being born in a season , sharing the areas in which homeownwers live  as bedrooms, livingrooms, kitchens, etc it just becomes impossible to handle. Not only that. A home is not a breeding facility. A home doesn't have the ability to be cleaned and sanitized as a factory, nor being hosed from floor to ceiling with desinfectants, therefore the home based operation is absolutely self limiting, because the moment cats and kittens raise from a certain limit, health problems start and people's lives become absolutely miserable. Vet costs sky rocket and the whole fun of home breeding and showing purebred cats is GONE!  We do not need regulation in this matter because the activity is TOTALLY self regulating!!  There are going to be very ugly unwanted consequences if this rule is passed. A lot of breeders will be forced out of their hobby and cat shows will  begin to dissapear. This is going to be detrimental to the economy as well. Thank you
