comment:
I owned a GM vehicle with DRL AND automatic on/off
headlights. I owned that new vehicle for 8 months. The
single reason I sold it, was because of the DRL's AND auto
headlights. I HATED BOTH "FEATURES"!!!!! I now own two new
vehicles without DRL's and auto headlights. GM received a
few e-mail messages about these disgusting "features". Until
GM removes these "features" from it's vehicles, I will never
again own a GM vehicle.

If I wanted to be tracked by the government under which I lived, I would have
moved to China, the USSR, or North Korea. This program puts the United States of
America on the level with those 3 mistakes of humanity. I'm utterly disgusted
that terrorists have invaded our country on so high a level that they are
creating and maintaining programs like this one. Congress should put a stop to
this unAmerican program and all others like it and return our country to it's
original state: a country that doesn't interfere in the private lives of it's
law abiding citizens.

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064801e9d4a', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'DHS-2006-0060-0062', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'DHS', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'Re: Automated Targeting System

I am writing to request that the Department of Homeland Security suspend operation of
the Automated Targeted System (ATS) described in its November 2, 2006, Federal
Register notice. I believe ATS may have been implemented illegally for the following
reasons:
1. The 2007 Homeland Security funding bill prohibits government agencies from
developing algorithms that assign risk scores to travelers not on government watchlists.
See Public Law 109-295, Title V, Sec. 514(e), http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?
c109:H.R.5441.enr:
2. The Privacy Act of 1974 requires that an individual be permitted access, correct and
amend personal information. Under the DHS notice, individuals whose profiles are in
the ATS database, which, at the rate of around 400 million border crossing a year, now
contains hundreds of millions of records, have no right to access the database--
although a broad range of law enforcement agencies, their contractors and the courts
do have access. DHS may consider ATS profiles exempt under the Privacy Act's
provisions for law enforcement and intelligence information (5 US Code 552a (j)(2) and
(k)(2)), but risk assessments of innocent travelers that DHS intends to retain for 40
years should fall outside those exemptions.
I note that a similar program, TIA--Total or Terrorism Information Awareness, was
expressly defunded by Congress.
Yours truly,
Aaron Crum

', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': None, 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'DHS-2006-0060', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': None, 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064801ed904', 'lastName': None, 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2009-05-31T22:46:07Z', 'organization': None, 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2006-12-19T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2006-12-18T20:46:29Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': None, 'title': 'Comment Submitted By Aaron Crum', 'trackingNbr': '801ed904', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}
comment:
Re: Automated Targeting System

I am writing to request that the Department of Homeland Security suspend operation of
the Automated Targeted System (ATS) described in its November 2, 2006, Federal
Register notice. I believe ATS may have been implemented illegally for the following
reasons:
1. The 2007 Homeland Security funding bill prohibits government agencies from
developing algorithms that assign risk scores to travelers not on government watchlists.
See Public Law 109-295, Title V, Sec. 514(e), http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?
c109:H.R.5441.enr:
2. The Privacy Act of 1974 requires that an individual be permitted access, correct and
amend personal information. Under the DHS notice, individuals whose profiles are in
the ATS database, which, at the rate of around 400 million border crossing a year, now
contains hundreds of millions of records, have no right to access the database--
although a broad range of law enforcement agencies, their contractors and the courts
do have access. DHS may consider ATS profiles exempt under the Privacy Act's
provisions for law enforcement and intelligence information (5 US Code 552a (j)(2) and
(k)(2)), but risk assessments of innocent travelers that DHS intends to retain for 40
years should fall outside those exemptions.
I note that a similar program, TIA--Total or Terrorism Information Awareness, was
expressly defunded by Congress.
Yours truly,
Aaron Crum

attributes:
{'commentOn': '09000064801e743a', 'commentOnDocumentId': 'ESA-2006-0022-0001', 'duplicateComments': 0, 'address1': None, 'address2': None, 'agencyId': 'ESA', 'city': None, 'category': None, 'comment': 'From: Penny Boyer [pboyer@dormanproducts.com]
Posted At: Tuesday, December 05, 2006 12:41 PM
Conversation: FMLA Leave Suggestions

Subject: FMLA Leave Suggestions

We all agree that FMLA is well intended and for the most part, necessary. However, the application for certain situations is a bit disconcerting and causes morale problems. We would appreciate it if you would please consider the following scenarios when rewriting the law.

Travel to foreign countries
1. We have a very diverse community of employees. Many are from India, Bangladesh and similarly remote areas of the world. Currently our FMLA year is calendar based although we will be changing this in the future.
We find that when these employees are at work, they are very good workers but it is amazing how many of them receive notification from a relative that their parent is sick and they must return home. Most of these requests come in the October/Nov timeframe. The employees are given the appropriate FMLA paperwork. They fly to their native country and someone faxes the completed paperwork back to us. We have no good way of verifying that the person completing the paperwork is a doctor or if there is actually a medical situation for which they are needed. On the occasions where we called to verify information, no one spoke English.

Taking matters to the next step, several of these same employees provide additional documentation in mid-end December (they are still out on their original FMLA leave and still in their native country) that another parent has fallen ill and requires their assistance. Additional paperwork and certs are provided and the process begins again. These empoyees are staying out of work for up to 24 weeks (12 for the current year, 12 for the new year) and we cannot validate the situation. It causes a great morale problem especially when some return and are married. They talk openly among themselves that they must return home to marry but we cannot disprove the medical information. Obviously something isn't quite right with this. Since you are re-evaluating the law, please give some consideration to how employers are able to provide timeoff while still being assured that they are dealing with legitimate medical facilities around the world.

2. Intermittent FMLA places undue hardship on employers. For example, situations such as asthma, in which a child may need periodic treatments, are truly justifiable however, when employers are prevented from asking for medical documention each time someone is out to care for someone, the employer is placed in a difficult situation. Again,the appropriate forms are completed and returned; However, it is amazing how many children get asthma attacks on Mondays and Fridays. We do watch for trends and when they occur, we speak to the individual but the story
is always the same. Their child had an asthma attack. If the law
would permit us to require a doctor's note for each day that they are out on intermittent leave, we believe that some of the abuse would be
slowed.

I travel to each of our sites and I realize FMLA is a valuable benefit when it is medically justified. Unfortunately, many employees stop to ask me what I can do to stop the abuse. Employees talk to one another.
They tell each other the real reason why they're not at work and laugh that they are "protected" under the law.

Thank you for listening. Please give our issues some consideration as you re-write the law. Employers want to provide the appropriate time-off for true medical situations but when we are prevented from getting the documentation that we need in order to apply this law fairly, we are all placed in a difficult situation.

Thank you,

Penny C. Boyer
Dorman Products, Inc.
Vice President
Human Resources

CONFIDENTIALITY NOTE
The information transmitted is intended only for the person or entity to which it is addressed and may contain confidential and/or privileged material. Any review, retransmission, dissemination or other use of, or taking of any action in reliance upon, this information by persons or entities other than the intended recipient is prohibited. If you received this in error, please contact the sender and delete the material from any computer.
', 'country': None, 'displayProperties': [{'name': 'pageCount', 'label': 'Page Count', 'tooltip': 'Number of pages In the content file'}], 'docAbstract': None, 'docketId': 'ESA-2006-0022', 'documentType': 'Public Submission', 'email': None, 'fax': None, 'field1': None, 'field2': None, 'fileFormats': None, 'firstName': 'Penny', 'govAgency': None, 'govAgencyType': None, 'objectId': '09000064801ee07f', 'lastName': 'Boyer', 'legacyId': None, 'modifyDate': '2007-03-22T21:23:42Z', 'organization': 'Dorman Products, Inc.', 'originalDocumentId': '', 'pageCount': 0, 'phone': None, 'postedDate': '2006-12-19T05:00:00Z', 'postmarkDate': None, 'reasonWithdrawn': None, 'receiveDate': '2006-12-19T18:53:27Z', 'restrictReason': None, 'restrictReasonType': None, 'stateProvinceRegion': None, 'submitterRep': None, 'submitterRepAddress': None, 'submitterRepCityState': None, 'subtype': 'Public Comment', 'title': 'Penny Boyer', 'trackingNbr': '801ee07f', 'withdrawn': False, 'zip': None, 'openForComment': False}

It causes a great morale problem especially when some return and are married. They talk openly among themselves that they must return home to marry but we cannot disprove the medical information. Obviously something isn't quite right with this. Since you are re-evaluating the law, please give some consideration to how employers are able to provide timeoff while still being assured that they are dealing with legitimate medical facilities around the world.

2. Intermittent FMLA places undue hardship on employers. For example, situations such as asthma, in which a child may need periodic treatments, are truly justifiable however, when employers are prevented from asking for medical documention each time someone is out to care for someone, the employer is placed in a difficult situation. Again,the appropriate forms are completed and returned; However, it is amazing how many children get asthma attacks on Mondays and Fridays. We do watch for trends and when they occur, we speak to the individual but the story
is always the same. Their child had an asthma attack. If the law
would permit us to require a doctor's note for each day that they are out on intermittent leave, we believe that some of the abuse would be
slowed.

I travel to each of our sites and I realize FMLA is a valuable benefit when it is medically justified. Unfortunately, many employees stop to ask me what I can do to stop the abuse. Employees talk to one another.
They tell each other the real reason why they're not at work and laugh that they are "protected" under the law.

Thank you for listening. Please give our issues some consideration as you re-write the law. Employers want to provide the appropriate time-off for true medical situations but when we are prevented from getting the documentation that we need in order to apply this law fairly, we are all placed in a difficult situation.

Thank you,

Penny C. Boyer
Dorman Products, Inc.
Vice President
Human Resources
